title: RE: My Sequential Circuits Prophet 5
post_content: Quai34 wrote:So, as you don't have your Prohet 5 anymore, how do you building your Sound? You just remember it? Or you have them recorded?Anyway, thanks a lot for all those programs...Hi Quai34, the first two are on old recordings but also committed to memory.  They're fairly simple but still distinctive.  Your question did make me think about the old Prophet 5 programming.  With only 40 programs available, the Prophets used to come with sheets of the entire knob layout so folks could write down every knob setting of a good program to go back to. It would be interesting to take a few and see how well they transpose to the Stage 3.  I seem to recall the original 40 being provided with the P5 too - I wonder if any are online somewhere.

title: RE: Walk of life  Dire straits
post_content: Here's a revised version of "Walk of Life" by Dire Straits along with a MP3 example.  The B3 is on the left split, the intro DX7-type organ is on right split with control pedal for volume, and the middle section is set up if you want to drop the B3 to play the second harmony on the intro. I didn't spend much time on the middle section harmony as we've usually had the guitar player cover the harmony and me play the two dominant organ parts. Listening to the original again, I'd back off the B3 distortion just a little bit and turn up the B3 volume a little more to compensate.  Hope you like it - take care.DS WalkOfLife  W.mp3DS WalkOfLife  W.ns3fProgram for "Walk of Life" by Dire Straits(574 Bytes) Downloaded 2963 times

I didn't spend much time on the middle section harmony as we've usually had the guitar player cover the harmony and me play the two dominant organ parts. Listening to the original again, I'd back off the B3 distortion just a little bit and turn it up to compensate.  Hope you like it - take care.DS WalkOfLife  W.mp3DS WalkOfLife  W.ns3fPerfeito

title: RE: Walk of life  Dire straits
post_content: venro wrote:WannaBBbad can you be more specific about what DX type organ you use for the solo and where to find it for my E5D?Guy Fletcher was one of the keyboard players at the time and I understand he used the Yamaha DX1 quite a bit on that album. For my program, the synth uses Wave 1 "Mix Triangle - Second" with a triangle wave mixed in 2 octaves higher.  Unison mode is set to 1 and chorus is added as well.  If you're trying to recreate this with a E5D, absent finding a sample to get close (check the samples section of this forum) you could try using the B3 organ 8' and 2' stops (adding a little of the 1' stop perhaps), but route it through the chorus effect (slow) rather than the Leslie.  Hope this helps, take care.

title: How to get organ tone like Hailu Mergia / similar ethiojazz
post_content: I'm trying to emulate some of the classic tones of ethiopian jazz, particularly the organ on Hailu Mergia's album Wede Harer Guzo (e.g., the song Anchin Kfu Ayinkash). I have a Nord Stage 3. Any tips on organs/drawbar settings/effects I should be using to get this tone? I saw him perform recently and forgot to leer at the Nord he was using!

title: RE: How to get organ tone like Hailu Mergia / similar ethiojazz
post_content: I am not familiar with the song, artist, or genre (LOL)...I found this on YouTube, if it's the right song/version:This organ sounds a bit like a roller rink type of sound...not sure if it's Hammond or Lowrey, or something else...very transistor sounding with vibrato and reverb.I'd look at the Vox and Farfisa section of the NS3 for some of this...also if using the B3 model, using mostly the even drawbars will get you close to this...with some C/V.

title: RE: How to get organ tone like Hailu Mergia / similar ethiojazz
post_content: If that YouTube video is the sound you're looking for, I'd start with a hammond model, something like 408726600 or thereabouts, Leslie fast (maybe a V3 vibrato instead of the Leslie) lots and lots of reverb.The later solo sound around the 3 minute mark sounds more like a transistor organ, but you might be able to make it work by pulling the 8th drawbar or so…

title: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: Hi guys, please, I am trying to figure out how to avoid using a second device and also minimize switching between programs while playing. Pls could you share your ideas? I think I can achieve this only on NS4 (3 synth layers). Maybe you have some idea.I want to split keyboard into 3 zones because I am playing in a band a bass part (left hand), then I want to keep pads/strings (hold by pedal) and at the same time sometimes play a rock lead rigs by right hand. When I switch to the different program the background pad sound holding by pedal immediately disappears.But this configuration requires 3 synth parts playing in the same program.Do you have any idea? I know I can replace the middle with hammond for example but for worship background? Bass replacement with Hammond is also challenging.Thank you

title: RE: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: Mektyswrote:↑07 Jun 2024, 07:38When I switch to the different program the background pad sound holding by pedal immediately disappears.In my eyes, this shouldn't happen. 'Seamless transition' should keep the sound (at least for a moment).You probably know that splitting a NS3 into 3 zones is not a problem, but applying 3 synths is.Some people re-sample 2 sounds and create a custom sample with 2 distinct sounds applied to different parts of the keyboard. This has nothing to do with the instrument's split functionality - it's just up to your phantasy. It's to be done via Nord Sample Editor. And you will need to balance the volume of both beforehand.BTW: Nord have been famous for their organ engine; they still are famous for their piano samples. When you need to use your Stage 3 with 3 synth sounds, something must be odd in my opinion. There are other instruments that easily achieve this.

title: RE: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: FZieglerwrote:↑07 Jun 2024, 10:13Mektyswrote:↑07 Jun 2024, 07:38When I switch to the different program the background pad sound holding by pedal immediately disappears.In my eyes, this shouldn't happen. 'Seamless transition' should keep the sound (at least for a moment).Yes, in fact this should be the case and notes to be kept until/unless you release the sustain meantime (even just a small glitch would stop the previous sound) or you run out of polyphony of Synth section and the notes of the second sound (the lead) take priority.

title: RE: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: You can use the External section to control a phone/tablet with dedicated sound application and route it back to the Monitor In to add 2 extra "synth" engines.Fred

title: RE: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: Thanks for responses. You are right. On NS3 probably the sample is the only solution. Why I need 3 synth? Left hand Bass, midle are Pads/Strings, right hand Lead solo.Thanks

title: RE: NS3 split 3 zones synth sounds
post_content: cookiewrote:↑07 Jun 2024, 13:13You can use the External section to control a phone/tablet with dedicated sound application and route it back to the Monitor In to add 2 extra "synth" engines.FredJust to pile on Fred's suggestion, I'd move the lead to an iPad controlled by the External MIDI and feed the signal back. Personally I'd feed the iPad audio to a small mixer board, however Fred's suggestion is good: you can connect the iPad to the NS3 Monitor In if you prefer to go that route.

title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: Wish I could give you a good technical answer, but OT how freakin good is Nick? Bummer that funk apostles cancelled their Zurich gig later this year

title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: I'm hearing a polyphonic glide. I can't think of a way to achieve that on an A1, which I guess is equivalent to the S3 (except S3 has 2 slots compared to A1's 4?). If the intervals in his progression were always the same, I guess you could build the chord by detuning slots, apply glide to all, and play it with one finger. But that's not what Nick's doing on his prophet. It's an interesting sound

title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: Great playing in this song. The Prophet Rev2 has layering and I assume one sound can be in mono voice (unison) and the other polyphonic, but not sure if the mono voice will track the highest note played in a chord - it sounds like it to me.  The old Prophets would track the high note that way and I'd love it if the Nords could be capable of tracking like that when in mono voice, at least as an option. On my Prophet 10, I could combine the upper and lower synths with one being in mono with glide, which added a bit of flexibility in playing - it's one of the first things I looked for when I got my first Stage.  What I'm hearing is a dominant top note with glide and the other notes with a similar polyphonic sound. I tried a split with two synths on the NS3 last night, one for mono part, and covering the filters and volume with the mod wheel. It's a little harder to play with the split than being able to play with both hands like in the video and just have the high note tracked - this at least might get you started.Update:The program was revised 9/22/2018 to add the mod wheel also covering the drop in pitch which required using OSC2 for the primary voice.Update2:As Nick starts to "open" the filter (turn up the Freq) more as the song picks up, the program was revised 9/25/2018 with the filter applied to the Control Pedal (rather than volume). I also added two additional programs that achieve the same sound but each accommodates a different playing technique as follows:"NS TradeItAll W.ns3f" is the same as previously posted but with the filter applied to the Control Pedal for when the song picks up."NS TradeItAll2 W.ns3f" swaps the Control Pedal and Mod Wheel functions. The Control Pedal is used all the way up, and then backed off quickly to pull the pitch down and "open" the filter."NS TradeItAll3 W.ns3f" is the same as 2 but with left and right hand sounds swapped.Take care.NS TradeItAll  W.mp3NS TradeItAll  W.ns3fNS3 Program for Nick Semrad on Trade It All - soft synth - mono voice split left, polyphonic voices split right, with Mod Wheel covering filter and drop in pitch, and Control Pedal for filter only(574 Bytes) Downloaded 2025 timesNS TradeItAll2 W.ns3fNS3 Program for Nick Semrad on Trade It All - soft synth - mono voice split left, polyphonic voices split right, with Control Pedal covering filter and drop in pitch, and Mod Wheel for filter only(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1950 timesNS TradeItAll3 W.ns3fNS3 Program for Nick Semrad on Trade It All - soft synth - polyphonic voices split left, mono voice split right, with Control Pedal covering filter and drop in pitch, and Mod Wheel for filter only(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1972 times

title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: Listening to the song past this part, Nick opens up the filter (increases Freq) more for the sound when the song picks up, so the solution may be to put the quick change to the filter and pitch on the control pedal, and have the filter only on the mod wheel. If I kept the mod wheel as currently programmed, I'd keep the mono voice on the left as well because it's much easier making the quick change with the mod wheel and going back to a single note than going back to a full chord. title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: Hello, Great, bravo !!! you master the Nordstage very well, apparently!Can you tell me please, if you have time of course, if it's the same sound in the following intro:I love this sound mais, but I can not manage the kind of "bend" on the attack of each chord! you would be you ???Thank you, it's nice to meet Pros!See you soonStef

title: RE: Find Sound Nick Semrad Prophet 08 Rev2
post_content: stefmazurier wrote:Hello, Great, bravo !!! you master the Nordstage very well, apparently!Can you tell me please, if you have time of course, if it's the same sound in the following intro:I love this sound mais, but I can not manage the kind of "bend" on the attack of each chord! you would be you ???Thank you, it's nice to meet Pros!See you soonStefYes, the sound is very close.  Below are the steps you can follow to program it. Good luck!Load program "NS TradeItAll2 W.ns3f" from above and for both Slot A and Slot B:a) Hold down the CTRLPED button under MORPH ASSIGN and turn the synth FREQ knob until the OLED panel indicates TO: "none", meaning the Control Pedal will not adjust the Freq value.b) Release the CTRLPED button and then set FREQ to 147 Hz (or to what sounds good to you).c) For MOD ENV set the ATTACK to 3, a typical setting for "brass synth" sounds, the setting determines how long it takes for the envelope filter to ramp up from the FREQ setting to the upper bound set for MODULATION MOD ENV.d) For AMP ENV set the ATTACK to 0.e) Save the program with a different name (or you can rename it using Sound Manager).That's it. To play, back off the Control Pedal a little from its max setting (lowering the pitch of OSC2) and then play the chord while increasing the Control Pedal to max to bring the sound up to the correct pitch. The Mod Wheel morph is already set to turn the FREQ up more if needed.  I hope this helps you learn a little bit more about the NS3. Take care.Mr_-G- provided the following link to a great site to more about the concepts behind synthesizers:https://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... d-on-sound

title: Money for Nothing (using Sample Editor)
post_content: The intro Money for Nothing is an epic synth exhibition, that we all know and love. By my count it has at least 6 or 7 distinct synth sounds, that come and go at various times, behind Sting's voice.I have a single Stage 3 88. It can only do 2 synth voices at a time.I'm wondering if it is viable to use Sample Editor to create a SINGLE sample, with all 6 or 7 subsamples, mapped across the 88 keys. You'd simply learn when to trigger the various sounds, which all have their own lengths.Before I attempt this project, with a bunch of VST's that I have on my Mac, or the Nord Synth itself, I'm I missing anything?Is there any reason why this isn't possible? It seems to me that if you can map a whole drum kit on various Nord keys, why can't you simply do the same with a bunch of synth sounds, triggered by different keys.I'm looking for guidance from all you sample gurus.With thanks!!

title: RE: Money for Nothing (using Sample Editor)
post_content: Im in the same boat - once you are past the opening I think it just needs a digital synth (was originally done on a DX-7)  and an organ (typical warm dire straights organ) - let me know how you work out - I may try to program this on my stage 3 this week

title: RE: Money for Nothing (using Sample Editor)
post_content: Being that it's a DX7 heavy song, most of the sounds might already have DX7 (or Dexed) programs available on the internet. One, possible the most important one is already in both *.nsmp format, and as a raw sample source on this forum.Splitting inside of an *.nsmp is tried and tested i.e. numerous samples on Uptown Funk for example. The things you need to be acutely aware of are A: hthe sounds have to be correctly level matched in the *nsmp. B: any velocity, filter, envelope or FX will apply to the whole section. What you export (from NSE) is what you get.

title: RE: Money for Nothing (using Sample Editor)
post_content: Thanks Elias.  I have the Arturia DX7 virtual synth. I agree that the song is heavy in FM type sounds.

title: RE: Money for Nothing (using Sample Editor)
post_content: So, finally, I have something to contribute.There are 2 program: one for the synth intro and one for the song after Knopfler guitar starts.1) the cool synth intro is about 45 seconds long.  It is a call-response thing, with Sting's vocals.  Each time Sting finishes a couplet, there is a chord change.  I approached it with a split having my left hand do the pads and arpeggio, all of which I did with samples, so they are triggered with single keys.  The right hand is dedicated to the Moog-like lead line (sounds like a French Horn), which is Gm pentatonic noodling.I have a Stage 3-88, so the key assignments reflect that.Left hand is used to trigger these samples.C1 is the drone on G (it's the Shine On drone from another user)-Sting sings-D1 and Eb1 are hit at the same time.  There are the arpeggio and the Gm chord pad.-Sting sings-Gb1 is the Gm7/Ab chord pad-Sting sings-A1 is the Ebmaj7 chord pad-Sting sings-Return to Eb1 Gm).-Drummer starts-B1 is the first glissando padC2 is the second glissando pad.Right hand is used to do the lead line.2) is after the song starts.  I call is Zap-OrganThe left hand is used for that metallic DX7 stuff, that was previously uploaded on this forum.The right hand is used for the Hammond.I owe a debt of gratitude to other users on this forum for the Shine On, the Arpeggio, and the Metallic DX7 bit.  As they say, I stood on the shoulders of giants.Enjoy

title: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: I was just wondering if anyone had any opinions on Patch Foundry.  I was looking at their $80 "NS3 Cover Band Collection".  While $80 isn't nothing, I did just pay a lot more than that for my Stage 3 88.  And it seems like it might be fun to have some of those patches, and interesting to see the makeup of them.  I'm fumbling my way through learning the programming but it will be a while before I get good at it, if for no other reason that I have very limited time.  Have any of you bought this set, or others from them?  Or do you just program all your patches yourself, and trade/download others on this forum?

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: I don't think there is a "makeup" for those patches. They're probably just samples to load into the synth. You can have a lot of samples for free from nordusersounds.com - the sibling to the forum.If you are in a hurry and need those sounds, it's an option, though.I only bought an organ collection from SynthCloud - for similar reasons. Wanted to have a quick point to start from, but didn't touch them any more after purchase.I think what you really need is a reason to play your instrument and get in touch with it. Outside my band engagement, I exactly created 3 programs in 3 years - for playing around. But looking for a nice sound for a special song (needn't be close to the original, but must be matching in some way) is fun!

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: I stand corrected: That collection comprises settings for piano and organ sounds, too. There are synth sounds as well. So, if the factory sounds and the nordusersounds aren't enough to learn from, go for it!

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: Thanks for pointing out nordusersounds.com!  I had no idea that was out there.  About the Foundry stuff, again, I would prefer to not buy patches, but it's a pretty small amount vs. what I paid for the Stage 3.  And I could use a few of those sounds right out of the gate.

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: I would start by saying : if you don't have time, or the will to create your own programs and this package includes many songs you're covering with your band (and you like the demos) + the price is no issue, then go for it !Personally, I only bought samples (generated from specific machines) for my Stage. I don't use them that much for covers (except some D50 sounds) but fun to have and to play with (can lead to very interesting experimental sounds).All the programs for my cover band are homemade, generally using resources found here (those are the same found much more organised in the NUS) as a start. I always end up tweaking those programs to my own tasteThing is : depending on your band setup, you will need different programs configuration (remove brass sound cause you have a horn section, no bass as the bassist doesn't want to have another layer). So there is not a "standard" program for a covered song.If you're using 2 keyboards, then you may need to reconfigure which sounds plays with which keyboards and in the end, for i.e., may not use this synth lead sound on the upper split section in the Nord program (BTW, that is the most time-consuming sound to create).Also, some of the songs I play are covers of coversTherefore, the original "Wurly killer patch with phaser" is of no use.Then, out of the 200 programs in the package, you'll need only say 80, the rest is unused for the money... and you'll need in many cases to go back to programming for tweaking.Stage are so easy to program. Importing samples or creating your own sample is also a piece of cake with NSE v4.And again, the community here is sharing so many programs and so reactive to share samples/programs upon requests that I never felt the need to go to commercial banks !I'd like to mention the quality of the Nord (and other brands) sounds from NarfSounds. Great ready to use program for covers, worth to take a look at !Fred

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: A cover band recently hired me to play keys on a 3-4 set gig. They had about 70 songs in a few diff styles like rock, soul, r&b, pop, and country that I quickly needed programs for, which was pretty daunting. I checked thru the list of tunes at the patchfoundry site, and it hit almost 25 on the band’s, so I thought it was worth my time to purchase them.It has paid off. I have found the patches that I’m using to be surprisingly practical and well thought out. One thing to remember is that all these patches require the mod wheel to be pushed fully on. That allows the control pedal to function with various patches, usually in a pretty cool and playable way. That screwed me up on the first gig! LolRecently, the band asked me to learn a few new songs, and a couple were in the collection. I’ve been pleasantly surprised to find these patchfoundry programs because they have saved me time preparing new tunes. Sometimes, I have found myself tweaking the volume of the effects down a bit or some other minor tweaks to the preset, but I can say that the $80 has def been worth the hours it saved me programming! These programs, along with many others I’ve found on this forum, have given me great ideas for programming my sounds.YMMV

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: I have it. Compared to what other creators are charging for a fraction of the songs, it's well worth $80. Quite a few are very accurate. You Can Call Me Al comes to mind. My only beef is I wish there were instructions for EACH patch that explained what each part of the program are intended for, meaning, I want to know exactly how he uses each patch in each song for those of us who can't piece it together for the not so obvious ones. Sometimes there's some guess work especially when some of the parts don't match anything in the original song. Most are self explanatory. Would love it if there was a simple video example of every patch that just shows the songs broken up into the sections that are played. The YouTube videos just skim over it from what I can tell. Could easily make a drinking game out of taking a shot every time he says "How fun is that?" during the YouTube videos.

title: RE: Anyone buy Patch Foundry Collections?
post_content: This is Eric from Patch Foundry- don’t know how I’m just now finding this threadReally appreciate the feedback here- the tutorial ideas are something I’ve been working on for a long time, great idea! title: Hungry Like The Wolf
post_content: My band wants to play Hungry Like The Wolf.  Hoping someone has a NS3 program they'll share.I spotted ericL's over here.  Just wondering if anyone else has taken a stab at getting it all into one program (2 panels).viewtopic.php?p=146375#p146375By my ear it would need:- arpeggiator- sweeping pad in verse- hollow pad in chorus- the giggle at the beginning would be a nice touch!Anyone have one they can share?

title: RE: Hungry Like The Wolf
post_content: Glad you found my example. It's far from perfect, though it works well live.I hadn't thought of sampling the giggle at the beginning...good idea!I'm only using one program for this song with the arp on one panel and the phased pad on the other panel, with control pedal morph for volume swells. I change my layered Hammond drawbar setting within the same program. Clearly Nick Rhodes didn't use a Hammond, LOL...it just fattens it up for me and works well live.If you wanted to have the giggle, plus the arp, plus two different synth sounds for verse and chorus, that's four different things. That won't fit into one program with the limitation of two synth panels, unless you create some custom samples where, for example, you have the giggle assigned to the lowest key with two other verse/chorus sounds sampled into zones above that (catching three sounds on one synth panel). Then you'd have the other synth panel free for the arpeggiator thing. That's a bit of work, though it would be possible. Another option would be using two programs and splitting things between those. With seamless transition and song mode, it makes that sort of thing pretty smooth on the NS3.Good luck if you work on this and please share your results!

If so please move it to full volume and you should hear the sounds. If you do not have a control pedal just disable the control pedal morph on both panel A and panel B and move the synth volume up manually on both panelsThanks for clarifying Schorsch!Hi Joe, most of my programs use the morph function with the Control Pedal, even if it's just for adjusting levels.  As noted by Schorsch, to bypass the morph function, hold down the Morph Assign button for the Control Pedal and turn the synth Level dial down until the "To" value says "none" on the screen. I hope this helps, take care.

title: RE: Van Halen Jump - free to a good home
RE: Van Halen Jump - free to a good home
post_content: I revisited this program to sample it to a NSMP file for other Nord users and decided to add a little more to it.  "VH Jump V3a    W.ns3f" the same as my original for Panel A synth, and I added the Panel B synth to mix in just a little different attack to the beginning of the sound. "VH Jump V3b    W.ns3f" is the second program for the song with the Panel A synth on the left hand shifted a couple octaves and the Panel B synth providing the strings for the song. My earlier posthereworks well as a third program if you want to have the high C note on strings on hold while playing the Panel A synth with both hands.For other Nord users that use samples, I've also attached NSMP files that have the doubled-up synths for the intro and strings on the high end. Using octave shifting you can play the main part as loaded and then shift it up a couple octaves to have the strings on the right hand.  To make the sample, I used my Panel A synth for Jump and added the "Final Brass Motif.nsmp3" sample from Ivan Jochner in Panel B to add a little more punch. If interested, the sample is available with his post atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p106093.  Ivan's sample is fairly small and can easily be added in place of what I have for Panel B in "VH Jump V3a.ns3f", but my preference above was to create a "Jump" program that didn't require loading a sample - your choice.Two NSMP files are provided below. one covering synth and strings and a smaller without the strings so the second panel could be used to accent the primary synth. The note samples are long/looped, hence the file sizes. Take care.VH Jump V3a    W.ns3fStage 3 Program for intro synth in "Jump" by Van Halen(592 Bytes) Downloaded 971 timesVH Jump V3b    W.ns3fStage 3 Program synth and strings in "Jump" by Van Halen(592 Bytes) Downloaded 775 timesMP3 of "VH Jump V3a    W.ns3f" with Chorus added to Panel A, "VH Jump V3b    W.ns3f", and then  "VH Jump V3a    W.ns3f" without Chorus on Panel A.VH Jump V3 W.mp3...and "VH Jump W S.nsmp" played on my Stage 3 with reverb/delay addedMP3 example of Van Halen Jump W Small NSMP.mp3VH Jump W S.nsmpDoubled-up synths of "VH Jump V3a    W.ns3f" and the strings of "VH Jump V3b    W.ns3f"(6.06 MiB) Downloaded 1038 timesVH Jump SynthA.nsmpNSMP of doubled-up synths of "VH Jump V3a    W.ns3f"(2.98 MiB) Downloaded 955 times

title: RE: Jesus he knows me - Genesis
post_content: Here's a program to get you started with the intro synth and pad through the song.  A B3 is added on the Mod Wheel to bring up during the Chorus. An option as well is to assign the synth vibrato to the Mod Wheel for a little more emphasis when used in the middle of the song. For the MP3 example I'm playing along with the Karaoke Version demo with the keyboards removed. Good luck!Update Mar 10, 2022- Keyboard split moved to C4 and program renamed. I also posted a NSMP sample with both keyboard parts atnord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/gene ... 22152.htmlJesusHeKnowsMe W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 272 timesJesusHeKnowsMe W DEMO.mp3

title: Rosanna Toto
post_content: Hi there,new to his forum, because  I Just bought my Stage 3 this friday and have been working on my programs since (ok, i also slept for a few hours)I live by the credo 'if you ask, you also have to give'So here's my first contribution,Toto's Rosanna.In the first program, you have the piano, which you can layer with organ ('not quite a year, since you went away) and exchange in the chorus with the brass sound (synth)toto_1.mp3The second program is for the solo. On note C7 there is a short arp you can use in between the solo, thats the seperate sample.toto_2.mp3Hope everything is clear, otherwise, please let me know. Hope it can be useful to others. And maybe i may ask a favour now and then in return

title: RE: Donnie Iris Ah! Leah! Synth patch
post_content: Are you talking about the pipe organ type sound with the heavy reverb? If so, try the pipe organ 1 model. Rotor in Stop mode. 008888888. title: RE: Request / Help - Billy Preston Space Race Patch
post_content: The Clav has heavy compression on it as well as the up front wah action.Not with my instrument now but here's how you get the synth lead: (Tasten-Berts advice gets you close but not quite)- Single saw wave, nothing fancy- MONO or LEGATO mode- A bit of glide (2/10 or more)- Fair bit of resonance on an LP M filter- Filter cutoff to 100 Hz- Filter ENV modulation to around 4[EDIT] on the recording, the Envelope Modulation amount is adjusted, by hand but you'll get similar results by morphing filter cutoff freq:- Map filter cutoff to a morph source (recommend CTRLP)- Required morph range is up to you, maybe up to 2 kHz- Use "vibrato delay 1", (go to sound menu to adjust vibrato speed and depth if you need to)- LFO frequency changes during the song(     - In the beginning it's something like 15 Hz (cricket effect))(     - Later it's slowed down to create a wobble)- Map filter LFO to a morph source (recommend AT)- AMP ENV- attack = < 100 ms- decay = sustain (full)- release = 300 ms maybe- MOD ENV- attack = 300 ms- decay = sustain- release = 300 msI'm going to gamble and say that's super close to the original, but I don't know for sure until someone posts a demo of the result.BTW, I like synthesizers...

title: output volume
post_content: I have a NS3.  With the same volume level on both the section and the general volume, I get different output levels on the PA.  I guess the samples have different volume levels.Is there a way to equalize that so in a live setting, I don't need to adjust the volume when moving between programs ?

title: RE: output volume
post_content: There is a parameter for that, see Utility Functions - Program Level (PROG LEVEL) on NS3 manual(in general, it is a good thing to spend some time and read it all, to get a better knowledge of your NS3)

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Thx maxpiano, but the PROG LEVEL affects only the panels/engines of a single program.  What I'm looking for is leveling the volume across programs of a Song for instance, or across songs.

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Orionn wrote:Thx maxpiano, but the PROG LEVEL affects only the panels/engines of a single program.  What I'm looking for is leveling the volume across programs of a Song for instance, or across songs.Yes, you'll have to go through each program and adjust and set those levels on each program to match per your taste and playing style. There is no automatic way to do it.

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Well, that is a bit annoying, but is there an indication of the output level per program so at least to have an indication ?

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Orionn wrote:Well, that is a bit annoying, but is there an indication of the output level per program so at least to have an indication ?Your ears or the mixer VU Meters or equivalent... consider anywya that for dynamic sounds (particularly pianos) the level depends also on your playing style (in general and for that song), so you cannot define its "output level", just the max ... many discussions already made on this topic, like this onehttps://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stag ... 18875.html; bottom line managing the level across programs is an art and (yes) takes effort and try/adjust/retry cycles (and it depends also the final output device, what you her in headphoens may sound different than sending the same signal to a stage PA with subwoofers, for example) .

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Leveling across all the programs in a performance is a long and tedious job.  There is no "auto" button, but there are ways to make the process easier.I start by establishing reference sounds and levels for a few programs, then do a back-and-forth compare between the new program and the reference one.  I then roll through through all of them quickly.  I lightly compress everything to help my sound stay well-behaved.  On the NS4, you can create and re-use presets for each section which include volume settings, greatly simplifying the process.You only can get your levels close ahead of time, never dead on, so I will also monitor the PA mix directly through my IEMs, and then use a volume pedal to place the keys precisely in the mix.

title: RE: output volume
post_content: The volume of a synth program may vary a lot depending on the filter, the volume of different samples may be the same even if they should sound totallly different by their nature, the volume of a harpsichord or a clav is much more percussive than an organ sound which will again affect the perception of the loudness; not to mention swell and drawbars on the organ. So there never can be a correct normalisation in loudness, and Nord even didn't try to get closer to it.I started by setting pianos to -2 dB but never got the right relation between them and a lot of other sounds. I now think -9 ~ -6 dB could be a good starting point for standard piano sounds to leave enough overhead for those (synth) sounds which need more amplification.In the end, your FX settings and use case may define which level is best.

title: RE: output volume
post_content: Just play everything at full volume! You know, like your bass player probably does.

title: RE: one Vision sample
post_content: Hi,you still know to use Nord Sound Manager, right?It has multiple tabs and you need to use the samples tab to transfer the sample to your Stage.Then, you start with a new program on your Stage:a) you can use an existing one and just dial in the sample in the synth section ,b) use an empty one orc) initiate a new program with the PROG INIT button: [Shift][Transpose], then select a synth program.Finally don't forget to STORE AS in order to be able to apply a name and save it to a program bank.So, getting a new sample into a program is usually done in two steps.

title: missing sounds

title: RE: missing sounds
post_content: Check that Output Routing settings for Organ are not on OUT 3 and/or 4, the B3 may still be heard  on OUT 1/2 thanks to Rotary (when active it forces Out 1/2), but maybe it is never used with Vox/Farfisa

title: RE: missing sounds
post_content: And make sure there wasn't a change in swell pedal setting: Farfisa and Vox can go down to vol=0 while a B3 doesn't.

title: RE: Converting mp3- or wave-files to nsmp3
post_content: You need to use the Nord Sample Editor (NSE4) in order to get samples to load on an Electro, Stage, Piano or Grand. NSE4 allows line audio or 16 bit *.wav files as sources. In order to get an MP3 into a Stage, you'd need to convert it first into a *.wav file.And there is a length limit of 60 seconds for samples on the NSE4. Which wasn't there in NSE2.

title: RE: Converting mp3- or wave-files to nsmp3
post_content: O.k., I could load the .wav-File into the Editor. But I can't find any command in the menu to send it to the Nord or to the Nord Sound Manager. How does this work?

title: RE: Converting mp3- or wave-files to nsmp3
post_content: Just save it according to your instrument - in this case in nsmp3 format. Then load it with NSM.The right format will be selected for saving if your instrument is connected. You have free choice if it isn't.

title: RE: Converting mp3- or wave-files to nsmp3
post_content: Meantime I got it managed)But it was sent directly from the Editor to the Nord without using the Manager.

title: downloading npno files to Stage3
post_content: I want to download sounds from the Nord Sound Library (Nord Piano Library - White Grand as an example).  It says the sounds are compatible with NS3 but all the files are npno and the Nord Sound Manager does not recognize them as valid to download.

title: RE: downloading npno files to Stage3
post_content: Nord Sound Manager has several tabs for different aspects of the memory - Piano, Samples, Programs, Songs, etc.You need to go to the Piano tab in the Nord Sound Manager and download there - likely needing to delete or substitute existing piano samples if you don't have enough memory to load the new one.

post_content: I‘d say it’s a very common 8888 and you may add some approximately half pulled upper drawbars, no percussion, chorus 1 or 2, leslie with slight distortion and frequent slow - fast changes. Little or no reverb in order to make the fast attacks cut through.Good luck, cheers

title: RE: Looking for Motif ES BrassOctvs
post_content: There are a few "Motif Brass" based sounds onhttps://nordusersounds.com, maybe note exactly that one but you may find somethign similar (?)In any case, always consider that a Nord sample of that Motif sound will be a single waveform and mono-layer, (while the original may be multi-layer and multi-part/waveform), so it may not keep the same level of expressivity.

title: RE: Looking for Motif ES BrassOctvs
post_content: The mono-layer is limiting the use of this in a studio environment for detailed simulation. In a full band/live setting, the dynamics are less important.I deal with that with some velocity triggered filtering and layering with a Nord Sample (I like "pop section 3") on a different velocity sensitivityFor realistic Brass sections I would use a VST/Mainstage. I did this for years, but in the end I stopped with worrying on the stabiliby of this setup (That worked perfect). And had double macBooks, Carefully updating MacOS, Mainstage and PluginsIn my band the Nord is more than good enough!YMMV

title: Tips for program Only the Children - Toto
post_content: Hi! Could anyone help me how I can make my Nord sounding like Toto's Only the Children? There are synth sounds and piano sounds and now I might only be interested in piano sounds in the verse and chorus. What I could do that I can make the piano sounding as cool as it sounds in the verse? In the chorus it doesn't seem to be a basic piano either, there is some brightness or something else with it.Thank you for your help! It would be really great if I managed to sound as much like the real Toto as possible.

title: RE: Tips for program Only the Children - Toto
post_content: I like to layer a grand piano (in my case a the White Grand), with DigiGrand 1. The acoustic gives a natural body, while the digital gives a really nice sparkle and brightness. It will overall sound less static, as there are slight differences in tuning between the samples (also try with Grand + Upright or any other combo). Tasteful chorus, delay, compression, (EQ) and reverb on both pianos. For maximum effect, use different chorus and delay settings on them. I use this piano sound exclusively on stage, for all songs.But some songs require something a bit extra, like in this case. Then I just add a synth layer. For example on "The Best" (Tina Turner) I've layered it with the D50 sample that also appears on the original studio version. I also have one version with some strings added to fill up the sound. This is what the Stage 3 excels at.Now for this exact song: I hear a lot of octaves on the piano. Not sure how it was achieved in the studio, but that's what gibes it the brightness. 2 alternatives on the Stage 3:A: just change the octave range on one of the pianos. Might get you close enough with the brightness, but will take away from the fullness (because the piano layers aren't working in the same register anymore). Wether that's a bad thing or not.B: add synth layer(s) with up-octaved oscillators (or an alternative method), to achieve that sense of "brightness or something else".You're probably best off adding synth layers anyway.Just look for the right balance between octaves and fullness and punchiness all those cool words.And the synth programs that you layer on the pianos don't need to be anything crazy. They just need to blend in with the piano, if (like in this case) all that's needed is "brightness or something else". So often fast attack is a good thing, maybe cut out the bottom (so it's not competing with the piano. Find the healthy amount unison/detune/thickness.If the stars align, I'll upload the programs here that I talked about but for the mean time just try it out. Not that complicated to be honest, just some playing around with chorus rates and delay times.

title: RE: Tips for program Only the Children - Toto
post_content: Here is the base of all my piano programs. White Grand XL (can well be substituted) + DigiGrand 1.Seasoned Grand.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 87 timesSeasoned Grand, Stringed Grand, Best Grand.mp3I just did some playing around on my Stage 3: added piano timbre "bright", and layer detune 1. And finally a subtle pad for good measure.Toto Grand n Pad.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 73 timesSeasoned Grand, Toto Grand, Toto Grand + Pad.mp3EDIT: A bundle that also includes the Stringed and D50 bell versions. I swapped the White grand for the Clavinet to reduce file size.Piano Bundle compact.ns3fbRelink a Grand Piano of your choice to panel A(22.4 MiB) Downloaded 67 times

post_content: Hi everybody,this seems to be a good question for me to realize that all the nords, even the most expensive ones, can never compete with workstations like the ones I had from korg and Roland (perhaps also Yamaha, just that I could never make friends with them). On one of those I can combine 8 or 16 sounds of the same category, even the very same one, and can individually adjust pitch envelopes, attack phases, volumes, panorama, whether or not each one reacts to the wheel or pedals and so on. title: RE: Emulating live brass
post_content: Nothing beats real brass. That is for sure.Also not in loudness...I used Kurzweil and Motifs. Now with the Nord synths I mix and match some samples and synth brassMy bread and butter Brass sound is a Motif sample that I downloaded from this forum somewhere and the Pop section 3.On the Nord Stage 3 I slightly (5-10%) add a sub saw one octave below to add some meat on the synth sections.Play with velocity setting: best to have it different for both sound to have more dynamic change of sound.Some eq and little bit plate and delay will also help to blend it better.Works great in my coverband.On the Wave 2 you could mix 4 sounds (I would add a trumpet and a synth brass to the section)

title: RE: Emulating live brass
post_content: The original arrangement called for two trumpets, an alto sax, and a tenor sax. Sometimes playing two-part, three-part, or four-part.As someone mentioned earlier, there are samples of horn “falls” that would work in the chorus, but some of those hits are also non-fall.  The coda seems the most challenging part to perform, with all those pitch bends (along with subtle volume tweaks) that were individually crafted by those players, and are an important part of the “personality” of that riff.

title: RE: Emulating live brass
post_content: We will be rehearsing "I Wish" for the first time with our post-Covid band lineup at today's rehearsal.We do have a trumpet and sax in our band (my son and I).But I would say it's more important to get the different syncopated rhythms covered: (1) the part of 8th and 16th notes played in this version by a guitar. (2) the chords played usually on an EP, which have a different syncopation, and of course (3) the bass line, which can be covered by an electric bass. If your bass guitar player uses a 4-string bass, he might tune down his low E string half a step (this has been our bass player's choice).If you have no horns in your band, you might consider using a B3 organ part to covers the hits played by horns in the original. Just get the rhythms right.

title: Foreigner - Long Long Way Intro
post_content: All - I'm looking for how to duplicate the synth sweep in the intro of Foreigner's "Long Long Way".Looking for settings, samples, etc.  Any tips would be helpful.  Working on it now but have an audition and any assistance in making this quicker would be helpful as I have so much to focus on.Thank you!

title: RE: Foreigner - Long Long Way Intro
post_content: Hello, as you've owned a Stage 2 before this, I assume you know how to set up a synth sound using the MOD ENV filter Attack to slowly "open" the filter and Decay to set the timing of the "close". On the Stage 3, set the MODULATION Mod Env to 10, and Freq starting around 2, to set the range of the sweep you want.  Try a classic sawtooth wave (try unison=1) for your sound and a pulse (square) wave on the LFO for the note iteration. To help get you started, I have a program postedherenamed "LFOFilterSweep" that you can modify. I hope this helps, good luck!

title: RE: Request: synth opening SFX -Steve Miller “Jungle Love”
post_content: Hello, and welcome to the Forum!  I created this sound for my Stage EX years ago but haven't created one for the Stage 3.  I chose the "easy button" in this case and used the Nord Sample Editor 4 to create the attached sample that has the intro synth from the soundtrack on E1 (loops at end) and the whistle on F1. The file is in NSMP format and Nord Sound Manager will convert it to NSMP3 format when loading it on your Stage 3.  Set up a split for the synth (I placed it at bottom), load the sample, and then use "octave shift" if needed until you have the intro on E and whistle on F.  The sample is in mono to save sample space.  I hope this helps, good luck to you.JungleLoveIntro.nsmpIntro synth and whistle for Steve Miller Band "Jungle Love"(408.22 KiB) Downloaded 122 times

title: RE: Request: synth opening SFX -Steve Miller “Jungle Love”
post_content: Hello,My original file was a program created for an older Stage EX, which can't be used on a Stage 3. The synth sample I provided today will load onto your Stage 3 using Nord Sound Manager as long as you have available sample memory. Open up NSM, click on the Sample tab, click to be in "organize" mode, and then load the sample into an available memory location. If you have a folder open with the sample file, you can "drag and drop" the file into the location. As a note, you can create NSMP3 sample files using Nord Sample Editor, but you can't edit samples already created if you don't have the original WAV and project files.Good luck!

title: Programming a 3-way SPLIT
post_content: Hey all. I've had success with creating a 2 way split on the keyboard (e.g., piano and organ).  But last night I tried a 3-way split. All the sounds are synth-generated (a pad, and 2 sfx).  Everytime I tried adding the 3rd sound to part of the keyboard, it "cancelled" out one of the other sounds.I can play one sound on the A bank and one on the B bank, or both together if I select both A & B, but the 3rd synth sound won't go onto the program unless it replaces one of the other 2. Any solutions or instructions?  Is there a video or anything on this subject that might help?Thanks again Nord(ics)!ST

title: RE: Programming a 3-way SPLIT
post_content: You only have 2 Synth sections available on the NS3, A and B, so you can't have "3 Synths" in the same Program

title: RE: Programming a 3-way SPLIT
post_content: Hi Sean,welcome to this forum!I’m not sure what you mean by the 3rd synth sound? You have just 2 synth engines available, one on Panel A and one on Panel B. That gives you 2 synth sounds which you can assign to different split zones of the keyboard, play individually or layer them. You add a piano or organ sound to another split zone, but not a 3rd synth sound from the Nord Stage 3Edit: Max won the race once again

title: RE: Programming a 3-way SPLIT
post_content: got it  thanks makes sense

title: Using vent with stage 3
post_content: Hi everyone and thanks for advance for answering this for me. How do I set up the Nord stage 3 so that all the organ engine sounds come out of one channel? I want to run that channel out into a ventilator Leslie simulator. I know there’s a way of programming the Nord, but not sure how.

title: RE: Using vent with stage 3
post_content: There’s a global setting you can set for output 3 to route organ separately and send to Vent. This can also be set as a Program level setting, if you want to set it up more specifically for each Program. It's easy.

title: RE: Using vent with stage 3
post_content: System menu, p. 7: Output Panel A/B - Main 1-2, Sub Org, Dest 3.

title: I Want It That Way Backstreet Boys, Ideas?
post_content: Hi. Does anyone have any idea how to achieve the wahwah effect in the first verse of the song?Around 0.20 is what I mean

title: RE: I Want It That Way Backstreet Boys, Ideas?
post_content: It sounds like maybe an EP sound with a slow phaser. The effect is very wet. It may be a Rhodes type sound or even a DX7 tine piano with a fairly bright bite to it. There was a preset on my Yamaha S90 called "Sweetness" that was very close to this sound, though the phaser wasn't pulsing quite so strong.This could be made on most any of the Nord Stage or Electro series with some experimentation across EP sounds and the phaser FX.

title: RE: I Want It That Way Backstreet Boys, Ideas?
post_content: ericL wrote:It sounds like maybe an EP sound with a slow phaser. The effect is very wet. It may be a Rhodes type sound or even a DX7 tine piano with a fairly bright bite to it. There was a preset on my Yamaha S90 called "Sweetness" that was very close to this sound, though the phaser wasn't pulsing quite so strong.This could be made on most any of the Nord Stage or Electro series with some experimentation across EP sounds and the phaser FX.Thanks for the tip. Due to my life commitments, as well as this is a very last-minute song change, I don't have the time to sit down and think or work out what the sound is supposed to be. It's actually for tonight so I will try and play around later hopefully I will get the chance to, and report back how it goes (or rather sounds).

title: RE: I Want It That Way Backstreet Boys, Ideas?
post_content: I only managed to play around a bit, but it is definitely the phaser effect that is key to the sound. Just need more time to experiment with it. Thank you very much for the help.

title: RE: I Want It That Way Backstreet Boys, Ideas?
post_content: Keep in mind that phasers have a huge amount of parameters that will change the effect, and NS3 gives you very limited control. So don't expect to get it spot on. AND: the effect the record is always synced to the tempo, which is not possible on the Stage 3.If you want it spot on (which I think would be unnecessary anyway), I would recommend sampling it from the song or replicating it on your computer and sampling to the Nord.

title: Rock Guitar - A Few Programs
post_content: Hi everyone, below are a few programs with multiple guitars that might come in handy.Updated January 30, 2022 - Rock guitar with a clean Strat for rhythm. A variation on my previous post and this one driven by a post by bluetrain playing a song by Joe Satriani. This program has a clean Strat sample from my post atnord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/bass ... 21417.htmlwith compression, a Clavinet with EQ for a little low end "bass", and a distorted "Les Paul Neck-mic" sample on the right with harmonic on AfterTouch, vibrato on Mod Wheel, and Wah morphed to the control pedal. If you like, you can also try this program with my new "Strat Pad W.nsmp" sample atnord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/stra ... 22009.html.  I hope some of you get some use out of this. Take care.DistortedGuitr3W Demo.mp3DistortedGuitr3W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 731 timesUpdated March 1, 2020 - Solo guitar with harmonic feedback added using aftertouch. Starting with the program below I placed a B3/Leslie and clean Strat with Tremolo/Chorus left of the split, and solo guitar with harmonic feedback right of the split. The harmonic is added using OSC2 and mixed with OSC1 using aftertouch. This program uses the new Nord Strat sample"E Guitar S 62_ST Stereo 3.0.nsmp3" (included below), but if you want to save sample space (>4MB), the small Stratocaster sample below or others you may already have could be used instead. On the mp3 the B3 and Strat are both held with the sustain pedal so the left hand is free for the pitch bar, mod wheel, and Leslie slow/fast. The B3 volume is on the control pedal.  The solo guitar uses the stock "Les Paul Neck-mic" sample, but you can try out others to your taste. Take care.Stage 3 Program - DistortedGuitr2W.mp3DistortedGuitr2W.ns3fStage 3 program with solo guitar and harmonic feedback(592 Bytes) Downloaded 962 timesEddy Money - Two Tickets To Paradise.This program has a Hammond B3 and dual guitars using the stock samples "Les Paul Neck-mic" on left and "Dist Guit" on right.Eddy Money EM2Tickets2PrdzW.mp3EM2Tickets2PrdzW.ns3fStage 3 Program - Eddy Money - Two Tickets To Paradise - Dual rock guitars and B3(592 Bytes) Downloaded 893 timesThe Eagles - Hotel California - Dual Guitars.  As a complement to my 12-string program posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15723.html, this program was put together for the dual guitars at the end of Hotel California with organ behind each on the control pedal to fade in and accent notes as you want. The Stratocaster sample below, posted previously by DJKeys, is used on the left and the stock "Les Paul Neck-mic" sample is used on the right.HotelCalifornia_DualGuitars.mp3DistortedGuitrsW.ns3fStage 3 Program - Dual Rock Guitars(592 Bytes) Downloaded 1055 timesStratocaster.nsmpStratocaster Guitar Sample(152.22 KiB) Downloaded 1178 timesFor those new to programming - Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

Check it out below.Note - Control Pedal morphs the low pass filters of both Panels.Burning Down The House Line.mp3Talkbox Solo.ns3fTalkbox Solo(592 Bytes) Downloaded 427 times[nordusersounds][/nordusersounds]

If you listen closely to the original solo, Bernie's synth is in monophonic with the glide prominent, and then mono is switched off and chords are played, and then mono is switched back on. title: Noise sounds on Beatles "I Want You"
post_content: I'm trying to get the noise sounds happening on my NS3 for the end of "I Want You".I've added Noise 2 MixNs2 to classic triangle...it's just not as meaty sounding as I'd like. Any suggestions?Also is it possible to get noise without a tonal sound??

title: RE: Noise sounds on Beatles "I Want You"
post_content: Hi-There is a synth preset called Velocity Noise, 6-10. There is no audible tone in that. Turn decay all the way up to sustain the sound, use the M filter, maximum filter drive, additional drive from the EQ section and some chorus with the slowest speed.  Use minimal resonance and EQ to taste. This should get you closer to what you need--dj

title: RE: NS 2 to NS3?
post_content: hello how i can have the converter?  And how i can log in to nord page for the converter? thank you

title: RE: NS 2 to NS3?
post_content: Hi jusix,that converter has been hidden behind a login wall because its function now is built into the Nord Sound Manager: There was nothing else but converting (user) samples from V.2 (*.nsmp) to V.3 (*.nsmp3). Which is now done automatically when you try to load a V.2 sample to your NS3.Unfortunately, that conversion only works for user created content for conversion into V.4 (*.nsmp4). But as long as you don't have a Stage 4 or a Piano 5, this not an issue for you.

title: RE: NS 2 to NS3?

title: RE: NS 2 to NS3?
post_content: jusix wrote:nobody have to old converter?That converter is deprecated and useless, since Nord Sound Manager incorporates it now and anywayconversion was and is only related to Synth Samples( .nsmp and not Programs, just to be clear)

title: Programs F27, F45, B13
post_content: Hey All!I updated my NS3 to the latest firmware and now I cant find the F27 program, also F45 and B13 are not sounding the same as before. I had OS Version 1.X (not sure specifically which).I can't find an early Factory Reset file that might help me restore the previous sounds.Any ideas how to recover them?Thanks all!

title: RE: Programs F27, F45, B13
post_content: Hi. And welcome to the forum.Do you still have the factory-programs on your board? If so here's a link to the factory restore file:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/downloads/nord-stage-3In order to get to the specific programs, change the file ending from xxxxxxx.ns3b to xxxxxxxx.zip.When you unzip the package you can find the specific programs instead of installing the whole factory bundle.

title: RE: Programs F27, F45, B13
post_content: How did you proceed? If you only updated the OS, sounds shouldn't have changed much. The only thing that changed meanwhile is the velocity curve - but you can set it to a new legacy value in the System (or MIDI) settings.If ever you used a Factory bundle to update your system, sounds are part of the update, too, and the earlier sounds would be gone. Factory bundles may change over time. But that's what the Nord family is all about: having the means to create your own sounds and trying new samples from time to time.Whereas you will find older OS versions by manipulating the last figures of the download address, I don't think that it works the same way with factory bundles. But you may ask the Nord support.BTW: Do you remember the name of the program missing? Names rule in that case, not numbers.

title: Explore my Stage 3: sharing all my programs
post_content: Link to files in Google DriveThe core of my setup is the Stage 3. I can play a show with only a sustain pedal + a control pedal added to that. In the future I intend to use Mainstage for 2 main functions: A talkbox and sidechain. Sidechain requires routing outputs 1-2 of the S3 through Mainstage, with a kick mic signal pumping it when needed. The talk box is a completely different story (which I'm happy to share), but that is completely handled in mainstage apart from S3 Extern controlling it.I have thefull repertoireon Spotify (almost 4 hours), but I decided to remove unnecessary songs from this list. This includes songs that just use basic (but good) piano or B3 programs. I have 4 different grand piano patches, with various levels of padding on top of the Silver Grand XL (my only grand piano sample). I have 4 B3 programs with increasing amounts of overdrive (and a solo volume on panel B), so I avoid making 23 redundant B3 programs.I play in a 5 piece band, with 1 guitar, 2 keys (me being one of them), bass and drums. My fellow keyboardist mainly plays piano, and occasionally some EP. This leaves me with lots ofdoing whatever the hell I want. YAY!My strategy in programs levels might seem weird to you, I try to keep the average volume low, so I have lots of headroom for solo sounds. I generally keep my programs even in volume, but store small adjustments beforehand to aid whoever is in charge of mixing our band.Here are the songs:I colour coded the ones that don't have their own Song, but are instead grouped into one Song with others on the instrument.All Night Long - Lionel RichieAll Night Long-04-2022.mp3Africa - Toto[/color]Africa-04-2022.mp3Animal Spirits - Vulfpeck-  (a very funktional synth with optionally a Talkbox)The Best - Tina Turner-  (uses a killer D-50 sample, credit to whoever shared it here)The Best-04-2022.mp3Breakthrough - Queen-  (tailored B3 for our pianist because I'm singing)Careless Whisper - George Michael-  (I wish there was a cheese "smilie" available)Careless Whisper-04-2022.mp3Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic - The Police-  (arrangement is much like in "Live in Buenos Aires" version. my part is B3-piano combo, and I love it!)Every Little Thing-04-2022.mp3Get Lucky-  (piano-EP blend + lead)Gimme! Gimme! Gimme!-  (I have alternative programs for this. I like a simple (string)pad+lead combo with CtrlPed controlling the lead volume)Higher Ground-  (flashy clavinet)Hold The LineHot N Cold - Katie Perry-  (can be bland without the sidechain in Mainstage, but can be pumped with CtrlPed)Isn't She LovelyI Wish - Stevie Wonder-  (rhodes + hybrid brass)Jump - Van Halen-  (normal + solo program, solo with a CtrlPed bonus for added effect)Kung för en dag - Magnus Uggla-  (no one will ever need this)Let's Go Crazy-  (s slappier Farfisa with some sprinkles)The Power Of Love - Huey Lewis & The News-  (B3 - synth split)Purple RainRosanna-  (piano + solo synth)Seven Days - Stings*x On Fire - Kings of Leon-  (apparently the platform will automatically censor some words)Shut Up And Dance - WALK THE MOON-  (Also benefits from sidechain)SledgehammerSledgehammer-04-2022.mp3Superstition-  (flashy clavinet)Thriller-  (2 programs, split synth bass on left side in bothoutput 3, plays through bass amp)Uptown FunkYou Can Call Me Al - Paul SimonYou Can Call Me Al-04-2022.mp3Link to files in Google DriveI tried to make this as readable as possible. Hope I this was helpful.

title: RE: Love is a Battlefieled - Pat Benatar Request
post_content: Here is what I made for Love is a Battlefield. It's a high/low split with panel A being the low split for left hand and uses a factory program called "synth pad". Use this for the chord progressions with the left hand and when you get to the parts of the song where she sings "both of us knowing" and the pitch goes wonky, I set it up for aftertouch to give vibrato for the wonky sound, and then use the pitch bend knob to bend it down an octave as you release the note. It will give a similar effect to that in the song.The upper split (panel B) I just used the electric piano section (EP4 Mk5 80s) and used the EQ to dial down the treble a bit for a more muted and less bright piano like what I hear on the record.

title: Styx - Too Much Time On My Hands - Revised
post_content: Below is a revised version of "Too Much Time On My Hands" by Styx - I hope you like it.  The first program for the intro (Styx2MuchTime1 W.ns3f) uses the sample"Styx2MuchTime__W.nsmp3"in Slot A.  Hold the high F note until you add the intro bass with the left hand.  While playing the intro bass, increment to the second program (Styx2MuchTime2 W.ns3f) that has the same intro bass, but a Rhodes and filter-sweep synth on the right hand.  I've added the WAV for the intro in case you want to make your own sample for assignment to a different key. I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.  I've added a link below to access over 70 programs I've posted over the last few years that at least may be a nice starting point for other songs you're interested in.Take care.Styx2MuchTimeIntro.mp3Styx2MuchTime1 W.ns3fProgram - Styx2MuchTime1_W with Intro Sample on F7 and Synth Bass(574 Bytes) Downloaded 692 timesStyx2MuchTime2 W.ns3fProgram - Styx2MuchTime2_W with Synth Bass, Rhodes, and filter sweep(574 Bytes) Downloaded 624 timesPrograms, MP3 examples, and links to many othersFor those new to programming - 70+ programsnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Styx - Too Much Time On My Hands - Revised
post_content: Hello, I hope all of you are doing well.  Below is the latest Nord sample for the song with the beginning intro and the ending clock ticking/alarm.  The intro is up through C7, the clock ticking is Db7 thru Eb7 (pitched), and the alarm starts at E7. To use with my Stage 3 program "Styx2MuchTime1 W.ns3f" above you will need to point the synth to the new sample loaded.  The clock ticking is pitched with actual seconds on D7, but playing Db7 will slow it down a little, and it's looped in case you hold out that section of the song a little longer.  Altogether the sample is about 1 MB as it's in mono, however attached as well are the original WAV files in case you want to make a stereo sample (clock ticking is still in mono). Take care.

title: RE: Styx - Too Much Time On My Hands - Revised
post_content: I hope all of you are doing well. I took a different approach to this song recently and created a single sample covering all of the synth sounds and effects for other Nord keyboards.  Below is a new Stage 3 program that uses the sample in one panel and overdriven Overland Guitar sample #137 in the other panel. EP1 Pianos with Chorus are used on both panels. title: RE: Patches for pop songs needed
post_content: MichaelNord6 wrote:Hi, I’m gonna play concert in next few days on borrowed Nord Stage 3Your request is still too vague. You should be listing down what songs you plan to play so the community can help you out quicker. Perhaps you can do a search around the forum and you may find some patches out there that will work well for your needs.

title: RE: Patches for pop songs needed
post_content: Be sure there were people thinking about how to help. But how much time will you have with the borrowed instrumend before your gig? And what role are you playing in your band respectively what sounds are you looking for (and how many per song)? A Stage 3 has 2 panels to switch between and the morphing feature (for mod wheel and control pedal, maybe aftertouch as well) plus 3 splits available for the keyboard, so you'll need some time for each program to find out how it works. And you'll need the time to load all the sounds and those programs to the borrowed instrument - may take up to one and a half hours.I wasn't sure if we should encourage you to proceed that way if you don't have a NS3 at hand to organize everything in advance.

No this is a Patch to use for practicing or just for fun, if I may say so.With control pedal in upper position no change. With CtrlP down synth-arp kicks in.Tap the MST CLK button a minimum of four times to set a tempo.JfrsonSOrgCtrPmw.ns3fAn organ is hidden in the original patch.In this patch the Organ is on and synths is added with Control Pedal down.After touch adds rotary speaker.Echo is put on Mod-wheel.What, No sound demo? Please start producing!Not your Patch? No but it´s your Demo!JfrsonSOrgCtrPmw.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 263 timesJfrsonStrsSarArp.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 264 timesFor these 5 very first of you who has downloaded the Organ patch the Vibrato was put on Mod wheel. title: 7and5 piano sound
post_content: This isn’t necessarily a question for the Nord forum, but people on this forum are amazing at dissecting sounds. The “7and5” artist has a very specific piano sound on the melody on quite a few songs. It seems like it should be super simple to create, but I am not able to get it nailed. It is really a very simple piano sound with (I think?) quite a lot of reverb. An example starts at time 0:15 in this:In addition to the NS3 piano options, I have Spectrasonics KeyScape and Ivory 2, so I think I probably have the necessary raw materials. I quite like that sound and would like to have it as an available preset for impromptu melodies. Any hints at types of reverb or other processing that makes it ring like that?Thanks,Mark

title: RE: 7and5 piano sound
post_content: Layer two different grand pianos, eq them a bit differently. I think that should get you the richness. Add a very quiet soft pad — at the level where it’s almost more a psychoacoustic effect.Drench in reverb and delay (mix turned down pretty far, so that it’s a wash in the background, not necessarily something you actually notice).

title: RE: 7and5 piano sound
post_content: Ah - that seems good. I did not think of trying two pianos. I will work with that and see what I can get. Thanks!

title: RE: 7and5 piano sound
post_content: Thanks again analogika. I played around with this some and and had an enjoyable evening. The "two piano" hint seemed to be a key part in creating the target sound. I combined the white grand and the lady d on the NS3. I did add a bit of synth/pad with a medium-ish amplitude delay. And a little bit of most of the on-board effects (pan, chorus, delay, reverb). I also added a bit more reverb with an external pedal. Playing the melody line along with one of those 7and5 songs sounds pretty similar. To my ear, you were pretty much spot on with your ideas. Very fun!Thanks!

title: Killers - All These Things That I've Done
post_content: Hey guys, does anybody happen to have a program for Killers - All These Things That I've Done.Can't seem to get the organ right for some reason.Cheers

title: RE: Killers - All These Things That I've Done
post_content: Sounds like a pipe organ.On the NE6, I'd start with something like Pipe2, drawbars at 8080 00 000, SPKR/COMP set to ROTARY with Drive at 0, and Leslie set full wide (I don't recall all the menu Leslie settings but IIRC there's something like that.)Someone with better ears could get closer, but that's way close enough for a cover band.  For live use, I'd probably use PIPE1 8086 03 000, which has fewer overtones so takes less sonic space, cleaner, leaving more room for the vocals to stand out.

title: Styx - Fooling Yourself (The Angry Young Man)
post_content: I hope all of you are doing well.  Below are three programs I put together for "Fooling Yourself" by Styx that I've been wanting to play with the band (guess that means I have to learn it now).  Make sure you download all three.  The intro synth should be played a little differently than on the MP3 I recorded: with my right hand I'm simply holding the low A note with my thumb while triggering the higher notes, whereas on the record the low A is played and released like the other notes. It will sound even better if you play it that way.  The solo synth for the middle has a quick slap-back echo, a little amplifier distortion, and other settings to fatten it up a little - I can't wait to try through my regular setup.  As with all my MP3s, I record directly from the Stage 3 to my laptop so what you hear is all Stage 3.  Take care.Note: If unable to see the information below from the Nord User Sounds site, you may need to set your browser to accept third-party cookies.For those new to programming - Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: Hello,I'm using the NS3 File Viewer, and even on the NS3 itself I'm not fully capturing the original sound. Has anyone experienced this? I wanted to try to recreate the sound on the NS4, so I created a new patch on both NS3 and NS4 and went step by step. The sounds are close on the NS3, but I"m not experiencing the richness and depth of the patches on the NS4. Still, I was wondering if people have had issues recreating sounds on the NS3 with the File Viewer.

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: Hi-The file viewer is a great tool, but I think it was designed to get you close enough so that you were not starting from scratch. The hardware is different, so just inputting the same NS3 parameters will not result the same exact sound. You will need to use your ears to tweak the sound to your liking--dj

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: But I mean even trying to replicate on the NS3 where it came from...have you had any issues with that?

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: I am sorry, I don't get it: if you have the .ns3p and you need to "replicate " it in an NS3, why don't you just download it to the keyboard?

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: I don’t get it either, but that’s a different story I think.You should get the exact same sound if you rebuild a program on theSAMENS3 where it came from originally. If you rebuild it on another NS3 I would check if for example the OS version is different from the original NS3, if all general settings are the same, if the attached amplification is the same etc. - all of this may have an impact on the outcome

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: I know I SHOULD have the same sound on the same instrument, but that's not what's been happening. Have you tried it and it came out exactly the same? The reason I did it was that I wanted to do it anew on both the NS3 (from where the sound came from) and the NS4 step by step to see where sounds differed as I added each element. Then I ended up not achieving the same sound on the NS3, which surprised me. Maybe I just have to do it again, but I thought I would see if others had the same result.

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: I never tried it. But you don't give a lot of information about what you were doing.Are samples implied? Do you have the same samples installed?

title: RE: File Viewer--not quite capturing the program
post_content: File Viewer is just displaying the parameters of a program file (Stage 2 and Stage 3).Replicating to another model may lead to not exactly the same sound (Synth engine obviously, but also some parameters that are not available on both models). But basically, again apart from the Synth engine, you'll get 90% common parameters, and this really helps converting quickly !Fred

title: RE: SAMPLE WHISTLE
post_content: in short, how to recreate samples like .nsmp / .nspg / .ns2p into nsmp that supports Nord Stage 3?

title: RE: SAMPLE WHISTLE
post_content: chopinko wrote:in short, how to recreate samples like .nsmp / .nspg / .ns2p into nsmp that supports Nord Stage 3?Nord Sound Manager will convert NSMP files to NSMP3 format when loading them onto your NS3. The other file types, ".nspg" and ".nsp2", are older Stage and Stage 2 program files respectively that can't be converted to samples. If you have one of the older keyboards you could create samples of program sounds you like using the Nord Sample Editor 4. You can view the settings of Stage 2 programs with theNS2 and NS3 Program Viewerand try to recreate them on your Stage 3. I hope that helps, good luck.

title: Steely Dan wurli/ Rhodes
post_content: I'm looking for some good Rhodes sounds for the Steely Dan tunes. I used to have a Rhodes with the tines setup for max. harmonics and stretch tuned, so when you hit the keys hard you get what I call "spitting: where the  sharp attack has tons of enharmonic partials. The Rhodes sound is most noticeable on the Katy Lied album. Some combinations of Rhodes sounds on NS3 come close, but not quite there

title: RE: Steely Dan wurli/ Rhodes
post_content: If you still have access to a real Rhodes with those characteristics you can sample the sounds yourself directly into your Stage 3 using the Sample editor and a modern A/D converter. It’s really easy to do and there are online tutorials available on YouTube that’ll get you going with the Sample editor in an hour or less.

title: RE: Steely Dan wurli/ Rhodes
post_content: I got real close by layering the Wurli and the EP 1 deep sound. Flange on the Wurli. with the compressor cranked, chorus and very short delay on the EP with a small amount of panning. All Flange.chorus, pan   rates very slightly offset .Stage reverb on the Wurli., room 2 on the EP. The compressor cranked gives it more of the sharp attack I was looking for.

title: RE: Walk this way second guitar sound
post_content: Hello, it would be helpful if you posted a link to the video or an audio clip of the 2nd guitar part you are interested in.

title: RE: Walk this way second guitar sound
post_content: Here ya' go.The guitar part is on the right side of the stereo field.

title: RE: Walk this way second guitar sound
post_content: That's a tough one between the pick action and the guitar strings being dampened in different ways by the hand. I'd either start out with samples played for the specific part to get a head start, or try to get that effect with the MOD ENV Velocity so notes played lighter would sound more muted. The Decay for both MOD and AMP ENV would have to be played around with also. With the isolated guitar audio, you could try sampling a few notes to see how good they sound in playback and work from there.  Here's an example if you wanted to sample riffs instead of individual notes.Aerosmith WTW Verse 2nd Guitar Example.mp3

title: Levitating by Dua Lipa sample/patches
post_content: Hi guysWas wondering if anyone has access or knows how to create the synth sound of the keys in dua lipa’s levitating.All help is useful.Thanks for your help I’m advance

title: RE: Levitating by Dua Lipa sample/patches
post_content: Hi,I made this little programm for you. It comes pretty close, but it is not 100% accurate. The problem is, there is a short attack-bend in that sound, sadly the NS3 on wich I programmed that, is not able to do that. The workaround would be to use a sample that has this small transient already in it. But the benefit of this program is, you do not need to load any samples, I used a sample that is already factory-preloaded (Choir Mixed Soft) in the NS3. Should handle it.It seems to me that this sample is in fact the base of the original wich has been modulated.

title: RE: Levitating by Dua Lipa sample/patches
post_content: Kaffimusic wrote:Hi,I made this little programm for you. It comes pretty close, but it is not 100% accurate. The problem is, there is a short attack-bend in that sound, sadly the NS3 on wich I programmed that, is not able to do that. The workaround would be to use a sample that has this small transient already in it. But the benefit of this program is, you do not need to load any samples, I used a sample that is already factory-preloaded (Choir Mixed Soft) in the NS3. Should handle it.It seems to me that this sample is in fact the base of the original wich has been modulated.Hello, for certain sounds, but not samples, you can get the bend-up effect with the Stage 3, but the MOD ENV Decay has to be set at max to not bend back down and release has to be set short. If you want to try it with the program you created, here's a link to a program for Crazy Dream by Tom Misch that is set up for it on one of the synths. Good luck!nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 16227.html
