title: RE: Levitating by Dua Lipa sample/patches
post_content: Winds wrote:Hey there. I think I got the P1W working fine. But the P2W I didn't seem to get it work correctly. Can you help me diagnose what step I must have missed?I created P1W to make the sample I originally used for P2W, so it isn't needed to play the song.  After creating P2W I put together a different sample taken from the original recording, so the program needs to be pointed to the new sample. Here are the steps needed:a) Open Nord Sound Manager and select "Organize" mode.b) Load the sample "DL Levitating2 W.nsmp" into an open sample memory slot. NSM will covert it to NSMP3 format. Note which location the sample is saved.c) Load the program "DL LevitatingP2W.ns3f".d) Select the program on your Stage 3, switch to Panel B, and turn the OSC1 Waveform dial to go to the sample location of "DL Levitating2 W".e) Save the program with the proper sample selected.Let me know if that works for you. Take care

title: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: helloi have a problem  with the organ engineall the sounds distorted'some dont work and thier volume is significantly lower than the rest of the sounds/anyone know how to solve this?

title: RE: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: Hi,can you let us know a bit more about your settings, for example- have you connected something to the organ swell or control pedal connectors and if so, what has been connected?- how do all of the organ settings look like in detail- how and through which outputs is your Nord connected to your amplification- is it the same through amplification and headphones

title: RE: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: Hi all,Has there been a resolution to this issue?I have recently discovered the same issue on my NS3 Compact. I have updated to the latest OS and this hasn't helped.Sometimes the volume of the organ engine comes back to where it should be (by its own accord) after playing for a few minutes, but then also randomly reduces volume.The other engines are providing output fine and I've swapped headphones to isolate the issue specifically to the organ engine alone.It is definitely a problem with the output of the organ engine in my NS3. It is nothing to do with settings (as I've previously successfully saved lots of programs and songs, but now they no longer work properly because of the organ engine issue).I have also reverted back to basics just turning on the organ engine in isolation (with piano engine and synth engines switched off) and ensuring any pedals are not connected. I've also cycled through the factory organ presets. However, the problem still remains throughout and the Farfisa model doesn't appear to be giving any sound output.I have had my NS3 Compact from new and had Electro 5d and Electro 4D before, so I am well versed in Nord architecture and I'm confident that this is not a "user error" in relation to any saved settings.Any suggestions or experience of how to fix this issue would be greatly appreciated.

title: RE: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: This sounds to me very much like a swell pedal issue: Swell reduces volume down to 0 on the Farfise but not on a B3. If you say you don't have a swell pedal connected to your Nord, have a look into the jack if there is some dirt inside. Or try with a continuous sustain pedal connected to the swell jack. What happens?

title: RE: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: Thanks for the suggestion.I've given that a try and also put a small amount of contact cleaner into all of the sockets on the rear.The connection of the sustain pedal into the swell socket didn't seem to make any difference (depressed or released).I've disconnected it but connected the volume pedal into the CTRL socket and have switched back into song mode, and for the saved songs containing organ parts it seems to have returned to previous (correct) volume levels. So hopefully using some contact cleaner and jiggling with pedals in sockets has hopefully resolved the issue. I'll keep an eye on things to see how it goes.FZiegler - thanks very much for your suggestions, they are greatly appreciated.

title: RE: problem with organ engine nord stage 3 -help
post_content: Glad it helped.

title: Solo Synth in NIN Closer Live Version
post_content: Greetings,I have been working to develop synth sounds to cover NIN Closer and have made pretty good progress so far. While it is easy to take isolated tracks and create samples and then map them onto keys, I have taken the time to listen and try to recreate without using cut and paste samples. So far so good with main bass riff, pan flutes, electric staccato/gated keys, and distorted phased guitar. I'm now trying to recreate the solo synth sound from a live version (Nine Inch Nails - Closer (Live: Beside You in Time - Unedited)) that starts at 2:49. I can hear a chirpy steel drumish sound with a bit of white noise. Not sure how to recreate without any samples by using just the synth, piano, and organ sections (or any combination of those). I'm open to any and all suggestions.Maybe start with an electric piano to cover the steel drum aspect, add a bit of autowah for chirp, and perhaps some distorion to get noise? Didn't get me there, though I can hear some bits that are.Thank in advance to any responders.Best,Rackmount

title: RE: Solo Synth in NIN Closer Live Version
post_content: It sounds like a ring modulation (RM) effect is being applied to the synth. RM is interesting to play around with, it can make the upper range of a Grand sound like a toy piano.

title: RE: Solo Synth in NIN Closer Live Version
post_content: Thanks for your input. I have seen and used many of your patches and found them to be pretty darn good at capturing the essence of sounds you are aiming for. I will investigate RM a bit and see what I come up with on my existing and perhaps a newer version.Rackmount

title: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs
post_content: Hi all,I'm looking at the brilliant Program Viewer tool that @florence and others have put together:nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 19939.htmlIt seems that it wouldn't be too hard to make a tool which did a basic job of creating NS3 or NS4 programs from previous versions.  Obviously the tool wouldn't be able to replicate the programs fully because the keyboard functionality is so different... but I think the following would be incredibly useful, and probably straightforward for someone with the right skills? My idea is:- Export my existing custom programs (in my case approx 40 of them on NS2)- The tool:-- Creates a new program for each (for either NS3 or NS4), with the correct name-- Assigns the correct sounds and samples to the slots / sections-- Does one or two basics that are common across boards, e.g. sets split points, volume- Import the new Programs to the new keyboardIt would save hours just from creating the basic names programs with the right sounds assigned.  From there I can sort out effects, or improve with all the new features like piano dynamics etc.What do you think? Is it doable? Who could do the actual work, and would a few of us chuck a few $$ towards it as a project?

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs
post_content: spradders wrote:What do you think? Is it doable?Yes, I think it's doable in general, but it requires full analysis of the different program structures of each of the instruments, which I am not sure was done by Florence for NS2 and NS3 since there might be more information in the files and specifics of the file formats than needed to identify the elements of a program. For NS4 there is no work done yet so this has to be fully analyzed first, which is a really time consuming process as I could imaginespradders wrote:Who could do the actual workWell, in theory everyone who is able to "re-engineer" the Nord file formats in total, has the programming skills to create such a tool and sufficient free time - plus help from NS4 users for the NS3 part (see my answer above for the first part of your question).spradders wrote:would a few of us chuck a few $$ towards it as a project?Yes absolutely, I would be willing to donate some money to support such a project!

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs
post_content: hiThis idea was already on the table when the NS3 was released, and makes a lot of sense of course. Nord should provide such app actually!Today the NS2/NS3 viewer app is 'only' a viewer to avoid any issue downloading non official file into our baby, but all the NS2/NS3 file structure is now available after, many, many hours.But for now I decided to not add a 'write program' feature to avoid any version issue. Why? Because this needs to be tested, maintained on each OS upgrade, and I simply have no spare time to spend on this.Also have no plan to migrate to the NS4 for now, maybe in 2/3 years but no needs for me to spend so much money, I'm not pro giging every week...As code is free and public, maybe another volunteer can jump in

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs

I would be willing to contribute to such a project as well but agree with florence that it would be easier if Nord took on the task (or at least provided assistance).

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs

title: RE: Tool to create NS3 and NS4 programs from NS2 and NS3 progs

post_content: Can't say enough on the tremendous work by Florence to create the NS2/3 Viewer, not forgetting the precious fellows who helped generate each program file for every single parameter change ! title: RE: descending synth sweep
post_content: MEL868 wrote:not what i was looking for.  it's the sweep descending sound in the video.  that's ok, it's minor, i just like it and thought i could use it for other applications.  The flute simulation Lizzo uses, is easy, all set with that.  i'll have another listen to it and try again.I can hear it, that "jet" effect, like a BP filtered noise descending sweep; there is a Synth preset on NS3 called Leaked Air, try to modify it using a BP Filter and then play with Freq (set it to the middle or less), add Mod Env modulation of filter and set Mod Env Decay according to sweep speed you need.PS: or check this free samples, which sounds similarhttps://samplefocus.com/samples/special-synth-fxorhttps://samplefocus.com/samples/noisy-fx-crushed(hover the mouse on the waveform to listen to it); you may import it in NSE4 and create a .nsmp to use in NS3 as a starting point, then just add some filter and envelope

title: RE: Street life piano Rhodes?
post_content: I love this Forum. Somehow some songs get by that I haven't heard over the years until brought up like this one. What a great Rhodes solo in this song!  Away from my NS3 as well, I believe the hard attack sometimes heard will come out a little more with KB set to 1 or 2 while retaining some dynamics. Only being able to listen to it on my phone, the original Rhodes sounds pretty clean (no chorus), but the chorus effect did start to become popular around '79, especially the Roland CE-1 that also had a great preamp in it that was perfect for the Rhodes. title: TRACY CHAPMAN - TALKIN' BOUT REVOLUTION
post_content: Good morning,I hope my request will not be deleted.I actually have two:I'm looking for the exact sound of the organ on this piece (talkin' bout revolution by Tracy Chapman).My second request is a little different, but I would really like to find the sheet music (even paid of course) or a video that allows me to see what the keyboard is playing exactly.I only have this version (), but can't decipher what it does on the keyboard. My ear is not trained enough.Thank you in advance for your help and sorry for my English google translation

title: RE: TRACY CHAPMAN - TALKIN' BOUT REVOLUTION
post_content: It sounds like a pretty typical organ sound. When organ tones get high enough, they start to sound thinner, and it becomes less critical to use the exact same drawbar settings that the player used in the recording you are listening to. I would start with 888888888, then play the top pitch alone, to see if it sounds reasonable or if you need to reduce certain drawbar settings. Then figure out what the next lowest note needs to be, play test those 'second notes' along with the 'top notes' and see if you need to modify the drawbar settings then, and continue.There is probably some chorus or vibrato in there too. You can add that either on an Electro or Stage.This organ part is not the main thing - it is a decoration. If you get the top two sounds of the chord right, with the right tone (drawbar and chorus settings), it will probably sound right in a band context, because the rhythm guitar and bass parts are much more prominent and important.Regarding the top note of the chord, for a lot of time in this song I hear a lot of the note "G": For example, for most of the time from 1:57-2:08 the "G" is most prominent at the top of the chord, and you can hear where it occasionally dips down to F#. The same is true earlier in the song, from 0:50-1:17. And then from 1:17-1:18 the organ sound gets richer - maybe an extra note below the others was added to the chord, or maybe the organ play added some volume via the control pedal?Part of what you will need to do will depend on how your band's guitarist plays. If they use an acoustic and play it similar to what you see in this video, that will leave space for you to play those sustained organ notes at a relatively high pitch, which you hear in this video. In the video, those two chord playing instruments did not step on each other's sound space - you can hear both, even with the organ part being soft. If your guitarist plays on electric instead of acoustic, that might change things, and if your guitarist starts playing higher chord voicings or most sustained notes, that could change things too.

title: RE: TRACY CHAPMAN - TALKIN' BOUT REVOLUTION
post_content: Yep, I would start the way harmonizer suggests, you‘ll get very close to it. G - C - E minor - D is what I can see from the guitar. And the part of which harmonizer says „organ sound gets richer“ I‘d say the Leslie turns to fast.And at around 2:10 he smears the change from D to G with short d - b - a - g.Nice tune, enjoy it. CheersEdit: corrected the bar at 2:10.

title: RE: We will rock you- Request done
post_content: Thanks for the"We will Rock You"Sound. But I have a technical question related to splitted sounds...Is it possible to separate the two sounds"BD"and"Snare+Claps"to have them on independend keys? I ask because "in live" our drummer not always keeps the speed 169How many split zone are possible?And what software do I use to build samples like this and convert them at the end to a NORD conform format? Is there already a manual in the forum ?I have to tell you I only have a Nord Electro 6!

title: RE: We will rock you- Request done
post_content: A few answers below:>> Is it possible to separate the two sounds"BD"and"Snare+Claps"to have them on independend keys?YES>>How many split zone are possible?With a sample every key can have a different sound, so you can set up your sample according to how you want to use it on your Electro 6.>>And what software do I use to build samples like this and convert them at the end to a NORD conform format? Is there already a manual in the forum ?At this link you can download the Nord Sample Editor 4 application and read their online guide: websitehttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/software- ... e-editor-4To create the separate sounds you need,- open the NSE4 software,- either a) load the original clip (saved as a WAV file) into NSE4 (drag-n-drop directly to a key also works well in this case), or b) record the sound directly into your laptop from your Electro 6,- copy the clip to the keys you want,- modify the start and stop time of the clip used for each key to have one key cover just the "BD" and the other cover the "Snare+Claps",- set the keyboard range you want for each sound and set the key samples as "unpitched".  For example, if you assigned BD to key C3 and the Snare+Claps to D3, the actual range of the BD sound can be all notes below C3 and C#3, and the range for the Snare+Claps could be D3 and above.  "Unpitched" is needed otherwise the sound on will be interpolated and sound like a recording being slowed down or sped up depending on whether below or above the root key used.As there's more to creating a sample than just the basic steps above, I'd suggest reading the online guide first to help fill in the blanks.  I hope this helps, good luck!

title: Hard Rock Organ Settings
post_content: Hello everybody!No question, no complaints - I just wanted to share my settings for the Hammond section I’m using in my hard rock tribute band.For a change, I’d like to comment on how amazingly good the Stage 3 organ works in a live/band environment. Having tried every available clonewheel on the market, I never had one that sounded better in a full rock band mix. I thoroughly tested Crumar Mojo, Viscount Legend, HX3, Hammond XK1c but none of them made me happy.My old Stage 2 EX, then my Electro 6D and currently my Stage 3 all made the FOH guys happy, commenting on how great they sounded through different PA systems.So these are the settings with some comments:EQ:- Treble +10.0 dB- Mid Freq 306 Hz- Mid +5.0 dB- Bass +5.0 dB=> That’s giving the B3 lots of treble to increase perceived overdrive and key click as well as some oomph in the lower mids- Drive (EQ Section): 3.0- Hammond Section Vol: -10.1=> The EQ increases the loudness so I had to tone down volume and use the EQ section drive for compensating the lack of distortion. Otherwise it’s hard to balance the B3 with other sounds.- Compressor: 5.0Hammond Sound Settings:- Tonewheel Mode: Vintage 2- Click Level: High- Rotary Speaker Type: 122- Rotary Balance: Bass/Horn 40/60- Rotary Rotor Speed: Low- Rotary Horn Speed: Low=> Yes, I’m not using the 122 Close like most people do. With the high amount of treble, the „throb“ (amplitude modulation) is just too much through a big PA. Also, am I the only one noticing that the 122 Close setting takes away all the presence in the higher mids?In addition, a citation from maestro Jon Lord about Chorus/Vibrato: „C1 - only one I ever use.“

title: RE: Hard Rock Organ Settings
post_content: I just wanted to directly share the programs I use most of the time:B3 Classic Rock:- basic, all-purpose Hammond for rock songs- overdrive is kept in the middle, turn up the Rotary Speaker Drive for full on distortionB3 Classic Rock.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 331 timesB3 Classic Rock.mp3B3 Lord 80s:- Perfect Strangers era Hammond with heavy distortion- contrary to what most people think, Jon did NOT refrain from using guitar amps, he used both Leslies and stationary amps at the same timePanel A: Hammond through Rotary SpeakerPanel B: Hammond through Twin amp with heavy EQ settings and DriveB3 Lord 80s.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 256 timesB3 Lord 80s.mp3B3 Lord 70s:- Machine Head era Hammond -> Second drawbar half in! Jon did never use the classic "Four Out" drawbar setting.- Jon had an RMI E-Piano wired into his upper manual that he used lots of times, it gives a lot of balls to the organ -> just listen to the studio recording of Space Truckin'- as there's no high gain guitar amp simulation, I also did a layer of two organs:Panel A: Hammond through Rotary Speaker put to Stop Mode | RMI E-Piano with filter distortion (Synth section) layered below middle CPanel B: Hammond through Twin amp with heavy EQ settings and DriveB3 Lord 70s.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 245 timesB3 Lord 70s.mp3

After making your new WAV file, you would load the WAV file into the Nord Sample Editor 4 to create a new sample. title: Morph wheel not always in full range
post_content: Hello,I just noticed that the morph wheel on my Stage 3 Compact does not always control the full range of what is set for morphing.As an example, I have created a programme where I set the organ volume to 100% and the piano volume to zero. I set the wheel to reduce the organ volume to zero and the piano volume to 100% when the wheel is pushed all the way up, and of course back to 100% for the organ and zero for the piano when it is pushed all the way back. Now I see that sometimes when I push the wheel all the way up or down, it doesn't go to 100% or zero, the last LED (the one for 100% and the one for zero respectively) stays dark. When I move the wheel up and down again, all the LEDs light up again, as they should.At the moment I'm not worried about this because it's barely audible, but I'm wondering if this is the start of a potential bigger problem. Has anyone here noticed the same behaviour from the wheel and is there anything that can be done to fix it?

title: RE: Here I go again - Organ version (Jon Lord)
post_content: I play it like this:Drawbars 888555555Chorus C1Perc SoftRotary Drive 3.2Reverb Stage Soft 2.8EQ Bass +15.0 Mid Freq 635 Hz Mid Gain -3.0 Treble +9.0Master Gain +10.0Right hand at 4th octave, left hand at second octave with single notes only.Might be that the Original is a little bit less distorted, but only a very little.I hate the later „synth string/bell“ version.The sound in verse 2 that you mention is a synth strings pad, I would say the „A1 The Prophet“ from the nord library plus a warm Chorus 2 effect should get you close.But on NE2 it’s not easy to have them both at once, you would need a second board.Cheers from very sunny Germany

title: Mony Mony
post_content: Just created a Mony Mony patch with a touch sensitive piano layered onto the organ, so that you can get the piano--w-less organ sound by hitting hard, or get the mostly-organ sound by hitting lightly.  The "prepared piano" sound for the break is in the lower split.Note that the B panel is set to Global Midi Channel 3, so that I can use a separate controller to play what is on the B panel only, but that isn't necessary for this patch to work, since all the layers are present regardless.This is my first upload to share with the community and I hope it can help someone!

post_content: I do not on this patch, but that will be a good option if the organ isn't cutting through enough on the choruses. Thanks for asking this question!

title: Won't Get Fooled Again The Who
post_content: Hello, someone knows what sounds can be used to get the keyboard playing the theme of The Who: Won't Get Fooled Again in format NS3 (nord stage 3) ????In the forum there are nord stage 2 files but they are not compatible with the nord stage 3Thank you

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again The Who
post_content: There's a great video on YouTube about Pete Townsend's use of a Lowrey organ through various electronics atthat might give you some ideas.  I haven't worked on this one but I would find a good organ wave (#8?) or sample, set the LFO to pulse at the tempo needed (rather than manually play it), and morph the WAH effect to the control pedal. The WAH will introduce a lot midrange to the sound, so I would EQ the synth to take some of that back out. Take careUPDATE: Bit the bullet this morning and followed the steps above programming this using the OSC1 Wave 8 "Wave Organ #1".  I learned just enough for the demo mp3, hope you like it. Everyone is welcome to take a stab at improving it and posting it on this thread. Take care.WhoWntGetFldAgnW.mp3WhoWntGetFldAgnW.ns3fProgram - The Who - "Won't Get Followed Again"(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1208 times

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again The Who
post_content: Sounds cool - please let me know your synth settings and which specific organ - that would be amazing

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again The Who
post_content: jweisgal wrote:Sounds cool - please let me know your synth settings and which specific organ - that would be amazingThanks - the program is posted above with the MP3 example. For the Slot A synth I used Wave 8 ("Wave Organ #1") and for the Slot B synth I used a triangle wave to fatten up the sound a little. For both synths the LFOs are set with the square wave and synced to the clock, the control pedal covers the Wah effect, and EQ is used to pull out some of the midrange. Try it out with your keyboard set up across the range of the control pedal and adjust the midrange EQ as needed to make sure there isn't a frequency range coming through too strong compared to the rest. Some add a phase shifter to their programs for additional effect - I might try that too. Take care.

title: Snarling Pig sound
post_content: Hello, I have been trying to re-create Jordan Rudess' Snarling Pig sound but haven't been remotely close yet.. Any ideas? For reference, that's the sound here:

title: RE: Snarling Pig sound
post_content: It sounds like aFormant Filterto me (for which you need more than two Band Pass filters to emulate vowel sounds). You might get something close by using a saw tooth oscillation in Sync mode with a Band Pass filter with a high Resonance value and modulate its Frequency. You could add a low LFO modulation to the Frequency to add some more movement.

title: RE: Snarling Pig sound
post_content: You should be able to get close with a narrow pulse wave set up as a sync oscillator with a little resonance.  Copy the sound to a second panel and detune them.-dj

title: Piano in Journey’s “Faithfully”
post_content: For those of you playing Faithfully, which piano/ and effects are you using on your Nord Stage 3?  TIA

title: RE: Piano in Journey’s “Faithfully”
post_content: I don’t play that ballad so much lately, but its tone is decidedly bright and had a lot of its midrange cut in the studio version, so as to not compete with the vocalist, and eventually the lead guitar later in the song.  I don’t hear a lot of FX applied, aside from the 80s-era echo applied to nearly everything from that time.The tone of the piano, and even the playing style, owes a LOT to Elton John’s original version of Rocket Man.  Whatever works for one will work for the other.

title: RE: Piano in Journey’s “Faithfully”
post_content: I use White Grand layered with Digi Grand 1. Both with subtle chorus, a bit of delay (different rates), and some reverb. I use this for all my piano needs, including this song.

title: RE: Piano in Journey’s “Faithfully”

OffKbd Touch 2EQBass + 4.0Mid Freq 7.5 kHz, + 7.1Treble + 11.2Eff 2 Chorus 1, Deep, 0.7HzDelay 1, 2.8Rev Stage Soft, 5.0Gain 10.0There are PAs that sound better without the Chorus or setting the piano to Mono, I notice that during soundcheck. An interview of Jonathan Cain where he talked about his piano sound made me set it up this way.Hope it gives you some ideas.Cheers from Germany

title: RE: Request: VH When it's Love
post_content: Hi, such an awesome patch! Thank you!I can't seem to be able to turn off completely the click. I played with Modulation/Mod Env but hear no change. Any help is gratefully appreciated. Thanks.Cheers,GhislainStage 3 76Komplete Kontrol S61 v.2DX7 (1985)Arturia MiniLab 25

title: RE: Request: VH When it's Love
post_content: gdeslongmusic wrote:Hi, such an awesome patch! Thank you!I can't seem to be able to turn off completely the click. I played with Modulation/Mod Env but hear no change. Any help is gratefully appreciated. Thanks.Cheers,GhislainYou're welcome! I played it this morning and I think what you might be hearing is the delay effect as the initial attack of the strings is being repeated. You can take that out completely by selecting the panel with the synth click, hold down the Morph Assign button for the Mod Wheel while turning the Delay Dry Wet knob to zero, and then saving the program. By doing this, the Mod Wheel will remove both the click and the delay effect. Good luck to you.

title: RE: Abba - Gimme Gimme Gimme
post_content: In order to get the bass synth, strings, and high "flute" sound in one program, I took the approach of using a Stage 3 string sample and adding a high triangle wave with OSC 2 (balancing the two with OSC CTRL), leaving the other for the bass synth. The high triangle would sound closer to the original using one panel for just that (perhaps using the 4MB sample from the post above) with appropriate LFO/Ring Mod effect, and using the other panel for the strings with a longer release, but the bass synth would have to be covered by another program or keyboard. The second program below is an option without the bass, with Piano/Strings on left and high Synth/Strings on the right. Hopefully these programs can get you started whatever direction you choose to take. Take care.Note:Synth bass updated in Dec 2022.Abba Gimme x 3 W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Gimme Gimme Gimme" by Abba - Bass and High Synth/Strings(592 Bytes) Downloaded 477 timesStage 3 - Abba Gimme Gimme Gimme - Bass and Synth.mp3Abba Gimme x 3bW.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Gimme Gimme Gimme" by Abba - Piano and High Synth/Strings(592 Bytes) Downloaded 625 timesStage 3 - Abba Gimme Gimme Gimme - Piano Strings.mp3Update Jan 8, 2021: Trying to take my mind off the recent events here in the U.S. I spent a little time putting together a better program capable of covering the whole song and another making use of the sample provided by Funk76 in the Stage 2 post. To use this some manual changes are needed throughout the song. In the MP3 for the first program, the White Grand and strings start out the intro, I then manually select MONO mode for the Panel A synth and use the Mod Wheel ("MW") to turn up the synth "flute" on OSC2 and back out the piano, and then turn off MONO mode and back off the MW to get back to the piano/strings.  A B3 is set up if you'd like more emphasis in the middle section. NOTE: You can adjust the MW morph on OSC2 to blend in more strings if you want it to sound like the MP3 for "Abba Gimme x 3 W.ns3f" above.Note:Synth bass updated and chorus on MW morphed to "flute"/strings in Dec 2022.ABBA GmeGmeGme W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Gimme Gimme Gimme" by ABBA - Bass Synth, Piano, B3 and High Synth/Strings(592 Bytes) Downloaded 419 timesStage 3 - ABBA Gimme Gimme Gimme no sample.mp3For the second program, I loaded the sample provided by Funk76 in place of the Panel B bass synth and kept the strings in Panel A but without OSC2.  In the MP3 for the second program, the White Grand and strings start out the intro, the MW is then used to turn up the Sample and back out the piano, and then the MW is backed off to return to the piano/strings combo and I added the B3.  For both programs the control pedal is set up to change the level of the B3 and Panel A Synth. Don't forget to load the sample below if you choose to go that route. Take care.ABBA GmeGmeGmesW.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Gimme Gimme Gimme" by ABBA - Piano, B3, Strings, and using Sample provided by Funk76(592 Bytes) Downloaded 663 timesStage 3 - ABBA Gimme Gimme Gimme with sample.mp3

post_content: Also, am I right in assuming you can layer two different sounds in the synth module ie a sample from the keyboard and an oscillator from the synth, effectively layering two parts in the synth module ?

title: RE: Abba - Gimme Gimme Gimme
post_content: timkeys wrote:ThanksThat sounds great  How do I access the bass part to make it louder ?Simply press the Panel B button to get to the bass synth.timkeys wrote:Also, am I right in assuming you can layer two different sounds in the synth module ie a sample from the keyboard and an oscillator from the synth, effectively layering two parts in the synth module ?Yes, but a limitation is that the attack, decay, release, and other synth settings affect both OSC1 and OSC2, so the settings have to be chosen that work well for both. It's a little different than layering two completed sounds, like layering the Panel A synth over the Panel B synth that can have completely different characteristics and effects applied.  Though the choice of OSC2 sources is different than OSC1, OSC2 adds a great deal of flexibility to the synth including the capability to affect the waveform of OSC1. My link below will take you to a lot of programs I've put together and it also has a link to Forum member "My Keys To Music" who has quite a few videos on Stage 3 programming that may be of help to you. Take care.LINK->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: You're the Voice - John Farnham
post_content: Hi,I would try the DigiGrand 2 with bright EQ of the piano section and probably some additional brightness from the EQ of the effects section, eventually layer it with the Bright or Silver Grand and play with the EQ for the grand as well

title: RE: You're the Voice - John Farnham
post_content: Schorsch wrote:Hi,I would try the DigiGrand 2 with bright EQ of the piano section and probably some additional brightness from the EQ of the effects section, eventually layer it with the Bright or Silver Grand and play with the EQ for the grand as wellThanks, i tried that. When played at max velocity it is getting better.It would be great if I could turn of velocity or only play between 80% en 100% velocity....This seems not possible.I tried the Korg M1 sample in the sampler section and that is single velocity and sounds bad in a good way, seems to nail the sound much better.add some reverb, slap-echo and slight compression --> voila

title: RE: You're the Voice - John Farnham
post_content: Did you set KB Touch to 3? That should help as well

title: RE: You're the Voice - John Farnham
post_content: I play it with the sounds and settings as follows:Piano is the Bright Grand which I think have loaded in XL, and I have split the keybed to play the synth, file is A1 The Prophet, as well on my nord.EQ:Bass 0.0 dBFreq 668 HzGain - 3.0 dBTreble + 15.0 dBKeyboard touch is set to zero, I‘m hammering the piano to get it as brilliant as possible.Reverb Dry/wet 5.7Eff 2 to synth only: 1.6 HzSynth:Attack 0.5 msRelease 545 msSplit point as visible, I play the synth on the keys below the drawbars and the piano below „Effects“.The bagpipe comes from my korg X50.Cheers from GermanyEdit: I should have added the octave shift infos:Synth is set to +1 (lower part)Piano is set to -1 (upper part)

title: RE: You're the Voice - John Farnham
post_content: Turning on the compressor will help as well.  Some grand piano is used in the live version, but most of the time the piano is buried in the mix.  Even in the recorded version, the piano is mixed down pretty far.Note the Yamaha KX-5 the keyboard player is wearing, I had one of those for years--dj

title: A small personal collection...
post_content: In the spirit of contribution, here are some of my favourite programs that I've created since purchasing my Stage 3:I usually spend a lot of time trying to recreate the original sound from the original recordings when performing covers. Here is my attempt at some:Mad World.mp3Clocks.mp3AnyColorYouLike.mp3I also make lo-fi beats as a hobby so I have a lot of lofi chill pianos and rhodes:Chilled Piano.mp3Chilled Rhodes 3.mp3Chilled Rhodes 4.mp3Chilled Rhodes 5.mp3Chilled Rhodes 6.mp3Chilled Wurl.mp3A simple synth with legato which I made to replicate the guitar at the beginning of Bad Company's Ready for Love, which seems to fit into every song I've used it in so far.Ready 4 Love.mp3I have more but the upload limit per post is 20 attachments. Hopefully this will motivate you to contribute your creations here! Cheers:)

title: RE: A small personal collection...
post_content: thank you - especially for the wonderful Mad World-Sound.I have a NE 5, so I can't use your stage-files: Could you help me to reconstruct the sound on my Nord electro 5:Which Piano sample do you use, which equalizer settings, which keyboard attack, which effect settings and especially the exact reverb setting

title: RE: A small personal collection...
post_content: Sure! On the Stage 3 i use Mellow Upright piano with Keyboard touch at 3, both string resonance and long release enabled and the soft eq for the piano section which you can imitate by cutting some high frequencies on the eq. I also use the compressor at 2 oclock and Stage Reverb at 12 oclock. I guess what makes it more like the original is the compressor which you can use from a DAW! hope this helps

title: Hooters - Satellite
post_content: Hi everybody,does anybody have a patch or hints for the song "Satellite" from the Hooters?

title: RE: Hooters - Satellite
post_content: Satellite.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 136 timesOk live versions on YT shows Rob playing this tune with one hand on the keyboard...or with a guitar on his neck and a melodica in his hands.However, there are several tracks on the recording and being born with two hands > I would approach this tune with a spilt set up.Lower - Piano Stack with Farfisa bed underneath to fill chording if you desire.Mid / High - Synth  > if you are doing the intro reverse fade stuff...roll up the Mod Env to 12:00 and ride the Mod Wheel for EchoHigh - Melodia on CV Pedal bring in and out thru the flow of the tuneI know it's not perfect...but add a few guitars sawing away and you will be closer to the recording than the live versions I am seeing.Tweak to taste!

title: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: Anyone have an authentic sounding pad/bell split for Foreigner - I Want To Know What Love Is

title: RE: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: I'm also interested in a patch for the Stage 3 for the song "I Want to Know What Love Is".Has anyone already created one?Thanks a lot for your answers.[/quote]

title: RE: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: Perhaps try this: After listening to the part, I stepped through the synth presets to 1:24 Bell Pad, set Attack at zero for Mod Env and Amp, mixed Osc 1 and 2 equally, and set the vibrato on longest delay (you can morph to aftertouch if you'd prefer). It will get you fairly close. Adding delay effect and reverb will help finish it up. Good luck to you.

title: RE: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: Want 2 No What.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 179 timesI am not one to call my programming "authentic"...but if my band were to add this song, I would show up at the first rehearsal with this patch and tweak filter / envelopes / panel mixes on the fly and resave it.give it a shot...Mod Wheel swells the Ah Pad

title: RE: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: Hi everybody,With the hints from WanitBBBad (using a Bell Pad 1:24) I put together a patch. Thanks to WanitBBBad for the helpful tips.

title: RE: I Want To Know What Love Is - Foreigner
post_content: Here another patch compiled with the hints of WanitBBBad (using a Bell Pad 1:24); in slot B I added 1:02 Soft pad 2 (morphed with control pedal) and EP Nefertiti  and in Slot A you find the Bell pad and Piano Ballad EP 1. Surely it's not the original sound for the song, but it works for me and many other rock ballads of the 80ties.

title: Looking for Pink Floyd/Waters sound (not the ones you think)
post_content: Hi, I'm looking for a way to reproduce the pitchless synth "shimmer" sound heard on Pink Floyd or Roger Waters's "The Thin Ice", from "The Wall". You can hear it herehttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fEgPxB8yLXQ- right at the beginning (0:06), the sound that accompanies the piano chords.I understand it must be noise with an LFO on the filter envelope, and any synth will be able to make it, but I've never been able to understand the mechanism correctly. If anyone can explain to me how this kind of sweep is made, thank you very much. Note: This was originally made on a Prophet-5 so directions for it are welcome too)

title: RE: Looking for Pink Floyd/Waters sound (not the ones you think)
post_content: It sounds like a synth with a very narrow bandpass filter at high resonance. Filter envelope with fast attack, slow decay.The video you linked isn't quite the original sound, but that's the gist of both of them. I'd probably use a sawtooth wave configuration with a second sawtooth mixed in a fifth (7 semitones) above the fundamental to get started.

title: RE: Looking for Pink Floyd/Waters sound (not the ones you think)

title: Tom Misch "Crazy Dream"
post_content: A request from stefmazurier - I put this together for the keyboard part in Crazy DreamI haven't had the opportunity to program a synth sound that "bends up" until now  - the approach includes:a) setting the MOD ENV ATTACK about 4 (it adjusts how quickly you want the sound to glide up to the final note).b) setting the MOD ENV DECAY all the way up to hold the final note (otherwise it will glide back down to the beginning note or pitch)b) setting OSC2 for the beginning note (set at 8 to glide up 4 semitones)c) setting the Modulation MOD ENV to about 7 - it is adjusted as needed to reach the final note (must compare against another sound to make sure it's in tune).The chords are played left of the split and the solo synth is right of the split.  The Control Pedal is set to control the volume of the solo synth and the Mod Wheel set to increase the FREQ is a little more brightness is desired for both.  Take careMP3 of Program TM Crazy Dream W.mp3TM Crazy Dream W.ns3fProgram for Tom Misch "Crazy Dream" with polyphonic voices split left, mono voice split right, with Mod Wheel covering filter FREQ, and Control Pedal covering volume for mono synth(574 Bytes) Downloaded 579 timesPrograms, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

post_content: Sry, do you have maybe nsmp format for that song, i want to performe with my band. Im using nord electro 6

title: RE: Tom Misch "Crazy Dream"
post_content: SajaPro wrote:Sry, do you have maybe nsmp format for that song, i want to performe with my band. Im using nord electro 6Hello, below is a NSMP file made by sampling each of the notes from my program. As the file is very big, I've also attached the two WAV files I used for Synth A and Synth B so you can make your own NSMP if you want it smaller. My file is large because I used samples for all notes across 2 octaves on the lower section and only skipped every other note on the upper section.  With sounds that have have a timed aspect to them, like the slide pitch change for Synth A,  you pretty much want each note to have the same characteristic, so that means more actual samples used, whereas for sounds like the one used for Synth B, you can skip more notes with interpolation working pretty well. Other ways to make the NSMP file smaller is only use the samples for the notes you will actually play in the song and let the rest be interpolated, and you can cut the file size in half by converting it to a mono (rather than stereo) file.  I hope this helps. Take care.

title: RE: need info loading programs
post_content: dennisb wrote:Hello all. I need to transfer my programs/presets from my Nord Stage 3 to a different Stage 3 for a travel gig. I see that transferring all the sounds/samples takes quite a bit of time. My Nord contains the original factory samples but I have made different patches/presets I need for the gig. Is there a way to just load in the info for my patches quickly without loading all the sounds/samples?thanks in advance.Yes, if the other Stage 3 also has the original factory samples (pianos and synth samples) you have the choice of loading your programs manually wherever you want them using the Organize feature in Nord Sound Manager, or loading a bundle (or full backup) which won't take much time if the samples are already on the Stage 3. I would take the route of preparing a bundle or full backup file just in case you find that the other Stage 3 is not 100% original.  Good luck

title: downloading Rhodes sound
post_content: I wonder if someone could help me with what is probably quite simple but is causing me major frustration. There's an electric piano sound called EP5 MK1 Bright Tines that in the sound demo on the website sounds amazing (found under Sound Libraries/electric pianos).I would love to get this sound onto my Stage 3. I downloaded the sample and dragged it into the piano library (running Mac). When it's in there it says there are numerous sounds using that program, and lists them. These are sounds I've already had in the keyboard (with different names) and none sounds like the sample on the website. Is there something I can do to get the sound I'm looking for?

title: RE: downloading Rhodes sound
post_content: What you downloaded is the basic instrument sound. It will usually not sound like the sound demo which comes from a tweaked preset: with FX, drive, EQ and reverb added, maybe compressed a bit, too. As you have a Stage 3, you have a full set of possibilities at hand to get that basic sound tweaked the way you want it.That's what it is all about with Nord sounds: You have a lot of knobs and buttons at hand and will need to learn to use them. It took me more than a few months, but I enjoy that game. Maybe, you start with 3 knobs: Timbre (piano section), Drive (amp sim) and Reverb.

title: RE: downloading Rhodes sound
post_content: That Rhodes is already part of the Factory Programs & Samples of the NS. So you had no need to add it, if your NS3 is new or you had made a restore of the Factory Backup.I suggest you start with a clean Program (make a Program Init as "Piano") and select that sample in the piano section, then as Fziegler suggested start trying to adjust it to your likes using (in this order) the Piano section EQ options (Soft, Mid, Bright, Dyno 1/2), Reverb, Drive and its Eq and finally other effects (Auto Pan or Tremolo, Chorus, Phaser).Another option is to start from one of the Factory Programs using that sample and modify it, you may also download and try the NS3 dedicated Program Library made by Ondre Jhttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... nature-epsand use those as a reference or starting point.

post_content: Hello, and welcome to the Forum! Can you post the program you've put together so far?

title: RE: recreating a sound
post_content: You haven’t posted your settings…?The basic character of that sound is that it is a „sync“ sound — where one oscillator‘s waveform is retriggered by another. That‘s what gives it the hollow, twangy character.

title: RE: recreating a sound
post_content: A hard synced sound with lot of reverb and some delay. Check this video about creating hard synced sounds, you might find it usefull. He doesn't use a stage ofcourse, but once you understand what is going on maybe you can apply it on your instrument, the principles are the same. Good luck!

title: Moog One sound?
post_content: Matt Johnson (Jamiroquai) published a lot of videos during corona times. I learned one or another thing from that and enjoyed his playing. Thereby, I stumbled over a Moog One sound type I've been searching for for quite a while - here it is:It sounds like something between a vibraphone, an EP and a toy piano to me, reminding me of a cheap electrical organ, too. I'd want to play it instead of a simple B3 sound. Unfortunately, I totally lack experience in 'classical' synth sounds. Does anyone get a starting point in mind to replicated that genre of sound (doesn't need to be exactly this)? I have no clue. May be a sample or a synth preset for NS3.Thanks in advance!

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: Ah, nice sound... it seems a mixture of a clang (could be emulated with the FM oscillator perhaps) and a filtered pad?

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: There are two elements.One is the bell attack, which requires audio-frequency pitch modulation. As Mr_-G- writes, your best bet for approximating this is using the FM oscillator, because the regular LFO doesn't go that far up.Then there's a detuned pad with some noise and a filter with hard attack and no sustain, just piano-like decay. And a fast LFO modulating the filter, giving it that rough edge.Hard to tell from a fast listen on laptop speakers, but it's possible it's the same LFO applied to the pad's oscillator pitches giving them that detuned effect.This is the kind of stuff the Memorymoog is exceptionally good for, except that's not as precise-sounding and more "woah", like all things Memorymoog.

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: I'm not sure you'll get very close with a Stage 3, as (seems to me like) the original program involves sloppy tuning as a defining character. Sure you can approximate it to some extent, but I don't think you'll get very close.

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: My sound shaping skills are not much developed. The synth on my NS3 has only been used to add some spice to my piano and organ sounds so far. For example, I haven't used the FM presets yet. So this is definitely a challenge to me. I'll consider any hint you've all been giving.I already imagined that I might need to do without that detuning effect. As I'm going to play in a big band, it might do the trick anyway. But you're right: What I'd wish to achieve is a slightly smearing 70ies analog sound, and this might be far away.

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: Actually you might get close to the higher part, if you use 2 saw waves, 1 octave apart but the higher one slightly flat. Drifting and sloppy tuning might not be necessary as I originally thought.But yes. Go ahead and experiment. There are not that many parameters to change in the synth engine after all.

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: Elias wrote:There are not that many parameters to change in the synth engine after all.You made me laugh. True, after 2 years of owning a NS3 beast, I also learned that this is a limited implementation of a VA synth. But I still need to recall the function and meaning of one or another knob. Thankfully, I'm familiar with half of what I should.

title: RE: Moog One sound?
post_content: Sloppy tuning: try using effect vibe with very low rate. Or morphing by AT an analog delay , very short time , all wet no feedback using the keys like a violin vibrato

title: RE: Create sound for Cher song "All or Nothing"
post_content: You would need to use delay on the NS3, as the arpeggiator does not have a "chord" mode like the NW2, and there is more than one note in there.  There is also noise mixed in the sound, so it would require both panels to reproduce.-dj

title: RE: Create sound for Cher song "All or Nothing"
post_content: I would try a square LFO, applied to the filter, and send whatever sample/synth it is into a "small" or a "twin" amp, with lots of drive, highs eq'd out, bass out a bit, and compression, some reverb.Maybe an electric guitar sample as source, though with enough drive, it's probably almost irrelevant what the actual sample is.Instead of the square LFO, the tremolo effect might work, as well.

title: Steely Dan "Peg" Program and Samples
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well.  Watching a great video on the making of the album "Aja", I came across a section where some (not all) of Michael McDonald's vocals were isolated for "Peg". Starting with those vocals, I blended in some backing vocals from the free demo of the chorus at Karaoke Version (https://www.karaoke-version.com) to complete the ending phrases. The samples provided in NSMP format:"Steely Dan - Peg W.nsmp" has the backing vocals on the low E1, F1, and F#1 keys and a modified sax to emulate the Lyricon. The vocals are down in the mix in case you want to use them to supplement your band's vocals."SD Peg Lyricon.nsmp" has just the Lyricon without the backing vocals if you would prefer to use that and save some sample space. For both samples, the notes for the Lyricon are set up with an octave shift down at Bb1 so that the higher intro notes on the Clavinet have the correct accompanying Lyricon notes (listen for it on the intro)."Clavinet S.nsmp" is a very small (198K) Clavinet sample made just for this song (you can try other Clavinet samples as well); it's manually turned off during the verses and chorus.The program has a Rhodes with Phase Shifter and Clavinet with Flanger (effect amount morphed to the Mod Wheel) that are panned slightly left-right and can be backed off with the Control Pedal to get a good balance with the Lyricon/vocals.  To make the attached MP3, I went to Karaoke Version and made a backing track for $2.99 U.S. with the bass, drums, and guitar; I'm really impressed with the quality of what's available at the site.  For those of you who transpose your keyboard down a half step, I've attached pitch-corrected samples that will split correctly with the keyboard transposed -1.  I hope some of you get some use out of these. Take care.Steely Dan Peg W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 318 timesSteely Dan - Peg W.nsmp(1.77 MiB) Downloaded 309 timesSD Peg Lyricon W.nsmp(896.75 KiB) Downloaded 265 timesClavinet S.nsmp(197.26 KiB) Downloaded 287 timesUPDATEDFeb. 1, 2022 - Pitch-Corrected to transpose correctly with keyboard down a semitone:Steely Dan - Peg W -1.nsmp(1.95 MiB) Downloaded 264 timesSD Peg Lyricon -1 W.nsmp(882.99 KiB) Downloaded 251 timesSteely Dan - Peg W DEMO.mp3

title: RE: Steely Dan "Peg" Program and Samples
post_content: SteveM wrote:I can't get the Steely Dan Peg program to sound correct.  I can't find the vocals in the mix and the splits aren't volume balanced.  I know how to adjust the volume of both panels and save, but it just doesn't sound right.  Also the Clavinet S(1) sample, I can't use the ReLink to use it, I think because it isn't saved as a Clav or Piano or other recognized category.  I tried to rename the category but it wouldn't accept it.  Can you help?  I appreciate the great programs and samples.  I know they take a lot of work.Sorry you're having trouble with setting this up. Using Nord Sound Manager, you would load "Steely Dan - Peg W.nsmp" and "Clavinet S.nsmp" first, and then load the program "Steely Dan Peg W.ns3f".  In that order the program would find the two samples needed for the program and have the backing vocals on the low E1, F1, and F#1 keys.  I play the chords to the song with my right hand while I play the intro clavinet/Lyricon with my left.  The clavinet sample is only used for the intro and just before the guitar solo, and manually turned off during the verses and chorus. I use a control pedal for some of the levels; if you don't have one you would need to disable the morphs for that. With the samples already loaded, try reloading the program and see if everything sets up as described.  Let me know how it turns out - good luck!

title: Laser pew sounds like on disco songs
post_content: Looking for samples or tutorial to create "pew" laser like sounds from video games but really more like what you hear on old disco songs

title: RE: Laser pew sounds like on disco songs
post_content: You can do this by cranking full up the Resonance of the LPF filter until self-oscillation, then lower the Frequency of the filter and control the filter Frequency with the MOD ENV (suggest 0 attack and some non-zero decay) so that opens and closes the filer matches the rate of decay in the frequency you want. The interesting aspect of this is that the filter becomes a sine oscillator.

title: RE: cover Muse
post_content: Hi there @Pastakoussok. Your English writing is good (so don't worry), but I will try to use simple English.These songs are full of unique sounds. This can be hard to do before meeting up and planning the band arrangement, because many sounds could be done with a guitar or vocals instead of your Stage 3. When you know for example: "I want to play a growling lead here," or "Here I need to play a calm pad", then you can try to make that specific sound.Most of these songs have not been discussed here before, but there are a couple of threads discussingBliss, which you can find by searching "Bliss Muse". If you find a Stage 2 program, load it up to our beloved file viewer app (link below in my signature), and copy it on your Stage 3. (Love and respect to the creators!)Remember: you will use this instrument to create art, not to just copy a certain sound. If you make programs and samples yourself, they might become much better.

title: Expressive Synth - Love Thing (Joe Satriani)
post_content: Here is a program I use for Joe Satriani's "Love Thing".(ExpressiveSynth.ns3f)You can watch my YouTube video of it here:It morphs A TOUCH and CTRLPED to wah effects (using OSC CTRL) on the Screamy Lead and works fairly well as an alternative for "lead guitar."I would much rather have used WannitBBBad's DistortedGuitr2W program from here:nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 17012.htmlbut the upper end on the distored lead guitar seems to "give out" and I also couldn't figure out how to combine 3 synth sounds (without dubbing...and I want to play it in realtime). I would need 3 synth engines for adding a bass to the 2 "Les Paul Neck-mic" sounds already being used in Panel A and B. Anyone know how?Anyway, maybe someone else can find use for this program, too. Enjoy!

title: RE: Expressive Synth - Love Thing (Joe Satriani)
post_content: bluetrain wrote:...I would have much rather used WannitBBBad's DistortedGuitr2W program from here:nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 17012.htmlbut the upper end on the distored lead guitar seems to "give out" and I also couldn't figure out how to combine 3 synth sounds (without dubbing...and I want to play it in realtime). I would need 3 synth engines for adding a bass to the 2 "Les Paul Neck-mic" sounds already being used in Panel A and B. Anyone know how?Anyway, maybe someone else can find use for this program, too. Enjoy!Hello, and welcome to the Forum! Very nice video and program, I like the morphing you did on OSC2 for the effect as well. My program used 2 guitars but for different parts, so the panel set aside for the left split could be assigned to the bass.  In case you want to try it, here's your program with the right distorted guitar added. I brightened it up a little with Freq and EQ, added the Wah effect on the control pedal, set AfterTouch for the high harmonic, and then put in the settings you wanted of having it in Mono with AMP Release set to 588ms. The Mod Wheel will add vibrato - another option would be to swap the high harmonic to be on the MW and Vibrato on AfterTouch (just my preference not to put them together on one control). After loading you'll need to reassign your piano to the program as I didn't have the same one loaded in my Stage 3.  Good luck to you!ExpressiveSynth2.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 130 times

title: RE: Expressive Synth - Love Thing (Joe Satriani)
post_content: A few things to try: a) check the OS to make sure you have the latest version; b) delete the program, download the program again and save it to your Stage 3; c) right after pulling up the Stage 3 program, save the Les Paul synth preset to your synth bank as "LesPaulHarmonicW", turn your synth preset dial to where you saved "LesPaulHarmonicW", and then save your Stage 3 program again.  The problem you're having sounds very odd. The effects and EQ settings are saved with the Stage 3 program, so stepping through the synth presets or simply the OSC types won't bring the EQ/distortion back. With LesPaulHarmonicW pulled up on the synth, I got sounds stepping through all OSC types. If you want to build the program from scratch, Forum member Florence has a Stage 2 and 3 program viewer atnord-stage-forum-f3/ns3-program-viewer-t19939.htmlUsing either the online or offline version of the viewer, you can print out all of the settings used and recreate them on your Stage 3.  Good luck to you!

BTW, I am also a software developer (23 years) so I'll be interested in checking out the source code for that app on Github. This is so much cooler than my old D-50!P.S. title: RE: Dave Mackay Bundle - just two of the sounds?
post_content: The bundle is in fact a *.zip file. So you can open it with a zipper like 7zip or the OS file viewer (the latter only after renaming it to *.zip) and go to \Program\Bank O\ and extract the two programs in question. You might need to extract and install some corresponding sample files, though.Extract the programs and samples first and then use the Nord Sound Manager to install them.

title: RE: Supertramp Logical Wurlitzer
post_content: But i think this version sounded better on NS2 in this threadnord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15482.html"User StageChris" made some recreations, here are his settings:Sample: Wurlitzer 2 Amped Lrg. 5.3Volume -4 DBEffekt: Chorus1 Rate 60 Amount 7,5EQ: Drive 0 Bass -3,5 Mid Freq. 1,2 kHz Mid +7,4 Treble +6,0 dbCompressor 2,0Hall: Stage1 4,5Excerpt from other article:"Roger Hodgson normally recorded his Wurlitzer 200A electric piano through a Roland Jazz Chorus amplifier. But when Hodgson was recording the keyboard part for “The Logical Song” on Supertramp’s 1979 album Breakfast in America, he fed the output of his Wurlitzer through a DI and then split the signal to a Boss CE-1 Chorus Ensemble pedal to achieve a semi-modulated effect. The Boss CE-1 first was made in 1976 and was based on the chorus circuit of the Roland JC-120 Jazz Chorus amplifier, making it a natural choice for Hodgson."

title: Hammond B3 - Chorus/Stereo Pan on Left, Leslie on Right
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well.  Periodically I'll see a post where someone would like to have the B3 on one panel not use the same Leslie/Reverb effect as the B3 on the other.  As the Stage 3 is programmed to utilize just one Leslie/Reverb setting (can't have a fast Leslie on Panel A and a slow Leslie on Panel B), I put together an easy work-around that uses the Chorus and Stereo Pan effect in place of the slow Leslie for one panel; the reverb on the B3 can also be set differently than what's used on the panel with the Leslie. For those playing in mono, I would suggest replacing the Stereo Pan effect with a Tremolo effect set lightly and at the same slow rate as the Chorus effect.  I hope this comes in handy for some of you. Take care.B3 NoLeslieLeftW.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 313 timesB3 - Chorus-Stereo Pan and Fast Leslie.mp3

title: RE: Hammond B3 - Chorus/Stereo Pan on Left, Leslie on Right
post_content: Very nice! I haven't experimented much with things like this and I wonder what might be possible in my scenario where I'm using a Ventilator almost exclusively for all of my organ sounds via Output 3. What I've seen is that if I turn the NS3 internal Leslie sim back on, it basically overrides the external sim and puts the organ sound back into Outputs 1 and 2. Not sure if there's a setting somewhere that might allow me to use one panel of organ through Output 3 into Vent, while the other panel is routing through the internal Leslie. Basically giving me the ability to have two Leslies doing different things. I don't believe it's possible. It does seem like I should experiment more with things like the sound posted above. Thanks for sharing!

title: RE: Hammond B3 - Chorus/Stereo Pan on Left, Leslie on Right
post_content: I always see what I can do with the internal sound capability of the Stage 3 before turning to using samples, but another possibility of having two distinctly different B3/Leslie/Reverb setups is throwing a B3 sample into the mix.  Using the B3/Leslie on both panels (panel A reverb used for both), one can also add a third B3 (sample) on panel B using that reverb.  I have quite a few B3 samples posted atnord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/hamm ... 21307.htmlthat have the Leslie incorporated into the sample if you ever want to try it. An example of three of the samples with a slow Leslie is below. Take care everyone.B3 888 888632234 888686868 LS.mp3

title: Request: Titanium Synth
post_content: Hey all.I've been trying to find a good set-up for the Synth in Titanium with David Guetta and Sia on the Stage 3. I am not really landing anything meaningful, especially with the shift from verse synth to the Chorus version. Can anyone of you please help me out?

title: RE: Request: Titanium Synth
post_content: Well... The backbone of synth sounds in EDM is both compressors and expandersside chained to rhythmic parts. So you get beating and ducking effects. If you are using something like Mainstage, and have a bass drum mic on stage, you can do the side chaining there. Otherwise just start basically all the sounds with Super Saw (or unison + detune), and morph the filter and volume as you wish.The sound you ultimately use depends highly on what you are after arrangement-wise.If your guitarist is telling you to replicate these sounds perfectly, politely tell him to "sod off". Just kidding, guitarists are bros.

title: Muse Resistance

title: RE: Muse Resistance
post_content: Hello, and welcome to the Forum!  I just came across this and am surprised it sat unanswered as we have so many helpful folks on the Forum.  Here's something to get you started - left of the split is a pad and right of the split is a mono synth with glide to cover the initial intro.  For the second program, both synths are placed on the left with soft Silver Grand on the right.  If you don't have my specific piano sample, you can designate another that sounds close.  Using the mono synth can be tricky when playing it with chords as I do in the attached demo, as you have to play each chord so that the top note is the last one hit or the mono synth will go to an unintended key.  Frankly, it may not be worth it to you to keep the mono synth for that part as you'll be able to play more freely to cover other parts that go with the piano.  Good luck to you!Muse Resistanc1W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 181 timesMuse Resistanc2W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 187 timesMuse Resistance2W Demo.mp3

title: Electric Light Orchestra - Telephone Line
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well during this odd time. Below are a few programs and samples I put together for "Telephone Line" by ELO. The intro program uses the Control Pedal for the wah effect placed on the synth, the verse program has strings on the left hand so the low piano notes can be easily added, and the chorus program uses the Control Pedal to add in strings an octave higher than the other strings during the manual arpeggio. There's a Rhodes used lightly with effects in all three.  I've also provided two samples, the one used in the program has the full electronic intro on the low keys and the C2 note and above just have the telephone for the middle of the song (1st MP3 example below); the other sample is a little smaller if you don't want the full intro (2nd MP3 example below). I couldn't find a telephone sample that matched the song, so I took another, changed the pitch, tone duration and period between tones to get closer to the original. BTW, the MP3 didn't record well, so there's some line noise in the long intro that won't be in the actual sample.  The WAV file is also attached below if you want to play around with it in the Sample Editor. The versatility of the Stage 3 comes out in this one. Take care.ELO Telephone Line Intro Verse and Chorus Programs.mp3ELO Telephone Line Intro Verse and Chorus Programs - Short.mp3ELO TelefonLin1W.ns3fStage 3 program for ELO "Telephone Line" Intro and Middle(592 Bytes) Downloaded 378 timesELO TelefonLin2W.ns3fStage 3 program for ELO "Telephone Line" Verse(592 Bytes) Downloaded 326 timesELO TelefonLin3W.ns3fStage 3 program for ELO "Telephone Line" Chorus(592 Bytes) Downloaded 332 times70+ Programs - For those new to programming...nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: Classic Rock and other programs - Set 2
post_content: I just purchased a Nord Stage 3 and working quickly to recreate all the patches I had on my Stage 2 before selling it. Some of the classic programs are fairly simple, but I thought some of you might appreciate saving a little time with something to start with and tweak. Note that most of my programs use the control pedal morph even if only to bring instruments in and out of a mix.With some of these programs you may need to relink the piano(s) to what you have in your Stage 3, as one of the first things I did when I got my Stage 3 was replace some pianos with smaller files to add more - I have 48 at this time.All sample locations below 250 are pre-loaded Stage 3 locations that I don't mess with. Even if I delete samples from the stock collection to add space, I keep those sample locations open and load new samples in locations 250 and above. The programs below use all the "stock" samples except for "DX7 Layered W" which uses "DX7 Rhodes" in location 267.I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.Little Feat - All That You Dream. Bill Payne is an amazing player - if you listen closely to the live version of All That You Dream you can hear him playing harmonizing parts during his solo using a Wurlitzer piano and his synthesizer. I still need to tweak this some, but it's a start:AllThatYouDreamW - Little Feat - All That You Dream.mp3AllThatYouDreamW.ns3fProgram - Little Feat - All That You Dream by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 551 timesAmbrosia - Biggest Part Of Me.  The keyboard parts build in this song - Rhodes, Piano, B3, fat analog synth. I added some voices on the wheel just for a little more effect:AmbrosiaBigPartW - Ambrosia - Biggest Part of Me.mp3AmbrosiaBigPartW.ns3fProgram - Ambrosia - Biggest Part Of Me by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 788 timesBruce Springsteen - Dancing In The Dark (UPDATED 1/1/2019)- I hear at least three different synth sounds in this song - this covers the two that I use but I've heard sampled versions that could be tried as well. I chose to put more attack on the right-hand synth as it stands out a little more in performance, but that can be backed off to your taste.BSDancingDark2 W.mp3BSDancingDark2 W.ns3fProgram - Bruce Springsteen - "Dancing in the Dark"(592 Bytes) Downloaded 747 timesBruce Springsteen - Glory Days:BSGloryDays    W - Bruce Springsteen - Glory Days.mp3BSGloryDays    W.ns3fProgram - Bruce Springsteen - Glory Days by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 800 timesEmerson Lake and Palmer - From The Beginning. This uses both Slot A and Slot B for the Synth sound. With the more flexible Synth in the Stage 3, I'll be playing with this more to see if a single synth in Slot A can capture both the low note and the other 2 octaves higher to free up Slot B. UPDATE: obwanz has a nice version that has an added effect on the mod wheel atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15566.htmlELP FromBgning W - Emerson Lake and Palmer - From the Beginning.mp3ELP FromBgning W.ns3fProgram - ELP From The Beginning by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 609 timesThe Eagles - Hotel California - Program 1. Left hand bass, 12 string, a hint of harpsichords added behind the 12 string for slight detuning with chorus, and... a B3:Hotel Calif4niaW - Eagles - Hotel California.mp3Hotel Calif4niaW.ns3fProgram - The Eagles - Hotel California by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1039 timesThe Eagles - Hotel California - Program 2 (added 1/19/2019). This version is set up similar to Program 1 but with Rhodes assigned to the left-hand bass so that a distorted Les Paul can be added to an additional split.HotelCalif4nGtrW.ns3fStage 3 Program - The Eagles - "Hotel California" with 12-string on left and distorted Les Paul guitar on right.(592 Bytes) Downloaded 678 timesThe Eagles - Hotel California - Rock Guitars. If you're looking to drop the 12-string and cover the dual guitars at the end, a version is posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 17012.htmlMy Blues Harp- Use a control pedal - the morph pedal emulates muffling the harmonica a little and when backed off, sets the Freq in the range where the LFO emulates the cupped-hand tremolo effect:HarmAccord     W - WannitBBBad Blues Harp.mp3HarmAccord     W.ns3fProgram - Blues Harp and Accordion by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 836 timesAnalog Sustained Strings- I took another program and just started adding to it and playing around with effects. Most programs like this are just to learn from and tweak to something you're looking for:AnalogSustainedW - WanniBBBad Sustained Strings Effects.mp3AnalogSustainedW.ns3fProgram - Analog Sustained Strings with multiple effects by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 663 timesMy Layerz- This is a program with just simple layers added, starting with a DX7 and then a sampled DX7 "DX7 Rhodes" I added to sample location 267. It doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store new samples in your Nord Stage 3, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load "DX7 Rhodes" into your sample location 280 (267 in mine), then you just need to point Slot A to 280 rather than 267:DX7 Layered    W - WannitBBBad Layerz.mp3DX7 Layered    W.ns3fProgram - Layers by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 850 timesDX7 Rhodes.nsmp390+ programs with MP3 examplesnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlClassic Rock and other programs - Set 1 (9 programs)nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15722.htmlClassic Rock and other programs - Set 3 (11 programs)nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15745.htmlMy Pianos and Program List as of April 2020 can be found at -->post130083.html?hilit=program%20list#p130083

title: David Bowie "Ashes to Ashes"
post_content: I love this Forum - I'm exposed all the time to songs that I haven't heard before, or in this case, one I haven't heard in 30 years or so. Forum member fuztec25 was looking for some assistance on the intro for "Ashes to Ashes" by David Bowie for his Stage 2, so I sent a few suggestions after playing around with it on my Stage 3. I finished the Stage 3 program this morning adding the other parts to the song with the lower split covering a shallow Rhodes that morphs out as the analog strings morph in with the control pedal, and the intro piano and LFO synth are on the upper split.  The analog strings on the left are set up so at the end of the song the user can select Mono to change the strings to a solo synth with glide and with the LFO amount on AfterTouch. Take care.DB Ashes2Ashes W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 206 timesDB Ashes2Ashes LFO Example.mp3YouTube Video:Stage 2 program by fuztec25:nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 22205.html

title: Search for Sound Nord Stage 3 ELP Fanfare for the common man
post_content: Hi there, I'm looking for the sound of ELPs "Fanfare for the common man". Has anybody these sound to share or can anyone program it for me? Thanks a lot in advanceAnton Salatanton-salat@aponet.de

title: RE: Search for Sound Nord Stage 3 ELP Fanfare for the common man
post_content: Those might be around, but I haven't seen them.  The original uses a recorded orchestra for the signature horn part.  Since that's a difficult-to-program sound, you might be better off just sampling the intro, as I've seen done by other bands.

title: RE: Search for Sound Nord Stage 3 ELP Fanfare for the common man
post_content: Hello, and welcome to the Forum! As noted by cphollis, for the orchestra here's an example using "Brass_05 W.nsmp" from my post atpost150547.html#p150547with a lot of reverb added. Adding another sample like "Final Brass Motif" by Ivan Jochner atpost106093.html#p106093can fatten it up a little if you want it to have more of a synth sound to it.  One of the other synths sounds somewhat like a harmonica - try Bluesharp stock sample 192 for that.  Others here might be able to help with suggestions; I'll look around when I have a little more time as well.  Good luck to you!Brass_05 W - Fanfare.mp3Brass_05 W with Final Brass added - Fanfare.mp3

title: RE: Search for Sound Nord Stage 3 ELP Fanfare for the common man
post_content: Holy cr*p, WannitBBBad, I hadn't heard that one.  What a great sound!  Thanks.

title: RE: Search for Sound Nord Stage 3 ELP Fanfare for the common man
post_content: cphollis wrote:Holy cr*p, WannitBBBad, I hadn't heard that one.  What a great sound!  Thanks.You're welcome!  Brass_05 is a mix of a Korg brass preset and the Mellotron Trumpets Legato (stock sample 60). As reverb is pretty forgiving, I also got pretty close to the same sound for this song using just Trumpets Legato with some EQ and OSC2 set on 7 MixSaw to provide more options on the attack and overall sound. Take care.

title: Looking for Jackson Browne - The Load-Out / Stay
post_content: Any pointers as to recreating the synth used during the solo of "The Load-Out?" Can't imagine it's too difficult to recreate, but I'm just getting acquainted with my first Nord (and first synth, really -- always just been a piano man) and man do I have a lot of learning to do! Solo starts around the 1:45 mark of The Load Out (2018 Remaster).

title: RE: Looking for Jackson Browne - The Load-Out / Stay
post_content: That's a fairly iconic Minimoog or similar pulse lead. I am pretty sure that if you scroll through the synth presets in the NS3 synth section, go to the leads and you'll find one that's pretty close. This sound, or very close to it, has been a preset in many keyboards for decades. Steve Winwood's "Finer Things" uses a very similar lead sound. I don't have a NS3 set up at the moment, though happy to look and find a sound one day when I am using it.

title: RE: Looking for Jackson Browne - The Load-Out / Stay
post_content: I honestly assumed it would be as simple as finding something that was pre-loaded in the synth engine. The thing is ridiculously chalk full of most things you could need in simple performance formats - just real overwhelming when you first turn the sucker on! Know very little about the world of synth, but with every bit of info I absorb, my mind gets blown a little more by how intuitive & comprehensive the engines are on this machine!!!

title: Unable to Download Sounds to Nord Stage 3
post_content: Hello,I am trying to download the sounds to my Nord Stage 3 but am unable to. I have the most recent sound manager and software but for some reason, the sound files (attached in the screenshot) are greyed out. I also have plenty of space on my Nord. Any ideas? Thank you

title: RE: Unable to Download Sounds to Nord Stage 3
post_content: Those are not "Synth presets"The npno is a piano sample and the ns3f is a program. You are trying to upload those to the wrong memory locations.

title: RE: Unable to Download Sounds to Nord Stage 3
post_content: You'll need to make sure you have enough Piano memory too. For just a few files, I usually put the Nord Stage Manager in "Organize" mode, select the tab, then just drag-n-drop the file where I want it.

title: RE: Unable to Download Sounds to Nord Stage 3
post_content: Thank you! I am new to this but that makes more sense now. I am now receiving this error that part of the program is not found however I am not sure I know what that means.

title: RE: Unable to Download Sounds to Nord Stage 3
post_content: I believe you need to load the Marimba npno file and possibly a DX7 based upon the program name. At this link to the Stage 3 program viewer, you can upload your program file and see what npno files it needs.nord-stage-forum-f3/ns3-program-viewer-t19939.html

post_content: Thank you!
