title: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Some of the most iconic synth riffs were created by a guitarist, Pete Townshend.Does anyone have a decent NS3 patch for the intro of Who Are You?   I don’t need an arpeggiator or sequencer.  I can play the notes. I’m having difficulty approximating the sound. I know Townsend sent a guitar signal through an early synth, but I would have thought that an NS3 could get reasonably close.Great tune, with lovely piano later on as a bonus for us keyboardists.Thanks.

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Not a lot of time today so looked at it quickly. Try this: Bring up synth program 1:49 Simple Machine, and make the following adjustments: MOD ENV Attack 3, Decay 4, Release 2; AMP ENV Release 2.5; FILTER Drive 3, Freq 3, Mod Env 5. Take care

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Thank you WannitBBBad!  I'll try that tonight.Your patches for Won't Get Fooled, and Baba O are brilliant, by the way.  It is really quite amazing that a guitarist (Townshend) came up with all of these signature synth riffs, that are so recognizable to anyone.Eminence Front is yet another one!

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Davywavy wrote:... It is really quite amazing that a guitarist (Townshend) came up with all of these signature synth riffs, that are so recognizable to anyone.Eminence Front is yet another one!I'm reading a book on him now - genius creativity behind so many unique sounds and great songs. I'd appreciate you following up with the program you've created - maybe a MP3 example too? Take care.

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: WannitBBBad, I took your starting point (described above) and added some auto-wah, and tweaked some knobs to get the right speed and depth of the autowah. The original riff is so quick the notes don’t have much time to wah, but it’s there.  It definitely needed that quack quack effect.Who knows, Townsend may have used a wah pedal.I think I’m close.  If I ever figure out how to post a program or mp3, I’ll do it.

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Is there a similar program( Simple Machine) on NS2, WannitBBBad?

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: apresaca wrote:Is there a similar program( Simple Machine) on NS2, WannitBBBad?There might be something similar, however I don't have my Stage 2 any longer to listen to the preset synth programs.  "Simple Machine" uses a sawtooth wave (what's typically used for an analog brass sound) and has the Modulation Mod Env applied to an OSC2 setting of the shape and Unison set on 1. I am not sure if you'll get the same effect utilizing Mod Env on the Stage 2. The synth in the song changes in different ways so what may work for the beginning may need to be changed for other parts - I'll be interested to hear what Davywavy comes up with using the Autowah effect.  As the Stage 2 doesn't have the synth Drive settings 1-3, you could use the Drive on the EQ that can be morphed to the control pedal or mod wheel for sound flexibility. Take care.

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: WannitBBBad has done the heavy lifting on this one.  He came up with the fundamental sound (which is above) for the quick synth riff at the beginning of WHO ARE YOU, which dances with the guitar playing of Townshend.I started with WannitBBBad's first cut at it, and sensed there was a wah effect on each note on the original.So I added from the effects, AutoWah 2, with setting Amount at 2, and Rate at 2.5.   I am no expert at synths.  I am a player, not a programmer.  The NS3C is my only synth, and so it's trial and error for me.  But I think the result, played at speed works well.Looking forward to WannitBBBad's feedback.

title: RE: The Who - Who Are You intro
post_content: Thanks for posting this. I listened to the song and I think the "quack" effect you noted was perhaps the filter Resonance adding a little more emphasis to the filter.  I tried that with your program and adjusted the Mod Env and Freq to see what that sounded like. In the song it sounds like there are two complementary parts being played at the beginning of the recording but not sure. I went ahead and added a stereo pan on the synth to get a little of the effect in the song and then added a piano on an upper split. Panel B has the synth across the whole keyboard. Here's the modified program and a MP3 of the sound playing a manual version of the intro riff. I hope this helps move it along further for you to use. Take care.Who-Are-You v2.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 199 timesWho-Are-You v2 Example.mp3

title: RE: Child Of Love - We the Kingdom Sound Request
post_content: Hi Bill. The Stage 3 program below uses the sample "Child Of Love W.NSMP". When you load it with Nord Sound Manager, NSM will ask if you want to convert it to NSMP3 format; after you agree it will load just fine as long as you have enough synth sample memory available. With the program you have the options of manually playing the notes with the Arpeggiator on (full chords are assigned to G1, C2, F2, and G2), or turning the Arpeggiator off and using the synth HOLD toa) play the chord progression on Bb1 taken from the program sound;b) play the chord progression on E1 taken from the original intro sample (turn off Tremolo, EQ, and Chorus, and turn FREQ to max); orc) play the chord progression on F1 taken from the original intro sample with high hat partially taken out (turn off Tremolo, EQ, and Chorus, and turn FREQ to max)Using the synth HOLD allows you to use both hands to play the piano.  The manual version will make it easier to sync from time to time with your drummer. The AMP Release is set so that the sound has some presence after the notes are triggered. The Tremolo puts emphasis on parts of the Arpeggiator sound . The program sound can be tweaked using FREQ, EQ, and other settings - when I get a chance I'll work on it further but I wanted to get this to you to play around with.I assigned a B3 and Strings to the right split so that they can be brought into the mix with the piano using the Control Pedal (similar to my Utility program). For the program I use the White Grand and Blue Swede Upright with Chorus applied. On the recording the piano sounds like a CP80 Electric Grand with Chorus, but I thought Blue Swede would work well.MP3 files are provided below with the some options played. It's a nice song - I hope this helps. Good luck!Child Of Love  W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 149 timesChild Of Love W.nsmp(2.38 MiB) Downloaded 152 timesChild Of Love W NSMP Orig Intro.mp3Child Of Love W NSMP Orig Intro - high EQ adjust.mp3Child Of Love W NSMP Program Chord Progression with Tremolo.mp3

title: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: Hello,This is more a request towards Nord !Any bundle files, as they include the piano samples (even if not used), can get quite big if the assigned piano is big.The only way to keep the bundle low is to assign the smallest npno ("Clavinet D6  5.0.npno"=6Mb) to both panels.As we all usually don't have this Clavinet sample as the 1st on in our piano sample memory, you need to manually assign both panels to Clavinet before saving. This is quite time consuming.I wish Nord would come with an "empty" npno that we could be load in Slot 1 of the piano memory.Fred

title: RE: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: Good idea

title: RE: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: And then you are on stage and wondering why the piano engine won't play, right? I wouldn't want to have it on my Stage 3 memory.But indeed, some solution to that size problem would be nice.

title: RE: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: Have you tried to remove the .npno from the Bundle after creation? I mean this process:  rename to .zip -> unzip (or use a zip editor) to remove the .npno. -> rezip (if unzipped) -> rename to original extension

title: RE: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: Once you get to a point where you have common sounds loaded into the Piano section, I've found that uploading and downloading Bundles happens more quickly. I still use the "switch to Clav" trick in some cases, particularly if I'm going to be moving Programs amongst more than one NS2 or NS3.

title: RE: Smaller npno to keep bundle files size reasonable ?
post_content: All of your comments make sense, thanks for your feedback.@FZiegler : as those bundles are not using Piano engine at all, I don't mind having the Clav by default@MaxPiano : yes, this is an option but I need to find a way to automate the removal of the specific npno inside many ZIP/bundle files (batch in command line ?)@EricL : correct. Nord made some enhancement to load more quickly bundles that already have the piano sample inside the engine. But see also my comment below.I'm raising this point specifically when I have many bundles I want to share or transfer.Any standard piano sound is 150Mb, therefore a standard 15-programs for 1-concert-set is going to eat up minimum 2.5G of file size... for nothingAnd this also applies here in NUF where the filesize is capped at 50Mb : always frustrating not be able to upload bundles or to find existing programs but pointing to "unknown" samples !Fred

post_content: Just received negative feedback from Nord.Still not getting used to itI'll dig the CMD/batch way to remove the npno from the ZIP/bundle file.Fred

post_content: cookie wrote:Any standard piano sound is 150Mb, therefore a standard 15-programs for 1-concert-set is going to eat up minimum 2.5G of file size...Why? title: Get lucky - synth sound
post_content: I'll try to create this synth sound at the end of Daft Punk's Get lucky.But as I'm not familiar with synthesis (yes, I'm a bad sample loader type of keyboardist), if anyone has some guidelines or can share the program/parameters, it will save me some time !The sound itself starts @03:42 :MerciFred

title: RE: Get lucky - synth sound
post_content: I got a similar sound with just a single saw wave through a low pass, medium resonance. Cutoff so that resonance hits the second harmonic of the F# note. (or just when it sounds right)Both Amp and Filter envelope have short attack and release, amp env has long decay, filter env has shorter decay. Then adjust the filter envelope amount. Select voice mode Mono and add a bit of glide.Hope this helps

post_content: Hey all,I hope everyone is good and staying safe.I'm in search of a few sounds could anyone be of assistance?I am a Gospel musician I've searched the whole forum and only found a few MKS sounds, the analog pad from the Motif Shout out to Dkernohan. I am in search of others including;RolandD-50 Heaven (Bright Pad) - JV-1080Stacc Heaven- -JV-1080PolyBrass JV-1080D50- Fantasia (Lower 1 and Upper 1&2)D50- Rich brass (Upper 2 only)YamahaJP Brass (From the original Motif I believe)After 1984 BrassJ Pop BellsThat's all for the time being lol thank you in advance.Now onto why I can't do it myself...I sample notes in minor 3rds and hold each note for 5 seconds (1elephant 2 elephants etc) The samples I make cut off with and without the sustain pedal.Do I need to Hold my notes out for longer in the sampling process? Why doesn't the sample just play out for infinity? The sustain option in the sampler is enabled as well.It's a lot to take in but I'd appreciate the help.Kind regards,Natty Smith

title: RE: Sound Requests for NS3 + Sampling Issue
post_content: Natty Smith wrote:...Now onto why I can't do it myself...   I sample notes in minor 3rds and hold each note for 5 seconds (1elephant 2 elephants etc) The samples I make cut off with and without the sustain pedal.Do I need to Hold my notes out for longer in the sampling process? Why doesn't the sample just play out for infinity? The sustain option in the sampler is enabled as well.It's a lot to take in but I'd appreciate the help.Kind regards,Natty SmithHello, I would suggest using the "search" function on the main page and Nord User Sounds site for the samples you are looking for - I believe some are posted.  Regarding your sampling issue, it sounds like all you need to do after loading your samples into the Nord Sample Editor 4 is enable "looping" and set where you want the loop to start and end if you don't care for the loop NSE4 automatically assigns. Along with the NSE4 manual, "My Keys To Music" on YouTube has a free series of videos on sampling that may help. Though you are sampling for 5 seconds (good practice to start with long samples, you can always shorten them in the NSE4), you'll find that for some samples you can loop them at a shorter duration after working with them in NSE4 to reduce the Nord sample size. Good luck to you!

title: RE: Sound Requests for NS3 + Sampling Issue

title: Four Clavinets w FX Program and NSMP Sample
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well.  For those looking for sounds and effects with the Clavinet, here's a program I put together that focuses on the synth side, combining my synth version of the clavinet "P5SynthClav W.ns3f" atviewtopic.php?t=15996with a Clavinet sample I put together that won't break the Nord memory bank at only 198 KB.  The MP3 covers the program in the following in order:A) Clavinet Sample on Panel AB) "A" plus FlangerC) "B" plus EQ and AutoWah with Rate morphed to the Control PedalD) P5SynthClav on Panel BE) "D" plus FlangerF) "E" plus AutoWah with Rate morphed to the Control Pedal (same settings as Panel A)G) Add Panel B piano section ClavinetH) Both Panels On ("C" and "G" settings)I) Add Panel A piano section ClavinetWhen I use the Wah or AutoWah, I usually use the EQ as well to add some low end back in and sometimes make other changes such as taking take out some of the midrange if needed.  You get what you "pay" for - at 198K my sample was put together using only three sampled notes focused on the low and middle section with the rest being interpolated (ending at G6).  Better, but larger Clavinet samples can be found on the Nord site athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... -30/pianosif you are interested. As set up, the effects can easily be applied to the piano section Clavinets if desired.  I hope some of you get some use out of these. Take care.Clavinet S.nsmp(197.26 KiB) Downloaded 190 times4 Clavinets FX W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 194 times4 Clavinets FX W Demo.mp3Note: "4 Clavinets FX W.ns3f" updated on January 23, 2022 with adjustments to Panel B AutoWah.

title: RE: Nord stage 3 layering samples
post_content: Ok so it’s quite a simple sample player then without any layers?

title: RE: Nord stage 3 layering samples
post_content: Tristanmac wrote:Ok so it’s quite a simple sample player then without any layers?As @FZiegler said, user manual is really easy to use and read. I don't own any Nord yet, but I've read whole Stage 3 manual few times and it's quite intuitive. Short answer, no it's not possible to layer two samples on the same A or B panel.But there is workaround to make something similar. If you use Nord Sample Editor, you can record each of the 2 or more samples you want to layer together and connect them into one sample.But there is a catch, before recording your samples into a DAW or Sample Editor, you should make all your desired settings for each sample to get what you want from them. Because when you connect those 2 or more samples together into one, and load them into Nord, there will be no way to control different parameters for each independent sample, because they're all layered together into one.So Nord reads them as one sample --> all effects, parameters inside synth section affect that whole sample (group you made)... but there you have it, that's the way you can have more than two sample layers on any Nord, but it's a little bit limited, so how useful is that depends on your needs.P.S. don't forget to read manual, it's really necessary and important to get most out of your stage 3. I don't get people who own that beautiful keyboard and don't read manual and do some research. I can't afford it at a moment, but I've done so so many research, read so much stuff about it, watched many many videos, and had a chance to play it 3-4 times in my local store for 1 or 2 hours... that's all... but it's  worth it to me, and can't wait a day when I'll probably own one.

title: RE: Nord stage 3 layering samples
post_content: Tristanmac wrote:Ok so it’s quite a simple sample player then without any layers?Yes, there is only one sound layer for the whole velocity range.But you can shape the sound according to velocity with the Mod Envelope and the Amp Envelope. So, no, it's not a simple sample player.Dig into it and try a bit. It'll take a few days to get through all the possibilities.And if you want to fatten a sound, you'll find ways to do it. Try Unison, for example.

title: RE: Nord stage 3 layering samples
post_content: A Nord Stage 3 isn't always the better live instrument. Depends on your needs. If it was different, you'd have to see a Nord on stage everywhere - which is not the case.I'm glad, for example, that I don't need brass sounds (as I've got enough brass around me in the band): You will not have the same features as on a workstation. To get a brass smear, you'll have to use the pitch stick. You can set its (synth) range in the Sound settings.But again, I'd suggest that you have a deep look into how a Nord Stage is going to be played - and it may take a few months until you can say if you like the concept or not. In my eyes, it's a great tool for people who want to make decent music with a reasonable effort. The manual is here:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sites/def ... on%20M.pdf. Around 55 pages to be read. No need to unpack it from the box.

title: RE: Nord stage 3 layering samples
post_content: There are people arriving on the forum who complain about the Nord Stage or Electro saying: What - only 1 or 2 synth engines, only 2 or 4 KB zones, only 2 or 4 MIDI channels etc.!If you want to fire preconstructed sounds, a Kronos probably will have much more capabilities to get close to the original. The arp section of the Stage is not very powerful, for example. No sequencer. Little capability for EDM (only 1 LFO). That's what you might need in a cover band - as far as I've understood.If you say: I want to make my own sounding and want to be able to hook up a new sound in a few seconds or change my settings softly or dramatically while playing, a Nord is great.I'm the keyboarder in a big band playing jazz, latin and pop standards - mostly with a different sounding than the original (special arrangements, no covers). So the capabilities of a Stage are far more than I need for that as nobody is asking me to sound exactly like XY.What I intended to say is: A Stage 3 cannot be the best instrument on the market for everything - as some people seem to think. But I have experienced that it has pushed my creativity. Of course, it's primarily made for live use - with a distinct idea behind what live playing could mean.Tristanmac wrote:I assumed as it was super easy to build a patch, piano/organ/pads, easily turn on/off or blend, and sounded great that it would be ideal for the meat and potatoes of any keys player?I fully agree on that. Even if I don't know what you exactly mean by a meat and potato sound (I'm not a native English speaker). To me, it's acoustic piano (great uprights!), Rhodes, Wurly, Clavinet, electric organs and a little synth playing. A Nord Stage will even provide some vegetable and sauce. And indeed: for the rest (whatever that is), you still have the Nord Sample Editor and the Extern section.

title: RE: The Weeknd - Save Your Tears
post_content: Hello. I noticed this is your first post, welcome to the Forum! I listened to song, and like many these days, it's loaded with different synth sounds. Hopefully someone from the Forum has worked on this and might have  something to start with, but until then, I would suggest writing down the different sounds you hear, where they are in the song, and deciding which ones you want to cover in your program(s). My approach to a song like this would be to come up with the individual sounds with as many programs as it takes to cover what I want to play, and then determine which ones would work well putting 2, 3, 4.. in one sample. I have a few examples of combining sounds in one sample and mapping out where they're used that works well for capturing multiple synth parts. This link has audio examples and links to the samples in the Sample Forum to give you an idea of what you could do. Good luck to you!nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/40-s ... 21907.html

post_content: I had a listen to it. title: RE: [REQ] Beetles Birthday Sound
post_content: Just remember that there were no synths at that time.All the "synth sounds" were normal, acoustic or electromechanical pianos, organs and guitars mangled through leslie speakers, guitar amps, tape editing, plate reverbs and all sorts of very analog stuff!Anyway, the Beatles are the most researched and studied band in history, you can surely find exactly how that sound was created.

title: RE: [REQ] Beetles Birthday Sound
post_content: http://www.beatlesebooks.com/birthdayhttps://www.beatlesbible.com/1968/09/18 ... -birthday/the piano sound was made by running it through a Vox Conqueror guitar amplifier and speaker cabinet which has a mid-range boost (MRB) function that jumps between the frequencies. After suggesting this effect, Ken Scott was recruited to make it work. "I plugged it up to show them what I meant," Ken explains. "When John heard it, he immediately said, 'Yeah, that's great - You do it,' and made me stay there turning the knob in time with the beat.that sounds like a VERY difficult effect to replicate with the "normal" effect section of the Stage or Electro!Maybe trying some combinations of piano with Leslie, flanger, EQ and distortion?

title: Nord Stage 3 and old macbook

title: RE: Nord Stage 3 and old macbook
post_content: Hi,downloading an older version of the software is possible by modifying the current software download link.The actual link is this:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sites/def ... 0v7.64.dmgThe numbers at the end just before the .dmg extension show the software version. If you like to download for example the old v7.28 software you would have to modify the link like this:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sites/def ... 0v7.28.dmgThis works for a number of old versions but not for all - you would have to give it a try to find out the latest version that works with Lion.

title: RE: Nord Stage 3 and old macbook

title: RE: Nord Stage 3 and old macbook
post_content: any NSE4 version works on Lion, NSE2 v2.28 (latest) works fine

title: RE: Nord Stage 3 and old macbook

title: RE: The killers - Somebody told me
post_content: First try for this song. Not fully satisfied of the sound but it can be a good start.First sound for intro:- play Bb on lower part. KB HOLD is used to free the left hand for modulation wheel (SYNC OSC CTRL) while playing octave with right hand.- Play Eb, then Gb and Bb + move mod wheel a lot for crazy effect.Second sound:- strings on upper part (pitch bend down for the end of strings part)- first patch upper part has been copied to lower part (to add an electro style along the song)I haven't yet used these patches with my band (I stay at home during coronavirus period).The difficulty is to correctly use the MOD WHEEL (No very good in my record).The two parts of first patch sound sometimes weird together when moving mod wheel.There are rooms for improvements (in the sound and my playing).Any suggestions are welcome...

title: Sliding Pitch Programs including Syndrum
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well.  A recent post in the main Stage Forumnord-stage-forum-f3/stage-3-synth-progr ... 21767.htmlhad a question about setting up a synth program allowing a single note to fall off in pitch over one or two beats after being hit. I offered a couple suggestions and then messed around with it further on my Stage 3.  Getting the pitch of a note to slide down, slide up, or both, without the use of morphing or the pitch stick is something the NS3 can cover well (as long as you don't need the effect on a Super or Sample waveform), however absent full ADSR capability, the effect cannot be delayed for some period after playing a note within one synth program.  To get around that, here are a couple of programs where I use two synth programs - the primary sound on one panel and a sliding pitch sound on the second panel with the Delay effect used to bring it in later than when the note is played. For the DX7 program, the Delay effect is on panel A with the AMP ENV Attack bringing it in slowly to somewhat coincide with the primary sound on Panel B decaying out. To learn more about it, there's nothing like turning the knobs and seeing what they do, so load a DX7 version and see if you can create the Analog Brass version from it - all are posted.  Good luck!Update Nov 26, 2021: Replaced the DX7 program with versions sliding (gliding) up and sliding down, and added a "Syndrum" program.DX7 SlidinDown W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 165 timesDX7 SlidinDown W NS3F Example2.mp3DX7 SlidinUp   W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 171 timesDX7 SlidinUp W NS3F Example.mp3Brass Slidin5thW.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 202 timesBrass Slidin5thW NS3F Example.mp3For the "Syndrum" program, both panels are used with the electronic drum on Panel A and an overlapping white noise "hit" on Panel B.  In the MP3 I play just Panel A, switch to Panel B, enable both, and then add an arpeggiator on both. Resonance can be added for other classic effects.SynDrum        W.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 162 timesSynDrum W NS3F Example.mp3Keywords: Glide Slide Pitch Simmons

title: [REQ] Looking for TB 303 Bass Sounds
post_content: I've done some searching here on the forum, Nord's site, and the internet...not finding much. I'm curious if anyone has done any Roland TB303 "acid" bass samples or tried to get this out of the NS3 synth engine? I have a song to learn that includes a bit of this sound and was searching for some starter material.A few of the synth bass samples on Nord's site are promising.nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/emul ... chi#p38921Does anyone have any TB303 bass sounds or tips to share? Thanks so much!Eric

title: RE: [REQ] Looking for TB 303 Bass Sounds
post_content: I never heard of the TB 303 until your post. I looked it up - it's amazing how much music was affected by a discarded Roland product just by folks simply being creative. A great article about the TB 303 is athttps://mixdownmag.com.au/features/the- ... -all-time/Paired with a sequencer, a NSMP3 sample of a pattern you created, or playing around with the arpeggiator for a similar effect, you could get a lot out of the Stage 3. Getting the sound is very much the same as what's discussed in the first video  - turning knobs. I don't have my Stage 3 right now, but using a classic wave like the pulse, start with Mod Env settings of Attack 0, Decay 3, Release 0 to get a quick drop from the Filter Mod Env setting of 10 down to the Freq setting of 1. Resonance is used a lot. On the Amp Env, set Attack 0, Decay 10, Release 1. Get a pattern started, put the Stage 3 synth on hold, then start turning the knobs. I'll mess around with it when I get back to my Stage 3.  Good luck, take care.

title: RE: [REQ] Looking for TB 303 Bass Sounds
post_content: As an example of my post above, I took a wave file I created for "Fame" posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... me#p142097and made a NSMP sample to play around with.  I added distortion and played around with a couple knobs.  Using a sample of a sequence is not as flexible as using a sequencer or the arpeggiator for easily changing the base sound and other parameters, but you can still getting something from it. Take care.Fame ACID.mp3

title: [REQ] Soul with a capital S
post_content: Can anyone make me a patch that is exactly like the one in the video? With the low brass at the bottom keys, rhodes piano in the middle, and brass/horns up top?Thanks so much.

title: RE: [REQ] Soul with a capital S
post_content: The keyboard in the middle is trying to be a Hammond organ — though you're going to have a hard time trying to make the Stage 3 organ sound as shitty as that one there.I suggest you try it yourself; it's fairly simple: Split the keyboard into three segments, assign an organ engine to the middle split, the synth on Panel A to the left, and the synth on Panel B to the right split. You can assign engines to a particular split section by either holding the "Shift" button and pressing the On/Off/Zone Select button, or by quickly double-pressing that button.Switch on the rotary speaker (to "organ"), set the organ model to "B3" and adjust drawbars to taste (I'd probably start with 888800036 or so, probably with chorus set to C3).Next, select the synth presets for the horns — you can press the "Shift" button an turn the "synth preset" knob to have it show a list of sounds that you scroll through.Choose a baritone sax synth preset for the synth on Panel A, and a full brass synth preset for the synth on Panel B.What you're *not* going to get is the bell ride he's playing on the highest note during the pre-chorus, but I have no idea why you'd want to play that, anyway.

title: Left / right channel test for the PA
post_content: Last couple of weeks playing at church, I noticed that the keyboard sound was lacking bass. After a bit of investigation with our sound team we found it was a patching error which meant that only the right side was making it through the PA (I normally go to the PA in stereo).That made me think wouldn't it be great to have a quick way to check both left and right channels are connected through the PA with the same gain etc. so I made a couple of quick left / right check samples from the excellent Bink audio test CD.  They both achieve the same purpose, but with different sample sizes.To use, load the program and sample, and simply hold any key to identify left and right channels.Nord Audio Test Long.mp3Nord Audio Test Short.mp3Audio Test Long.nsmp3Long audio test sample(224.36 KiB) Downloaded 130 timesAudio Test Short.nsmp3Short audio test sample(84.98 KiB) Downloaded 128 timesAudio Test Long.ns3fLong audio test program(592 Bytes) Downloaded 121 timesAudio Test Short.ns3fShort audio test program(592 Bytes) Downloaded 119 times

title: RE: Left / right channel test for the PA
post_content: I use the autopan at a very slow rate.

title: RE: Left / right channel test for the PA
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:I use the autopan at a very slow rate.Ping pong delay works as well--dj

title: RE: Left / right channel test for the PA
post_content: or unplugging one cable at a time and verifying signal path that way ... a bit rough on everyone's ears, but quick

title: RE: Left / right channel test for the PA
post_content: Great idea, thanks.There is a setting on the NE6 to change the output from stereo to L/Organ R/Piano.  A quick switch to this setting lets me know both channels are making it to the mains and monitors.  I've had nights where I had no definition (highs) to the piano and like you, I found I wasn't getting both outputs.  In my case, it was a 1/4" patch cable that jumped out of the socket.  It was a planet waves cable that had a plug that was just barely shorter then it needed and managed to wiggle out while playing.  Switched to Monoprice patch cables and haven't had it happen since.

title: Piano with good sustain
post_content: HeyIm a bit of a Nord novice, I have a NS3 and tend to use only a fraction of its capabilities as Im a solo singer who tends to use just piano voices. Im looking for a good long sustain on the piano, any advice on how to get this? I would love to hear from anyone who is techie enough to have set up a really layered piano which could be my go to sound for solo piano and singing.Stuart

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: stuartmclean wrote:HeyIm a bit of a Nord novice, I have a NS3 and tend to use only a fraction of its capabilities as Im a solo singer who tends to use just piano voices. Im looking for a good long sustain on the piano, any advice on how to get this? I would love to hear from anyone who is techie enough to have set up a really layered piano which could be my go to sound for solo piano and singing.StuartMy "go to" pianos are typically the White Grand and Amber Upright. Using compression (far right on the Nord) can help notes retain a higher output level (but losing some initial dynamics if up too much) giving the impression of a longer sustain, however other options include adding a longer-sustaining piano sample to the synth section and having it fade in behind your primary piano, or incorporating a light "pad" behind the piano in the mix that can hold for a longer duration without standing out. Here are a couple examples with the pads further out in the mix but easy to move back using the Control Pedal. Follow the links to get to the programs that you can load into your Stage 3 using the Nord Sound Manager.  I hope this helps, good luck!nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p132240MP3 Example of Felt Piano  W.mp3nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p104370EastSouthern_W.mp3

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: That is so helpful, thank you. I love the mp3 examples you've included,e specially the first one. Appreciate you coming back to me.

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: Another quick question. Can I take these mp3 examples and load them in to my nord as samples?

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: stuartmclean wrote:Another quick question. Can I take these mp3 examples and load them in to my nord as samples?Not directly, but you can convert them in .wav format and load them in the Nord Sample Editor, which will convert them in Nord's proprietary .nsmp files.

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: What Spider suggest to sample, is true for isolated (one note at a time) audio files, but not for recordings of a performance.Before getting into sampling, it might be a good idea to try the many pianos in Nord Piano Library and learn how to layer some strings sounds.You definitely want to try the ns3f files (links) that WannitBBBad has posted above which you can load into your instrument and reproduce the sounds he recorded in the MP3s. If you get stuck with the procedure, ask and people here will help.Also maybe you can try using reverb to give some more spatial sustain to the sound.

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: Instead of a synth pad, you can consider layering a Rhodes EP under the acoustic piano. It will have the same polyphony and overall behavior of the piano, but will give you a warm sustaining sound similar to a synth pad. Keep it lower in volume than the acoustic sound, and it might yield the effect you’re looking for.

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: @stuartmclean, you have a wonderful instrument for what you want to do -- backing your vocals -- you just need to crack open the well-written manual and go through the examples.  Follow that with a few youtube videos for reinforcement and more examples.  Then, sit down at your instrument, put on some headphones, and spend some serious time.  It will be worth it.The variety and appeal of the sounds you can get out of a NS3 without much work at all is amazing.  And you might enjoy the process.

title: RE: Piano with good sustain
post_content: stuartmclean wrote:Another quick question. Can I take these mp3 examples and load them in to my nord as samples?As noted by Mr_-G-, you can follow the links to get to the Stage 3 programs I used to make the mp3 examples (I modified my first response to add that point). Using the Nord Sound Manager available on the Nord site athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/software- ... nd-manageryou can load the programs into your Stage 3.  I use a control pedal for most of my programs, so you would need to get one to take full advantage of my programs and the morphing feature in general. I use a Yamaha FC-7 for my control pedal, but a search for "control pedal" in this Forum will yield other suggestions as well.  Adding an EP in the other panel as suggested by Rusty Mike or simply adding a nice long reverb effect can add character to the piano without overshadowing it.  Most importantly, reading through the manual provided for each Nord App as suggested by cphollis will help quite a bit. Good luck to you!

title: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: Hi there,can anyone tell me how to create the sound of Genesis Turn it on again on NS3. Especially the Bridge part .Please i need your help.Best regardsJürgen

title: RE: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: Hi Jürgen,The base sound, as you might already know, is a CP80 with loads of chorus (1, 70%, speed around 40)The bridge sound should be some kind of Saw lead sound, which is really fat and soft - I couldn't recreate the softness on my Stage 2...But it's close... use a saw sound with a filter and modulation envelope. add a second saw detuned -5, voice mode mono, glide 1.3unison 1, chorus 2 100% speed 25You might need the second panel if you want to have Chorus on both sounds.I hope this helps you - I was kinda curious when I read the post and wanted to try very quickly on my NS2!

title: RE: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: Dear Martinthank you very much for your help.Best regardsJürgen

title: RE: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: MartinJ2EX wrote:The base sound, as you might already know, is a CP80 with loads of chorus (1, 70%, speed around 40)Thanks for reminding me of this one, I hadn’t listened to it in a long time...If you don’t have a guitarist with a 12-string electric handy, you might consider adding a sample to get that “twang”, and some thickness.  There’s only a few spots where both do not sound together (e.g., CP80 speaks alone in the high fill leading into “I... I... I...”)And then there’s the occasional horn stab.

title: RE: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: Check out the re-mastered version of this song, much more aggressive. One of my fav Genesis albums.D.

title: RE: [REQ] Genesis Turn it on again
post_content: Bridge = brass + strings.... I like the CS20 string sample (Bank A) and the pop brass sample (Bank B).  Add reverb, chorus and compression.Piano is just your CP-70 electric piano sound that is on one of your grand piano banks near the end.  Add chorus, leslie (slow, 0 drive), reverb and compression and you should be good to go.Good luck and have fun!

title: RE: [REQ] Looking for 8 Bit Sounds (old video game sounds)
post_content: This might be off-topic here but how would someone replicate the same sound on a Lead A1? I opened up the "Old School Game" program in NS3 Program Viewer. It says there is a Square wave with the second oscillator being a detuned square wave.As far as I could tell the second oscillator is detuned by 4 semitones. Or is it 0.4 semitones because of the fine adjustment?It doesn't sound anything like the uploaded demo.

title: RE: [REQ] Looking for 8 Bit Sounds (old video game sounds)
post_content: szszoke wrote:This might be off-topic here but how would someone replicate the same sound on a Lead A1? I opened up the "Old School Game" program in NS3 Program Viewer. It says there is a Square wave with the second oscillator being a detuned square wave.As far as I could tell the second oscillator is detuned by 4 semitones. Or is it 0.4 semitones because of the fine adjustment?It doesn't sound anything like the uploaded demo.The "4" that you see in the viewer is noting that it's using 4th type of OSC 2 setting on the Stage 3 - it's the same thing we see on the OLED display. The OSC2 pulse is set to be an octave lower than the OSC1 pulse, and the OSC Control is set at zero, so there isn't any detune being applied.  Try setting up two pulse waves an octave apart (equal levels) with vibrato applied. I hope that helps, take care.

post_content: I recommend you to get acquainted with different pianos and effects. Just play around with settings and you will find a suitable sound in no time. The sound does not have to be an exact representation of what you get on Bon Jovi's record. In contrast to that, you can make a sound that you like. And you will be more prepared to make changes to it in case you (or your bandmates) think it needs some adjusting.

title: [REQ] sound of "Entangled" Genesis for Nord stage 3
post_content: Hi friends,Does anyone has a good sweeping sound for Entangled ( Genesis) ?For Nord Stage 3Thanks very much

title: RE: [REQ] sound of "Entangled" Genesis for Nord stage 3
post_content: Hello. Listening to the song and then looking up more info on the keyboard setup, I believe a Mellotron was used with male voices for the lower part and an Arp Pro-Soloist with fast vibrato was used for the higher part, so a keyboard split with both synth panels could come close.  As the vibrato speed is a universal setting, I would use the LFO to get the effect for the solo synth. For most of the song, a 12-string sample could be used to play along with the other guitars. I'll check it out on my Stage 3 tomorrow and suggest some settings to try. Take care

title: Strings Bank (Hard, Soft, Synt strings)
post_content: This is my strings bank. It contains 15 programs, in 3 categories:Hard Strings: Fast attack strings for symphonic elementsSoft Strings: Slow attack strings for ambient atmospheresSynt Strings: Analog string emulations for vintage soundsSome practical notes:All patches are programmed at approximately -2 to -4 dB, to allow for some volume tweaking in both directions.Additionally, all patches have a default light compression and reverb setting, intended for live playing.Finally, all these default patches are limited to using Panel A only. This was done for mainly 2 reasons:For me to learn the synth better, and use all possibilities within one panelTo allow for better expansion upon all my base patchesLinks to NUS and a list of samples used are in the following posts.PS: A special sample is needed for the Hard Strings 5 program - this has to be "FullStrings2" from the 2.0 sample library (because I couldn't get the 3.0 version to work with "Fast Attack" option), and it has to be loaded in Sample Lib, Loc. 8. There is a direct link to this sound, and a bundled version as well (Hard Strings 5.ns3fb file).PPS: These patches are also meant as inspiration, it shouldn't be too hard to edit them, change samples, layers etc. - but starting from a good base sound, instead of a completely blank program.EDIT: Hard Strings and Soft Strings patches have been updated with better modulation envelope settings.Enjoy!

title: Strings Bank (Hard, Soft, Synt strings)
post_content: Link:https://nordusersounds.com/sound/50174Samples used:Hard Strings 1: Samp Lib, 22, 16-Violin Legato_SO 3.0.Hard Strings 2: Samp Lib, 28, 10-Celli Legato_SO 3.1.Hard Strings 3: Samp Lib, 20, Strings Ensemble Leg_KG 3.0.Hard Strings 4: Samp Lib, 1, OrchStrings Legato_KH 3.0.Hard Strings 5: Samp Lib, 8, Full Strings 2_SR mono 2.0 (also bundled).Link toFullStrings 2 (v2.0)(load into Sample Lib, Loc. 8)Alternative download (v1.1)

title: Pitch Bend or other technique
post_content: Not sure if something like this is possible with the stage 3. I can always sequence it or sample, but trying to think if there was a way to recreate on the fly.playing the A/E in left hand and right hand the little melody, but out of hands to also apply the creepy pitch bend. title: RE: Pitch Bend or other technique
post_content: waypastmidnight wrote:....Can anything else be setup to modify the pitch?Unfortunately only the pitch bar can be used with the sample, however the pitch can be morphed to the Control Pedal for the Classic, Wave, and Formant waves available. I have an example posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p106971where the pitch and filter FREQ are morphed to the Control Pedal. You could try modifying the Tubular Bells wave to see if you could emulate the toy piano. I would go at it with both panel synths and use the 2nd to get the initial striking sound (perhaps toy piano sample cut off with almost immediate decay). Take care

title: RE: Pitch Bend or other technique
post_content: Following you advice, here's what I came up with.Using the control pedal to roll off the pitch and freq, also having it bring in some ring modulation and push it farther into the reverb.Thanks

title: RE: Patch request - ELP - In the Beginning
post_content: Hi, I still have a Stage 2 for the time being and my band will be covering From the Beginning. I used the same approach of using synths in Slots A and B to get the octave spread - mine sounds "OK", but yours sounds better.  Do you still have a Stage 2 version of this patch?  I would love to compare notes regarding all the other settings you used - i.e., specific wave forms, glide settings, envelope, wet/dry, amp sim, etc.Also, if you have experience with the actual Moog settings that Emerson used... I don't own a Moog, but I'd love to learn any basic Moog facts that relate to this sound, if you'd care to share them. For example, which Moog did he use? - what knobs would he have turned?  (it would be fun to look at a picture of a Moog control panel and think about how someone would have achieved that sound). Thanks!Kevin

title: RE: Patch request - ELP - In the Beginning
post_content: jkodhner wrote:... Do you still have a Stage 2 version of this patch? ...Also, if you have experience with the actual Moog settings that Emerson used...I have the Stage 2 version posted atnord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... t7676.htmland you might find the following link helpful for other Stage 2 programs as well:nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html.I believe Keith Emerson used an ARP synthesizer on this song - the Stage 2 controls used would include the MOD ENV DECAY, FREQ, MOD ENV, and RES (resonance). Learning more about the Stage 3 after the post above, it is possible to get two notes using OSC1 and OSC2 on the Stage 3 (one Synth slot). Obwanz has a Stage 3 version posted before mine that I really like where synth effects are morphed to the Mod Wheel for sounds at the end of the song.  You might want to try that after loading the Stage 2 program and see what you come up with. I hope this helps. Take care.

title: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: Hi all,I've had my Stage 3 88 for a little over a year now and am still very much so learning the ropes with it. I play in a trio (Keyboards, Drums, Vocals) and am in need of heavier low end sounds to comp for not having a bass player. My sound guy keeps harping on me to improve my electric piano sound as he says it sounds very thin. Attached is the file, anyone have any idea as to how I may be able to increase the fullness of the sound?Thanks,Spencer

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: Hi Spencer, I haven’t checked your program yet but have you tried to split the keyboard and add another electric piano or a bass sample to the lower part, for which you can also use the EQ to adjust to your taste?

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: Schorsch wrote:Hi Spencer, I haven’t checked your program yet but have you tried to split the keyboard and add another electric piano or a bass sample to the lower part, for which you can also use the EQ to adjust to your taste?I've played with the idea some - layering in a fretless bass. My biggest problem there is that I can often hear the bass coming through as well which in my opinion compromises the sound a bit. Was out this past weekend and saw a Steely Dan tribute band - both keyboardists utilizing Nord Stage 3 88 units. Needless to say, I couldn't believe how full their electric piano sounds were. Have had to really pump the EQ settings to achieve fullness out of the sounds all across the board in my Stage 3, it leads me to think I'm doing something very wrong. Any ideas as to why this may be? Do you have trouble with thin sounds as well?

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: I think that speakers also matter a lot, it’s different listening to a band with a full PA or listening at home through some monitor speakers or headphones. For samples I would look at some soft synth bass samples rather than bass guitars which might be suited better to add a subtle amount of low end without compromising the electric piano sound too much

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: UPDATE:Went into Guitar Center today and was able to side by side my Nord Stage 3 with one they had on the floor. Sounds when compared were identical in fullness leading me to believe that it may be a cable problem?Question for anyone who knows cables. I'm currently running 1/4 in. to XLR hybrid cables directly to the board. The tech at Guitar Center had told me I should try running straight 1/4 in. to the board or utilize a direct box. Had mentioned level impedance as the cause for sounds lacking fullness. Would the variation in hybrid cable to straight instrument cable have that big of an impact on sound? If this is the case the problem might lie entirely with how I'm getting to the board rather than within the sounds themselves.Thanks in advance for any advice on the subject.Spencer

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: The Nord outputs are unbalanced, so a mixer with balanced outputs or a direct box is a good idea going to the main board--dj

title: RE: Nord Electric Piano Sounds
post_content: Hello, I don't see any benefit in using those cables if they don't convert your signal from Hi-Z to Lo-Z.  I would suggest using a direct box for each channel out (1/4" to the direct box and XLR from the box to the mixer) or running 1/4" cables straight to the board. Also, if your house mix isn't stereo with your channels (assuming just two) panned left and right, the NS3 also won't sound optimal as well. I hope this helps, good luck.Edit: Agree with DJKeys about a mixer being a good option as well.

title: Program for September - Earth Wind & Fire
post_content: Just wondered whether anyone has a program for Earth Wind & Fire with the brass sounds. I know how to make one simply but struggling with the brass sounds on the NS3 to make it sound good.Thanks for any help in advance

title: RE: Program for September - Earth Wind & Fire
post_content: I checked this out quickly this morning and one suggestion would be to try stock NS3 sample 60 "Trumpets Legato_KH 3.0" in Panel A and sample 69 "BrassSection Double 2_CL 3.0" an octave lower in Panel B. The original group had a sax, trombone, and two trumpets, so you might want to try a few different sample combinations including BrassSection Pop to get the right mix and attack. Good luck!

title: Quick help on creating SAW sound with LFO/filter + effects
post_content: Hello !I usually don't ask for help here, but I'm currently travelling (greetings from Togo !) and will land home next saturday, just few hours before a concert (fresh and smiling) !Could someone please share a program that recreates the SAW sound heard in the intro song of Marcia Baila ?Talking about the A note that goes from one octave to the octave up.Googled around and it seems this is a 1 OSC SAW with portamento, with a resonance filter and an LFO with modulates the filter. I'll use the Mod Wheel for morphing.As for the effects, it seems flanger and auto-wah are applied, see the parameters used by a Motif fellow in the doc below.http://kikiclavier.free.fr/audiokeys/do ... aBaila.pdfI also have a NS2, so glad to check your ns2p if ns3f is not possible !Again, thanks for any help !This is the kind of sound that really is missed if not played !Fred

title: RE: Quick help on creating SAW sound with LFO/filter + effects

Not perfect but good starting point, have not yet tested it in live, let me know how it sounds...Using only sample from the Nord Library. Bonus: I'm adding my Brass section too.Intro:EStx Sweeper BR fromhttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... ka-synthexBrass:PowerSynths Modern Symphonics BR:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... wer-synthsFL Orche12:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... orchestral

title: Edgar WINTER Frankenstein
post_content: Has anyone had any luck programming the Edgar Winter Frankenstein synthesizer sounds for NS3? I guess I could always sample it from my Yamaha motif es, but would love to hear it from the nord synth engine. Thanks

title: RE: Edgar WINTER Frankenstein
post_content: Great song for synths, unfortunately I haven't programmed this one but others might have.  Watching Edgar Winter play it live on the video below helps in seeing how it's played and also what's in some of the sounds used.  A control knob to the left provides the wide pitch swings; setting up the synth to use only OSC2 will provide the wide swings but they will be digital stairs steps, not the smooth analog pitch changes.  The "wah" effect is either provided by a traditional wah wah pedal or possibly a control pedal for the ARP. The first sound used is a classic analog synth with portamento and some amount of release, but the other after the drums has a pulse LFO applied and possibly an octave trigger (notes toggling an octave like you'd get with the single octave arpeggiator playing individual notes). Later it gets even more interesting when Edgar moves to the ARP panel; the panel B synth for my program "WannitBBBadSyncW.ns3f" atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlhas some similar effects that can be adjusted in real-time if you'd want to try messing around with it for that part (MP3 provided below).  Good luck to you.Slot_B_WannitBBBadSyncW short.mp3VIDEO AT:https://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=ed ... &FORM=VIRE

title: RE: Trying to create organ sound
post_content: I don't have my Stage 3 with me right now to check it out, but I'd suggest trying a B3 setting like 800060300 with a fast Leslie and no Chorus/Vibrato or touch percussion. You can play around with upper "drawbars" 60300 to tweak the sound further. Good luck

title: RE: Is too much enough?
post_content: This is a surprisingly difficult challenge, I must say.So even though I'm curious; take your time.I have now and then improved these 5 patches for over a year; thus this is not a measure for the difficultness only a result of no deadline.So, can I do a maxed-out patch in only a few days? Well… obviously yes because a result is here.But it’s not easy to get several sounds to marry each other and have good balance between them and ensure that all individual sounds contribute to the result in some way, not only light a Led.This new patch is originally not changed with Control pedal in upper position.Only difference is the piano sample changed from V5 to V6 and echo is put on Mod-wheel.When Control pedal is down then more sounds adds, but due to difficulty’s mentioned only subtly.[nordusersounds]JfrsonStrCtrlpMW.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 181 times[/nordusersounds][/mp3player]

title: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: Hi all,Im new to the forum, so thank you all for your kind and helpful replies.I did mention this in another post in samples, however I was wondering who out here has bought the 76 key version of the stage 3, and wished they go the 88?Im missing the low 'C' sometimes, but not sure if its that important when playing live gigs?I know its an extra 6-7kg and another £200-300, which isn't a real issue - so in two minds, as Ive only a few weeks to make my decision before having to commit.Thx all

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: Probably not because the lower frequency spectrum is covered by our bass guy anyway, so I don't play much there. If I have to because it’s a piano only intro or something I would probably do an octave shift on the 76key to play the lower bass part the piano soundin case I would have a 76HP(which will never happen)

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: In my opinion, it's you who'd have to know about kilos and key ranges for your settings.You should take Schorsch's hint seriously: It's not the same keybed if you are talking about Stage 3-HP76 and HA88. There is a considerable difference - where the HP76 is optimized towards weight and the 88HA towards a 'synthable' light hammer action.And take into account that you were talking about splits: The Stage has only 2 splitpoints per octave, so you always need a little key range to set up a KB zone. I think, on the HP76 and the HA88 you have a different number of split points, too (not sure, though).As far as I'm concerned, I'm perfectly fine with my NS3C (73 waterfall keys) using a piano MIDI keyboard for piano sounds (and not needing the 88 keys for that, too).

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: You cannot say "better live keyboard" as a general rule, since it depends on many different things.The Nords are best if you want to have all sorts of controls at hand without the need to dive into menu layers. Fantom might be "better" if changing controls/adjusting sounds in a live situation is not needed that much but you need other features like multi-layer samples of natural instuments, more parts, integrated sequencer etc. - very different concepts between those two (or in general between Nords and the ususal workstation suspects)I for one do not need all these additional functions anymore which a workstation like the Fantom or also the Montage / Kronos / .....  provides, for the band I'm playing I need a good sounding B3 organ with direct access to the controls, great piano sounds and the ablity to add pads and some synth sounds which I can shape to my needs whenever I want on stage, hence the Nord Stage is the perfect keyboardfor me.Long story short - it's you alone who can answer your question. I suggest you go and test both a Nord and a Frantom in light of the music you will play live and, much more important,howyou will play live, then decide if the one or the other suits your needs best (or maybe none of them ...)Edit: I understand from your other thread that you have already purchased a Nord Stage 3 76HP, are you able to return it for another one like the NS3 88, or isn't it a bit too late otherwise to ask these questions?

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: To me its not so much about the octaves, if the ns3-compact(organ) key had been avaliabel in an 88 key version I would had taken that, because of the split keyboard options.To me a Piano-keybed is like drivningar car whithout power-steering, too heavy.

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: Maybe it’s about reliability, usability. Confidence that you can sort out the situation, do the job.About responsiveness and expressiveness.Combine this with the best sounds and you have a Musical Instrument.And Nord Stage 3 is a candidate.Nord Stage 3 can seem boring compared to a workstation just like a real piano can seem boring compared to a synthesizer.I think it’s very difficult to master a workstation like Kronos and then the same confidence in the instrument cannot be achieved.To make a short story shorter, I agree with by Schorsch and the other ones in for example Nord Stage Forum / Stage 3 Rivals, that suggests and defends NS3.

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: For what is worth, I've been playing an 88-key stage piano since, well, forever. In the last 8 years, that 88-key has been the Nord Stage 2 (first the original, then the EX).But more and more, I was realizing that it was probably too much and I was sticking with the 88 keys purely out of habit, being a trained pianist.For my jazz band, where I only play piano, I don't need all the extra functionalities of the Stage.For my cover bands, where I play all sorts of sounds, I don't need the 88 keys.In any and all situations, I was getting tired of lugging a big stage piano up and downstairs, on cramped stages in small venues, etc.So, for the jazz band I got a Yamaha P-121: decent acoustic pianos (the only sounds I use there), onboard speakers, 10 kilos, 73 keys of Yamaha GH hammer action, surely not the best around, but not the worst for sure (I actually like it a bit more than the FATAR TP/40 in the Stage).And now I just substituted my NS2 88 with the Compact version: 100% of the sonic power in only 80% of the size and 50% of the weight. The VERY rare occasions when I miss the extra keys are when I had programs with complex splits and layers which used the whole keyboard. But I just had to reprogram those patches (making new custom-mapped samples in a couple of occasions) and that was it, I really didn't lose anything from the performance side.Of course the piano sounds are less enjoyable on the SW action, but for comping behind a band it's more than good enough. When I REALLY need, I can always bring along the P-121 to have an extra set of weighted keys, and the two instruments together weigh barely more than the NS2 HA88 by itself.In the studio, I don't miss the weighted keys because I play the Nord pianos in the Compact via MIDI, from my Kawai CN-27 with the excellent RH-III action (the same as the Nord Grand).So, for the first time in my whole life, I'm without a 88-key piano for gigging. Does it feel weird? Of course.Does it make my performance worse in any way? Not at all.

title: RE: Does anyone miss the extra octave between 76 and 88?
post_content: Being a classical trained pianist too it still feels uncomfortable to me to play piano sounds from the NS3C keybed, missing the haptics of fully weighted keys. I however agree in that carrying around both the NS3C and the NS3 88 is quite an effort to bearIt is and remains a question of personal preference

title: New sound sets on Nord website

title: Newbie question about cross-Nord compatibility
post_content: I see different people selling cover song patches for the Stage 3, and they also have the same or similar library offered for the Piano or Electro or Wave 2.I have a NP4. NS3C and soon a NW2, so will be figuring out my workflow and I’ll have 3 keyboards, all of which have sample memory.I asked one of the patch companies and they told me there were separate libraries for each device, but is there a way in principle to build something for the Stage 3 and relatively easily port it to the Wave 2 for example if it’s sample-based? Understand if it’s a licensing issue why I couldn’t copy but I’m also looking at sampling some rack gear and it would be great if the programs could be easily used on multiple boards without too much work.

title: RE: Newbie question about cross-Nord compatibility
post_content: MarkJames wrote:...I asked one of the patch companies and they told me there were separate libraries for each device, but is there a way in principle to build something for the Stage 3 and relatively easily port it to the Wave 2 for example if it’s sample-based? Understand if it’s a licensing issue why I couldn’t copy but I’m also looking at sampling some rack gear and it would be great if the programs could be easily used on multiple boards without too much work.Hello. Any samples provided for the Nord Stage 3 can directly be used with the NW2, however I anticipate that you would then have to set up the synth and effects parameters to get your NW2 program to sound close to the NS3 program (absent any piano or organ that might also be in the NS3 patch). The NS3 file viewer available from Forum member Florence can provide the settings for any NS3 program loaded. No need to purchase two separate libraries if you want to try that approach - you'll learn a lot about both keyboards quickly as well.Regarding sampling, at least in the U.S., you can sample anything you want for personal use, however it's potentially illegal when you start offering it to others. I'm not an attorney, but I anticipate the line is drawn between whether they are samples of sounds you personally created from the other keyboards, or samples of programs that came with the keyboards (someone else's program/intellectual property). Take care.

title: RE: Newbie question about cross-Nord compatibility
post_content: As the synth engines are different between the NS3 and NW2, some settings may not directly be applicable, but you should be able to get close. The effects and Piano settings (for the NP) will be covered well. I would suggest before buying anything, that you search this Forum and the Nord User Sounds websites, as a lot of what you're looking for might already be posted for free. Good luck!

title: RE: Live Mode  Song Modus
post_content: mellotronix wrote:Hello everyone, if I jump from Live mode to Song mode and back again, then not the last sound played, but the first one is activated again. How can I prevent that or what am I doing wrong? Many thanks for your help.Hello and welcome to the Forum! It sounds like you are selecting Live mode and then selecting Song mode again, which will always start at the first song in that bank.  If you select Live mode, and then hit the Live mode button again to exit, you will return to your selected song. Take care.

title: My Pianos and Program List
post_content: I hope all of you are doing well.  I've posted quite a few programs and from time to time I'll be asked what piano I used when someone's downloaded a program and a piano wasn't found. On future posts I'll note that information or reference this post.  When I first got my Stage 3, I replaced all the XL pianos with smaller versions and then added others to have a wider selection available to me. In a live band setting the additional quality of the fully-mapped keyboard of the XL is lost, so I opted for quantity and variety. Most piano samples I use are Large, however for a few pianos I rarely use, I went a little smaller rather than get rid of them.  Attached is the current list for my Piano section with 45 available Grands, Uprights, EPianos and others, along with the list of programs I have posted with the related pianos/samples. I hope some of you find it helpful. I recently did the oposite: kept 4 XL grands, 4 XL uprights and the some bread and butter.Thanks in advanceNeo

title: RE: My Pianos and Program List
post_content: neomad wrote:Hello, first at all, thanks for the huge work that you do for the community. I started a few years back with your programs, so I am glad to highlight a bigSecondly, I would like you to elaborate a little bit more about that:WannitBBBad wrote:In a live band setting the additional quality of the fully-mapped keyboard of the XL is lost, so I opted for quantity and variety. Most piano samples I use are Large, however for a few pianos I rarely use, I went a little smaller rather than get rid of them.Nord Stage 3 Piano List.pdfNord Stage 3 Programs Posted.pdfWhy do you think that the XL advantages are lost in a live band situation? I recently did the oposite: kept 4 XL grands, 4 XL uprights and the some bread and butter.Thanks in advanceNeoYou're welcome, I appreciate the thanks for my work. To your question, in my opinion the XL is excellent for recording and instances where the piano is the central or only instrument in a live performance, but in a band environment where many consider themselves fortunate that the person in front got the mix right, I think the nuances of having a fully-mapped keyboard are lost. Similarly, if I was in the audience with a band playing, really wouldn't be able to determine if the keyboard player was using a Large sample with full-range string resonance or a Medium sample with string resonance in the middle only. With the XL we're using valuable sample memory for a fully-mapped 88 key sample when we might be playing a 73 or 76 key Nord to start with. If you think about what you play, you might use the outer regions of your keyboard for different parts, but how often for the outer low or high notes of an 88-key piano? There's no right or wrong approach. I opted to have a wider range of pianos immediately available to me, and even though I've found that I have my "favorites" and rarely if ever use a few others, I haven't been driven yet to remove some to install the XL versions again. The Nord site provides more information on the differences athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... nformation. Thanks, take care.

title: Queen One Vision Arpeggiator - Half Step Down - Need Help!
post_content: Hey there fellow Nordsters!I have a little problem...I got myself the great "Essential Covers" Bundle from narfsounds for my Stage 3, mainly for the Queen presets on it as I currently play in a Queen tribute band.Now the dilemma: the band plays a tuned down, a half-step to be precise. Now the preset for the song "One Vision" contains one sample which features a sampled arpeggio as well as a String swell.What is the easiest method to bring that down half a step so I can use the whole sound with the band? I doubt that the stage 3 can do that internally...Best regards!EDIT: I do have the Nord Sample Editor, is there an easy way to use i for that purpose?

title: RE: Queen One Vision Arpeggiator - Half Step Down - Need Help!
post_content: Hello, welcome to the Forum! To address the problem I would record a WAV file of the notes with the Arpegiator and string swell using Audacity (or other recorder/editor software). Load your sample into an empty program so all synth parameters are at their default and all effects are off; you want the sample you create to be in the same raw format as the original (granted the original will be playing through the HP12 filter). Play all the notes you need sampled starting from the bottom and leaving a clean break between notes. Once your WAV file is created (save the original), change the pitch of the notes in the WAV file you need altered and save it under a new name for importing into the Nord Sample Editor.  If you use Audacity, make sure the lower left box is checked to use high quality stretching (see pic). The tricky part of putting together a sample meant to be transposed is with split points, understanding that transposing the Nord down a half step means that the sample you create will have all notes shifted UP a half step (whatever is on B will play on the C note for example). Addressing the split point(s): If the two sounds have a split point set at C3, you'll want the range of your lower sample to end at Bb2 and the range of the upper sample to start at B2.  When you transpose down a half step on the Stage 3, the sample will shift UP a half step so that upper sample will start at C3. Make sense?  Good luck to you!Audacity - Change Pitch.jpg (35.97 KiB) Viewed 1273 times

Hope all of you are well, take care.The first program has splits that overlap and has organ on the bottom split for the start of the chorus where you have the option of switching to program 2. title: Dancing in the Street Van Halen
post_content: I just got my first Nord (S3) a week ago and I love it.  I want to give a huge "thank you" all the programmers who donate their patches.  I'm a rookie at this, and this is my attempt at making a patch for Dancing in the Street by Van Halen.  I thought I'd share it with everyone.  I've got the delays set at 120 BPM with dotted eight notes, so all you need to do is play some blue notes along with the chord structure - I never played more than 4 notes at a time - mostly 2 or 3 notes. title: 4 Programs for "Africa" by Toto
post_content: I've always loved this song so bit the bullet and programmed the following starting from a post by Buisbird and Africa_split sample by rudiratlos (Thank you!).  I haven't ever played this out but learned a few parts for the demo mp3s below. I hope you like these - take care.Sounds needed:  Marimba in Piano Section, Africa_split.nsmp3 sample, Flute Sample for Solo, White Grand (or link one you like). Marimba available at the Nord site:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... us/marimbaProgram "Toto Africa p1 W": This program is used for the Intro, First Verse and End, with synth brass/marimba on left and Africa_split sample/marimba on right.  The filter for the brass is morphed to both the Mod Wheel and Aftertouch - the MW allows for nice adjustment if you want the sound a little brighter and AT is used at the end of the verse (listen to end of mp3). The Marimba in the piano section is used for both slots, and the delay effect is set at a tight slapback to sound like multiple players. The sample and Marimbas are morphed to the control pedal to pull them out of the mix during the verse. For those of you limited on sample space, I've added a second program "Toto Africa p1bW" using the Kalimbas that are pre-loaded in the Stage 3 - the high end could be tweaked a little.Toto Africa Intro and First Verse.mp3Toto Africa p1 W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Intro using "Africa_split.nsmp3" sample(592 Bytes) Downloaded 1225 timesafrica_split.nsmp3Sample with synth and kalimbas for "Africa" by Toto(2.17 MiB) Downloaded 933 timesToto Africa p1bW.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Intro using Nord Kalimba sample(592 Bytes) Downloaded 1007 timesProgram "Toto Africa p3 W": This program is used for the 2nd verse where brass is on the left and mono synth is on the right. The White Grand is blended in a little for the 2nd verse as well.Toto Africa 2nd Verse with mono synth.mp3Toto Africa p3 W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Used for second verse with brass left (marimbas on control pedal) and solo synth right(592 Bytes) Downloaded 904 timesProgram "Toto AfricaSoloW": This program uses the Flute sample with OSC2 added with a synth Sine wave, and Marimbas from the piano section added using the Control Pedal.  I found it easier to duplicate the sounds and set up a split for left and right hands.  The delay effect is set at a tighter slapback than the intro but not as heavy so it wouldn't sound like sloppy playingFor those of you who would prefer to play the part with your hands overlapping in the same split so you could set up another part on the keyboard as well, I also have "Toto AfricaSol2W" posted that also uses the Africa sample. I really like the Flute sample (sounds great on "Can't You See" by Marshall Tucker too) but you can try others already preloaded in the Stage 3 if you lack the space.Toto Africa Solo.mp3Toto AfricaSoloW.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Solo with Marimba/Flute - left and right hands on separate splits(592 Bytes) Downloaded 927 timesFlute.nsmp3Flute sample - Africa - Can't You See - others(4.89 MiB) Downloaded 782 timesToto AfricaSol2W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Solo with Marimba/Flute - left and right hands together(592 Bytes) Downloaded 880 timesProgram "Toto Africa Ch W": This program is used for the chorus. The MP3 is of the ending chorus where I used the Control Pedal to bring in more piano, second synth, and slight B3 - you can mix those to your taste.Toto Africa Chorus.mp3Toto Africa Ch W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "Africa" by Toto - Chorus - Piano, 2nd synth, and B3 on Control Pedal(592 Bytes) Downloaded 900 timesMy post covering 100+ Programsnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Help In Locating A Sound
post_content: Hi peterg3986,are you new to the Stage 3?I don't know what video you are talking about. But what you spotted will probably have been a program, not a piano (sample). And it will probably not have been preloaded, but custom made. But you are a lucky one: There is a Micheal Bereal Sound Bank to download at Nord, and it contains a program labeled BIZZ CHRCH ATTCK. Which may be what you were looking for:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... sound-bankBesides, the Stage 3 is a beast easy to program, so you will often find custom made programs that you can get nowhere else. You will learn to do it on your own within a few months.

title: RE: Expression pedal
post_content: Hi, you should read the "Morph" paragraph of the NS3 manual to learn how to map the CtrlPedal to NS3 parameters, on each Program.If instead you want to use it as a Swell or Volume pedal (depending on System Settings), you should connect it to the SwellPedal input.

title: RE: Expression pedal
post_content: Maybe maxpiano's  answer is dedicated to a Nord Stage 3 while you have an Electro 3. I think, there is no morph functionality on an Electro 3. Just read p. 7 in the Electro 3 manual to see what you have to do: Connect your pedal into the control pedal jack and set the system menu.

title: RE: Expression pedal
post_content: Page 7 of the manual explains this.https://www.nordkeyboards.com/downloads/nord-electro-3The pedal can be used as a swell pedal for the organs, a volume pedal for pianos and samples and also as a controller for two of the effects: the P-wah and the ring modulator (RM)
