title: Classic Rock and other programs - Set 1
post_content: I just purchased a Nord Stage 3 and working quickly to recreate all the patches I had on my Stage 2 before selling it. Most of the classic programs are fairly simple, but I thought some of you might appreciate saving a little time with something to start with and tweak. Note that most of my programs use the control pedal morph even if only to bring instruments in and out of a mix.With some of these programs you may need to relink the piano(s) to what you have in your Stage 3, as one of the first things I did when I got my Stage 3 was replace some pianos with smaller files to add more - I have 48 at this time.All sample locations below 250 are pre-loaded Stage 3 locations that I don't mess with.  Even if I delete samples from the stock collection to add space, I keep those sample locations open and load new samples in locations 250 and above. The programs below use all the "stock" samples except for the James Taylor song which uses "SynthPad2__CL stereo 3.0" in location 252.It doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store new samples in your Nord Stage 3, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load "SynthPad2__CL stereo 3.0" into your sample location 280 (252 in mine), then you just need to point Slot B to 280 rather than 252.I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.I found the program for the 10cc song "I'm Not In Love" on this site for the Stage 2.  I recreated it for the Stage 3:10 cc on Mod   W.ns3fProgram - 10cc I'm Not in Love(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1038 times10 cc on Mod   W.mp3A little Jimmy Buffett:JB MargaritaVilW.ns3fProgram - Jimmy Buffett Margaritaville by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 605 timesJB MargaritaVilW - Jimmy Buffett - Margaritaville.mp3John Mellencamp - Check It Out. Accordion and violin on right hand, harpsicord on left to emulate autoharp:JM CheckItOut  W.ns3fProgram - John Mellencamp - Check It Out by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 564 timesJM CheckItOut  W - John Mellenkamp - Check It Out.mp3James Taylor - Everyday. Left hand has the soft pad, the low note at the beginning is the right hand with the Rhodes. Top split set aside for the Ballad EP2.  As noted above, this program uses a sample I loaded in slot 252 - I will follow up with a post right after this with "SynthPad2__CL stereo 3.0":JTEveryDay MK1 W.ns3fProgram - James Taylor - Everyday by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 535 timesJTEveryDay MK1 W - James Taylor - Everyday.mp3Procol Harum - A Whiter Shade of Pale. Hammonds on split keyboard with reverb. I originally set up this program heavier in effects and a little "darker" to sound closer to the original, but found it wasn't cutting through quite enough in a live setting. This is what I ended up with and I let the room do the rest.Update:After downloading, set the 2nd harmonic touch percussion on slow for the right hand and try starting out with the Leslie in stop mode, but set up a very slow Chorus 1 on the B3 to add a little "motion" to the sound but not too much.  Some set the upper manual at 68860.. and lower manual at 00443 if you want tp try that as well.WhiterShadePaleW.ns3fProgram - Procol Harum - A Whiter Shade of Pale(592 Bytes) Downloaded 515 timesWhiterShadePaleW.mp3Styx - Renegade. title: RE: Whitney Houston- How Will I Know
post_content: Completely awesome song, love it!Quite tricky / a lot of sampling work on the Nord, though - if you want to get very close to the soundWhat I tried in MainStage with Dexed + TAL J-8:The main rhodes-like and guitar-like stabs are most likely played on a DX7, the Synth Strings pad in the chorus could also be DX7, but also could be a Jupiter-8The bass sound could be a MiniMoog, but can also be recreated with a Jupiter-8 for exampleBass sound: try "LadderBass", which should already be included in your Stage 3's sample lib, and adjust the filterFor the stabs, I've used the following in MainStage and plugins:layer1: Dexed and "Rippedroas" patch, which sounds similar to the "FullTines" but has a softer, more resonant attack + Chorus FX!layer2: Dexed 12String DX7 patch + Chorus FXlayer3 (Chorus only): TAL J-8 2 Saw oscillators, detuned by 12semis, and loads loads of Chorus FXconclusio: for the main sounds (right hand), you should be fine with "DX Full Tines" in the Piano section + a detune Saw +12 in the Synth

title: RE: Whitney Houston- How Will I Know
post_content: Such a beautiful voice and taken far too soon.  I'm glad to contribute this so hopefully more folks will also choose to cover it with their band.  The first program uses the DX7 synth sample that comes with the Stage 3 and has the synth special effect on the other panel. The second (main) program covers the synth bass with vibrato on AT and DX7/Strings. The third program has the softer DX7/bell sound with the synth bass on the other panel.  The approach to the programs would be a little different if I wasn't using the 2nd synth panel for the synth bass, but I like the effect in the song. If you're playing with a bass player and together the lows are too overpowering, trimming off the bass in the panel EQ might be a better option than turning down the synth Level so you keep the effect.  Take careWH HowWillKnow1W.ns3fStage 3 Program for Intro to "How Will I Know" by Whitney Houston using DX7 Sample(592 Bytes) Downloaded 295 timesWH HowWillKnow W.ns3fStage 3 Program for "How Will I Know" by Whitney Houston(592 Bytes) Downloaded 277 timesWH HowWillKnow3W.ns3fStage 3 Program #3 with synth bass and DX7/Bell on right for "How Will I Know" by Whitney Houston(592 Bytes) Downloaded 269 timesThis example covers the three programs including two different ways of using the 3rd program if you have a bass player.WH HowWillKnow W 3 Programs.mp3This example covers just the main (second) program "WH HowWillKnow W.ns3f"that can be used on its own if you don't want/need the effect with the intro program. The program is set up for the Control Pedal to increase the LEVEL and FREQ of the strings and back off the DX7 Piano. The DX7 can be backed all the way out with the Mod Wheel.  For the solo and ending key change, I turn on the B3 to add a little low end to the strings to fatten them up.WH How Will I Know W Program2.mp380+ Programs/MP3 examples for Stage 3LINK->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

post_content: Is the “latch” the same as a Sostenuto? Or what is it?

title: RE: Comfortably NUMB (Pink Floyd) - Refrain & Chorus wanted
post_content: In the NS2 documentation the Triple Pedal description says:The middle Nord Triple Pedal is the Sostenuto/Latch pedal.So I guess yes latch is the same as Sostenuto...What is missing on the NS3:Latch Ped & KB GateThe Latch Pedal feature allows you to latch arpeggios in the synth, sustain chords or individual notes on selected instruments by operating a pedal, without affecting other instruments or the functionality of the sustain pedal. The Latch is activated for the individual instruments by holding Shift and pressing the right Octave (Latch Ped) button; the On LED lights up. This behaves like the sostenuto functionality on a grand piano; only the keys that are pressed down when the pedal is activated will sustain.If you use a Nord Triple Pedal, the center pedal on that unit will be the designated latch pedal. A standard sustain pedal connected to the Ro- tor/Latch input can also be used. If you use the Rotor/Latch input, you need to change a setting in the System Menu, read more about this on “Rotor/Latch Pedal Func” on page 42.The KBGATE feature allows you to disable an instrument from being triggered by the keyboard, for as long as the latch pedal is operated.

title: Loverboy's "Turn Me Loose" with Chromatic Intro
post_content: "Turn Me Loose" by Loverboy came on the radio the other day and it dawned on me how to cover the stepped chromatic intro with the synth section of the Stage 3. Using only OSC2 with a sawtooth waveform, I set it at 24 semitones initially so that a complete turn during performance would take it to 48 semitones (and no further) for the rest of the song.  The effect is similar to the SC Prophet 5 where the OSC Frequency also moved in steps when the knob was turned.  The main synth is played with the left hand, a CP80 with Chorus is set up for the right hand, and a synth with Legato is set up for the break in the middle at the top split.  Wishing all of you a Happy New Year, take care.Turn Me Loose  W.ns3fNord Stage 3 Program for Turn Me Loose by Loverboy(592 Bytes) Downloaded 336 timesStage 3 - Loverboy Turn Me Loose.mp3Version 2 added December 31, 2020 with an updated Legato synth and other minor tweaks including a little less brightness in the intro synth (easy to add a little back in with FREQ and/or EQ). Take care.Turn Me Loose2 W.ns3fNord Stage 3 Program Version 2 for Turn Me Loose by Loverboy(592 Bytes) Downloaded 353 timesStage 3 - Loverboy Turn Me Loose v2.mp370+ Programs - For those new to programming...nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Whats your go to Cold Chisel piano sound
post_content: Though he uses different piano sounds depending on the song, ones that sound a little detuned I believe are Uprights. Many in the Forum like the Amber Upright in general, but for the sound you are looking for, I would try using the BlueSwede Large Upright (https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... de-upright) perhaps with the bright setting. Depending on what you like, you might not need much Chorus, but I wouldn't suggest using Detune between the two panels, that's a bit too much. I hope that helps, take care.

title: RE: Saving programs panel A and B
post_content: I don't know how you can configure your Triton, but can you assign different channels on the triton?I guess this is not how the Triton works, as well...When you select this program on your Nord, afaik, both Extern program commands are sent at the same time, in your case on Ch1.Seemingly, it only opens the one Piano preset on your Triton.Don't know what the Triton can do, but for your task, you will need to somehow activate both Strings and Piano in one patch on the Triton, maybe with a split or a layer and assign different MIDI channels to each sound if that's possible?Then you will need to set the Nord's External MIDI Ch to those same two MIDI Outs

title: RE: Saving programs panel A and B

title: RE: Saving programs panel A and B
post_content: I also would suggest that you use different midi channels on A and B, and at the Korg corresponding.The Triton is most likely multi-timbral (haven't read the specs).

title: RE: Saving programs panel A and B
post_content: Yes, what Martin says.I'm not familiar with the particular VST, but most play only one sound for each midi channel (unless you can do splits on incoming midi).So the two extern A and B should almost certainly be on different MIDI channels for this to work - and certainly when you send program change messages.Also, it sounds like you use a zone for each extern on your nord? Then you very likely need to use the octave shift buttons in one or both zones (in the extern panel) too in order to shift the range to where your VST expects it.Sent from my phone in brevity

title: Need this Synthpad Sound for NS3
post_content: Hey dear community im new herecan someone help me to create this synth pad sound ? (Not the Square Lead).Or can someone create it?? i need this Pad / Strings so muchIm using the Nord Stage 3first-auido-mixdown-lonely-boy-mh_WsYhZfqH.mp3

title: RE: Need this Synthpad Sound for NS3
post_content: First of all, welcome the Forum and congratulations on your new Nord Stage 3!You could use the S-Wave mode (SuperWave) and try out SuperSaw, SuperStrings or SuperOrgan - then you’ll need to experiment with the filter - I’d say Resonance around 10-11 o’clock

title: RE: Need this Synthpad Sound for NS3
post_content: Try a super saw wave with long attack, long decay, full sustain and some release in the amp envelope. Set a low pass filter somewhere over the middle and a sine or triangle LFO affecting the filter in a very slow rate and low level, just for some motion. I would also add a good amount of reverb and some stereo delay to make the motion more interesting. I'm sure You will come prety close if you play around with those parametres.Another option instead of setting the LFO opening and closing the filter, is to assign it to the Mod Wheel or Pedal so that you can control the motion yourself.

title: RE: Need this Synthpad Sound for NS3

I've made a short YouTube video to demonstrate, as these are sounds built into some Programs with other elements, including use of the control pedal for morphing volume and/or filter frequency.Hope this helps!Eric

title: "Babe" by Styx - free to a good home
post_content: Hi everyone, I hope all of you are doing well.  Below are two programs I put together for "Babe" by Styx.  The Rhodes EP1 (Version 6) has the Dyno filter set and EQ'd to bring out the tines even more with the midrange boosted at 5K Hz and treble flat.  I have the same piano mapped on the lower/mid range for Slot A and upper split for Slot B as I set up program 1 so I can bring in the strings and mono synth on the upper split with the Control Pedal and while simultaneously taking out the upper Slot B Rhodes. If you listen closely to the actual song, it sounds like the upper D note on the Rhodes has more of a tine sound than some others since they are individually voiced, and the lower notes especially don't have quite as much, so you may want to trim off the mid and treble a little on the Rhodes for Slot A if it's too much after listening to it through your rig, but try it first - some really like the distinctive sound so I biased it that way. I hope some of you can make use of this. Take care.Note: If you don't play live with your Stage 3 in stereo, you'll lose the stereo panning effect that's part of the original sound, so you may need to play around with the Phase Shifter a little more or use the Chorus effect.The mp3 covers:a) Program 1 - the intro with the Control Pedal down so you hear the upper range of the Rhodes,b) Program 1 - the Control Pedal up to take out the upper Rhodes and bring in the Strings on lower split and Mono synth on the upper split,c) Program 2 - Rhodes, B3 and stock Stage 3 voice sample in mono, played during the guitar solo making sure the highest note is hit last so the voice on the highest note comes out while the chord is being played, andd) Program 2 - an alternative for the guitar solo part with the Rhodes, B3, and voices on the left hand and another mono synth on the right hand (arpeggiator used to make it easy, but can be turned off).  I don't know the actual part being played but just threw in something in for the demo.Stage 3 - Styx - Babe Programs.mp3Styx Babe 1    W.ns3fStage 3 Program #1 for "Babe" by Styx played for intro with Control Pedal down and during main song bringing in Strings and mono synth with the Control Pedal when needed.(592 Bytes) Downloaded 366 timesStyx Babe 2    W.ns3fStage 3 Program #2 for "Babe" by Styx played during the guitar solo(592 Bytes) Downloaded 341 timesPrograms, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Centerfold J. Geils Band
post_content: Jethro wrote:2021-03-18 1133.m4aThanks for the reply, I think ive uploaded the file ok??   Cheers for the helpHello, you're definitely getting there. I have a few suggestions that hopefully will help get it where you want it.  Listening to the original I hear a faint note playing an octave lower than what I consider to be the primary note; there isn't a distinct character to the tone, so for the sample I'd suggest adding a sine wave to OSC2, setting it an octave lower than the sax and slightly blending it in.  It sounds like you might already be capturing the other sound an octave higher than the sax with the sawtooth, but another option (if not already programmed this way) is to set the sawtooth OSC1 at the same octave as the Sax sample and use a sawtooth for OSC2 set an octave higher and blend the two.  It sounds like you recorded the sound off a speaker where I'm also hearing perhaps the keys being played, but I'm hearing more initial attack (like a piano) than the sound on the original.  I would suggest setting the filter and amp attack slightly above zero on the sounds used (sawtooth especially) and setting the release about 9-10 o'clock.  Here's an example of an analog brass program that has settings that you could play around with. Good luck.AnalogBrass    W.ns3fStage 3 Analog Brass Program(592 Bytes) Downloaded 122 times

title: RE: NEW TO NORD - A COUPLE NEWBIE QUESTIONS??
post_content: I'm glad you have a new Nordgreat choice! And welcome to the forum.1. So, NS3 has 2 GB of piano and 480MB of synth memory. If you want to put new sounds on, you obviously must have enough memory equivalent to the size of that particular sounds. Nord sound manager has a feature where you can select to see all the sounds that are unused (when I say unused, I mean sounds that are not being used by any progam). I would suggest that you delete them first (those you don't like), that will probably make some memory already. If that's not enough, deleting sound that is being used in any program/s will change that programs. So if you like some programs with sounds you don't like, try to avoid deleting them.2. You can't upload mp3 directly to the board, but you can use sample manager to sample it to your board.3. As much as I know, you can use Nord sound manager and whatever sound you click on, you will be able to play it instantly on a board. I think there is no such player that can do that for Nord (but not sure about that one).You should be able to edit factory sounds, but not that you can change them permanently like a sound, rather you can tweak their parameters in order to achieve your desired type of sound and save it per program. Then you can copy panels to make it easier for you to use that sound again.I don't own Nord yet, but I love it and it's my dream, so I have a lot of research behind me for NS3, that's where my info comes from. I hope I said everything correctly.I hope I helped somehow

title: RE: NEW TO NORD - A COUPLE NEWBIE QUESTIONS??
post_content: Hi and welcome here!First of all I would like to clarify one fundamental question to answer your 1st question - what do you mean by “sound”?I’m asking because this is not a unique term and could mean two different things on the Nord:a) a sampleSamples are used in the piano section and in the synth section. Both sections have their own amount of available memory to hold samples, for pianos the space is 2GB, for synth  samples it is 480MB and they are totally separated from each other, you also cannot make use of some free space in the synth section to store a piano sample there and vice versa. Also the samples for the piano section are provided by Nord exclusively, those cannot be created by users. Samples for the synth section can be loaded both from Nord but also from others, like you will find massively here in the forum - those samples are either .nsmp or .nsmp3 files.If you mean samples when talking about sounds, and you want to add some more to the Nord you need to check if the respective memory section has enough free space to load additional samples, otherwise need to delete some which you don’t need. Deleting a sample affects all programs (see following item b) which make use of this sample. Best way is to delete the program first which you don’t need, and then see if Nord Sound Manager marks the sample as “unused”, which means that no other program makes use of it and you can then delete it.b) a programThis holds all information which is needed to play a certain sound, it contains for example the organ settings, the specific piano sample and all related settings, the synth settings or synth samples which are needed, all effects settings etc. - this combines a whole bunch of different settings. Programs do not have any effect on memory usage, there are 400 programs which can be used, deleting programs does not have an effect on memory.For question 2: the MP3 files are provided here to be able to listen to the sound of a specific sample, but MP3 files cannot loaded into the Nord Stage. It makes use of .nsmp3 samples which are loaded on the Stage by using Nord Sound Manager, this software is also able to convert the (older) .nsmp format into the .nsmp3 format when uploading them to the Stage.For question 3: the answer is “no” - you can listen to .nsmp or .nsmp3 samples only if you load them onto the Nord, create a program which makes use of the sample and then play. That’s the reason why people usually provide MP3 files with an example of how the sample will sound (see above)For your last question: yes absolutely, you can edit factory program and change every single bit of it, you just have to make sure to switch memory protection off in the general settings to be able to save what you have changedHope it helps a bit - I recommend to listen to some tutorials which are available on YouTube, one very good channel is “My Keys To Music” atand also this one:and read the manual

title: RE: NEW TO NORD - A COUPLE NEWBIE QUESTIONS??
post_content: Hello and welcome to the Forum! Below are a few tips that might come in handy for freeing up sample memory using the Nord Sound Manager:- View your current samples in "organize" mode to show open memory locations.- Sort samples from largest to smallest and delete the ones you don't want starting with the largest so you're freeing up the most space without losing as many samples.- Save all new samples to memory locations 250 and above so you can keep track of what samples you added versus the ones (0-249) that came with the Stage 3.Regarding the Piano memory, when I first got my Stage 3 I replaced all the XL pianos with smaller versions and then added others to have a wider selection available to me. In a live band setting the additional quality of the fully-mapped keyboard of the XL is lost, so I opted for quantity and variety. The current list for my Piano section with 45 available Grands, Uprights, EPianos and others is at the following post if you are interested.  Good luck to you!LINK ->post130083.html

title: RE: NEW TO NORD - A COUPLE NEWBIE QUESTIONS??
post_content: A brief overview of the different file formats used by the Nord Stage 3 that I wrote up a while ago:Nord Stage 3 file formats.nsmp/.nsmp3 files are the raw sample format. They can be used by a synth engine set to “sample” mode. The .nsmp3 format includes support for default parameters like attack or release settings, as well as filter adjustments, that make them more useful immediately, without needing any setting-up. These files are copied onto the machine and can be used in a program or several programs, or not at all..npno files — same thing, but available only to the piano engine. Different sample format (including multiple velocity layers)..ns3f files are full Nord Stage 3 programs that go in the program section. They contain the settings for one organ, one piano, and one synth for each of the two layers — regardless of whether those engines are actually switched on in the program. Effects settings are also saved, of course. They DO NOT include the samples or piano files — merely information about which ones are used. These are machine-specific and can only be read by Nord Stage 3..ns3y files are synth presets that go in the synth section and can be stored as part of a program on the Stage. Again, specific to the Nord Stage 3..ns3fb is a bundle format that includes the program and any piano/sample files used. It’s just a .zip file with a different ending, so renaming it to “.zip” and unpacking it will alle you to see the samples and pianos, so you can transfer those, at least, to another incompatible machine, as these are, of course, specific to the Stage 3..ns3b is a full backup of the entire machine, including all pianos, all samples, all synth presets, and all programs. It, too, is just a .zip file with a different extension.

title: RE: missing support sounds when using shared programs
post_content: wayne2005_10 wrote:Now that I have found some cool programs, (thank you for shares), I load them in and find that the supporting sounds are missing, most likely the ones i have removed.Hi, if this happens it means that what you removed weren't Programs but actual sounds (pianos and/samples). OR, that the Programs you downloaded refer to pianos that weren't loaded in your memory to start with.Either way, you'll have to download them from the Library if you want them, and then upload them in the keyboard using the Sound Manager.A Program, in Nord language, doesn't "contain", in the strict sense, any sound. It just "points" at sounds (piano and samples) that must be actually uploaded in the machine for the Program to work. (Note that the organ engine is different in that it's fixed.)

title: RE: ALDO NOVA "FANTASY"
post_content: Guys, I don't have that specific clip to share, but the following process will open you up to a whole world of capturing samples from any audio you can play on a Windows PC, including any YouTube videos.  It does not take any special or advanced technical skills.1. Download Audacity and install it.https://www.audacityteam.org/2. Configure Audacity for Windows WASAPI loopback recording to digitally capture audio that is being played on your computer.  Make sure you select the correct "loopback" device for recording.https://manual.audacityteam.org/man/tut ... ndows.html3. Start recording in Audacity and play the video. You may have to try a couple of different "loopback" options before you select the correct one.4. Trim if you wish, export as a WAV file (File > Save Other > Export as WAV), then import into Nord Sample Editor.Good luck!

title: RE: Looking for this sound to stage3
post_content: Hi Rfilipe,with a Stage 3, you didn't buy a sound workstation: It's a Stage piano. Why would you want to make it play that?As you certainly will know, the synth sample engine on a Stage 3 only has one velocity layer, so you won't be able to have different sounds depending on the velocity. You may use your two panels, though, for morphing between two different sounds with the help of a pedal.As you already have that sound, you may record it and transfer it to the Nord Sample Editor. But only for one fixed velocity level. It will remain a compromise. Maybe people would use the Extern section of the Stage 3 and play sounds like that from the computer on stage.

title: RE: Looking for Drum Kit Sample Pack
post_content: Lumserei wrote:I have also been experimenting with drum samples for some time.Is there a trick to stop the open hihat when the closed hihat sounds, that would be very important for playing drum sounds live.Nope, the Nord samples are meant to be waveforms for a VA synth oscillator, not to transform it into a workstation/arranger like ROMpler with drumkits.Better use something external (hardware, app on a tablet or computer) for that, if your only keyboard is a Nord.

title: RE: Looking for Drum Kit Sample Pack
post_content: Lumserei wrote:I have also been experimenting with drum samples for some time.Is there a trick to stop the open hihat when the closed hihat sounds, that would be very important for playing drum sounds live.The only thing that comes to mind would require using both synths: one panel to cover the drum sounds that you want to be able to be simultaneously played, the other to cover samples in mono where playing one note (closed hi-hat) would cancel the other (open hi-hat).

title: RE: Looking for Drum Kit Sample Pack
post_content: For almost 16 years I always had a laptop with me on stage and since the NS 3 I enjoy it very much without it.  In the meantime, I have already tried using external tools to create corresponding note offs to the open HH from the note on of the closed HH, but that didn't work because the note on and off come from different sources. Then I thought to put toms and hihats monophonically in the middle split zone and the rest in another. But there is no split zone Hi and Low simultaneously, so everything above or below the Hihats remains monophonic, therefore not playable live.  Maybe it is possible to split the drum samples up and split the hihats down to be able to put them monophonic on panel B.

title: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Sorry guys for asking probably a newbie question, but... I attempted Loading programs from the Nord website. Never used the the site before for doing this other than updating the OS. I have always just used our forums for getting programs and samples. Now I downloaded the the White Grand Piano XL, deleted a handful of pianos that I don't use like the uprights. So once the down load was complete I thought I would find the White Grand on my Stage 3 and I'm off to the races to start playing it. To my surprise I cant find on the Nord Stage 3. Am I doing something wrong?

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: It sounds like you downloaded the White Grand to your PC, however you need to transfer it to your Stage 3 using the Nord Sound Manager. Let me know if I didn't understand correctly. Good luck.

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Whatever you download will have to be saved on your PC. It's the same with the Nord or our user website: always two steps until sounding.

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Sorry if I didn't explain myself that well. I did download to my PC and then put it on the sound manager. I managed to add to the white grand to some of the sounds that had the upright pianos on them before so when I deleted the uprights the program had no piano there. So that sounds nice but is there a way just to have the white grand on its own?

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Once you've got the White Grand on the Stage, disconnect the PC from the Stage. Dial in an empty program or use the Prog Init function ([Shift]+[Transpose]) to set up a fresh/empty program. Activate the piano engine on one of the panels and dial in the right piano.Maybe, it's worth having a closer look into the manual - it's definitely readable.

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Hi,if sound manager has loaded the white grand successfully to your stage 3 you can either move to an empty program slot or to one which you will not use anymore, then initialize this slot and select piano as the program type. You will do this with the program init button, either shift-transpose or shift-live mode depending on the revision of your stage 3. Then push the type button to select the grand category and select the white grand, this will give you a pure white grand program with default settings.Edit: fziegler was a bit faster ....

title: RE: Loading programs from the Nord website
post_content: Thank you so much for the help guys.

title: programs for nord stage 3
post_content: Greetings AllPlease excuse my ignorance, Ive just purchased a new NS3 and am wondering if which programs and samples are compatible with this keyboard?Do the programs work on all the nord keyboards, or  only work on the ones they were created on?Any advice would be greatly appreciated as Im struggling to find the right sounds for the cover songs I need to doThanksTim

title: RE: programs for nord stage 3
post_content: Regrettably, file types aren't listed in the manual. But as Nord instruments have their own philosophy , it's a good idea to have a look into the manual anyway. It's definitely readable.What you get from Nord, aren't programs (except from factory restore):*.npno is a Nord Piano Sample, only provided by Clavia Nord*.nsmp/nsmp3 is a Nord Synth Sample (2nd and 3rd generation - both usable via the Nord Sound Manager)Just look intohttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-librariesWhat you will get from 3rd party, are bundles, programs and the above synth samples:*.ns3pb is a Stage 3 program bundle (program + content)*.ns3p is a Stage 3 program*.ns3y is a Stage 3 synth preset which is always part of a program bundleNo other programs are readable for the Stage 3 as the programs directly refer to the features of the sound engines. Have a look intonord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files-f32/on this portal or the affiliatedhttps://nordusersounds.com/Have a nice start with your instrument!

title: RE: programs for nord stage 3
post_content: timkeys wrote:Greetings AllPlease excuse my ignorance, Ive just purchased a new NS3 and am wondering if which programs and samples are compatible with this keyboard?Do the programs work on all the nord keyboards, or  only work on the ones they were created on?Any advice would be greatly appreciated as Im struggling to find the right sounds for the cover songs I need to doThanksTimHi, nothing to excuse and no ignorance, this is a valid question.The quick answer is that programs work only on the keyboardgenerationthey have been made for, like for example Nord Stage 3 programs work on Nord Stage 3 only, Nord Stage 2 programs work for both Nord Stage 2 and Nord Stage 2EX.Samples can be shared if they are in .nsmp format, which will be converted by sound manager into the new .nsmp3 format for those keyboard working with the new format.

title: RE: programs for nord stage 3
post_content: Thanks very much for the replyVery helpfulCheers

title: RE: stage 3 rhodes program
post_content: kirbyjwilson wrote:If anyone has a modification / improvement to my Rhodes program, please post it, thanks!Wow, great program, kirbyjwilson. I did a mod to suit my personal taste/playing style: Drive reduced from 4.0 to ~1.8-2.0, Layer Detune at 1, and less Vibe effect (reduced from 10 to 3) I won't call these improvements, because sounds are whatever works.A couple of elements that I really appreciate in your program:1) When using a control pedal for Wah, the intensity effect can be varied, by the placement of the Mod Wheel, from slight to all the way (for full Wah).2) As with any Wah effect, set the Mod Wheel all the way up, and set the Control Pedal at any position for the desired amount of upper mid boost.

title: Wild Thing Ocarina

title: Duran Duran RIO
post_content: Hello allI have started from the excellent work of  stgermain in 2015 for Stage 2.My target was to have an arpeggio that could be used for all song ... but this was the main problem .... the intro has an arpeggio RANDOM but with UP tendency with a range E4--B7.Verse - Break and Chorus  follow chords sequence with a UP pattern of 1 octave (easy)...... SO ... i ve lopped all with a Jupiterish sound, and created 4 loop in the lower split to be used with 1 fingerB1--Intro (not looped .. it ends after 2 bar)C2--Verse -- 4 bars loopedD2-- Break pre chorus -- 2 bars loopedE2 -- Chorus -- 4 bars loopedFor the Brass/Pad sound I have used, In the upper split, a Stage2 default sample (A1 the prophet_NLA1) ... u can download here already converted for Stage3 or pick it from Nord website and convert yourself.Use the wheel to have a smooth/sharp sound to be used in the verse and chorusI ve attached also 2 MP31) Only arp and synth as in the program2) The same but adding some bass and drum in order to listen how it can works with a band playingAll the best and enjoyClaudioRio-Arp-mp3.mp3Rio-band-MP3.mp3

title: RE: Duran Duran RIO
post_content: Here are attached the 4 samples to repack the arpeggios loop in the nsmp formatNow i ve focused only on that -- synth A ... on next topic i will talk about synth B1) Set a lower split (F2 will be more than u need)2) Open sample editor3) Import in order the 4 samples and assign to a single key (be aware that each sample has NO range otherwise when u change key u will retrigg the previous sample)4) the order is : Intro-verse-break-chorus5)The assign order could be B1-C2-D2-E2  (its easy to have the intro out of the second octave since it will be used once... but feel free to have another layout)5) All the samples must be set as "unpitched"6) The "Intro" sample should be NOT looped since it plays once for 2 bars at the start of song and then no more ... but fell free to loop it for longer intro in a live contest7)The rest of samples must be looped8)Save and upload to stage29)Assign to Synth A on lower split and select KB HOLD if u want to play hand free (I DO .. cos i am lazy)Let me knowEnjoyClaudio

title: Jerry Garcia - Keepers Clav Wah Sound
post_content: Please refer to the link for the sound I'm trying to capture on my NS3 88 key:Loving this sound but it seems like my NS3 can't get anywhere close with that amazing distorted Wah effect.Speaking of Wah effects, are the suggested pedals that would really enhance this? I play a lot of jam band type music (Phish, etc.).Thanks!

title: RE: Jerry Garcia - Keepers Clav Wah Sound
post_content: Starting with my "Higher Ground" program atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15722.html, I would suggest using the Fender Twin Amp emulation with some distortion, and tweaking the EQ to cut through as this does. For the program I used the auto-wah affect and used the control pedal to change the filter range - that yielded the effect I wanted without giving me a foot cramp through the whole song. Using the control pedal on the regular wah effect works nicely too if you want more control over the rate, fast or slow, over the wah itself. I hope that helps. Take care.

title: RE: Jerry Garcia - Keepers Clav Wah Sound
post_content: That's a bad @ss jam you linked to -- thanks for that!

title: RE: Jerry Garcia - Keepers Clav Wah Sound
post_content: krupa809 wrote:Thanks so much. Really appreciate your response. Sorry for the amateur question but I'm a new NS3 owner. Can i do the pedal affect using an expression pedal or do I need to purchase a separate pedal? Note that I also have the sustain pedal that came along with it.Thank you,Good question. The Nord Stage 3 supports the following pedals for use as the Control Pedal: Fatar, Yamaha FC7, Roland EV-7, Roland EV-5, Korg EXP2 and Korg XVP10.  I have used the Yamaha FC7 for over 30 years and have only had one fail over that whole time (I believe a cable failure due to too many tugs and not enough care). Taking the time to learn how to morph various control parameters (level, freq, rate, etc) to the Control Pedal, Mod Wheel, and/or Aftertouch will open up all kinds of possibilities for what you can do with your Stage 3 - you'll love it.  In case you're interested, I have over 70 programs available at-->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlthat all use the Control Pedal in some way, even if just to vary the level of an instrument compared to another.  Good luck and take care.

title: Brass Section with longer fall time
post_content: Hi there,got my NS3 a couple of weeks ago and still trying to replace/ recreate the sounds of my previous gear.I found a decent Sample called "Brass Section Fall Sing" and I like this one very much but the fall time of that sound is a bit too short for my needs.Or in other words: I need the sound sustain a little bit longer before the tone drops.Is there a way to tweak it (by length) or do I need to find a completely new sample? If the latter, does someone own such a .wav and would make it available for the community?Searching this forum did not produce no results.Thanks for you support!Cheersverbalakrobat

title: RE: Brass Section with longer fall time
post_content: You could try blending it with another one that has longer duration. Maybe give the second a longer attack time if you like the attack of the first one to be more distinct.

title: RE: Brass Section with longer fall time
post_content: Hello, welcome to the Forum! Taking from the suggestion by alex78 until you find a sample more suitable, try assigning the delay effect to your sample for a single repeat with only the effect sounding (none of the original in the mix). Set the timing for however long you need the sound to play before the drop. Set the Amp Env Attack to fade in. Then find another sample for the other synth slot that doesn't drop and have it fade out as the other is fading in. This has a limited use, as the sound will play after you stop playing a note because of the delay effect. Morphing the levels between the two might help as well, simply turning down one while turning the other up while playing a note, that way one could be used normally and the one with the drop effect brought in only when needed.  I hope you find something better, but this exercise will help in future programming also. Good luck.

title: Piano Bank (Grand, Dance, Dream pianos)
post_content: This is my piano bank. It contains 15 programs, in 3 categories:Grand Pianos: Realistic and powerful piano sounds for dynamic live playingDance Pianos: Fast and aggressive piano sounds that can cut through a mixDream Pianos: Lush and atmospheric piano sounds for rock power balladsSome practical notes:All patches are programmed at -2 to -4 dB, to allow for some volume tweaking in both directions.Additionally, all patches have a default light compression and reverb setting, intended for live playing.Finally, all these default patches are limited to using Panel A only. This was done for mainly 2 reasons:For me to learn the synth better, and use all possibilities within one panelTo allow for better expansion upon all my base patchesLinks to NUS and a list of samples used are in the following posts.PS: I didn't do these as bundles, since it wouldn't make much sense to include several hundred megabytes of default sounds, and besides I also think you should be able to choose the size of piano samples yourself.PPS: These patches are also meant as inspiration, it shouldn't be too hard to edit them, change samples, layers etc. - but starting from a good base sound, instead of a completely blank program.EDIT: Dance Piano 14 and 15 have been updated with better synth piano sounds.Enjoy!

title: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Hi,Wanted to share with the community what I have done so far regarding my program viewer app. The main idea was to display Nord Stage 3 program settings (ns3f files) without any download (no Nord Stage required, no Nord Sound Manager app required). Program sheet can then be saved as pdf file. Nord Stage 2 support is added too.Online version:https://chris55.github.io/ns3-program-viewer/Offline versions (no longer supported):Windows:https://github.com/Chris55/ns3-program-viewer/releasesMac: AppStore -https://apps.apple.com/app/id1549939673Linux:https://github.com/Chris55/ns3-program-viewer/releasesNS2 & NS3 file format documentation:https://chris55.github.io/nord-documentation/Updates:Dec 2020:NS2 is also included now! (ns2p files)Jan 2021: Offline version now available as standalone desktop application for Windows and MacMar 2021: Added NS3 synth file support (ns3y)May 2021: Offline version available for Linux distribution x64 and ARM for Debian/Ubuntu (*.deb) and Fedora/SUSE (*.rpm)Jun 2021: Added NS2 synth file support (ns2s), and new Smart feature (highlight in red any setting that is different from the INIT values)Oct 2021: Added bundle and backup files support (ns3b, ns3fb, ns3synthpb, ns3sbundle, ns2pb, ns2exb, ns2b, ns2synthpb files). File collection are listed as on Nord Sound ManagerExample of program settings:Hi Resolution MW Program.png (680.31 KiB) Viewed 43310 timesExample of Bundle/Backup file:Bundle Example.png (634.72 KiB) Viewed 38753 timesExample of Smart Mode:Smart mode.png (379.72 KiB) Viewed 41108 timesThank you to the contributors @gaaal, @rpossemo, @cookie, @gordon, and @hobsterVideo Tutorial (thanks to Marc from My Keys To Music):Full source code available here:https://github.com/Chris55/ns3-program-viewerCurrent coverage:- Organ: 100%- Piano: 100%- Synth: 100%- Extern: 100%- Morph: 100%- FX: 100%- Global parameters: Master Clock/Transpose/Split/Dual Kb/Output Routing 100%My questions would be:- is it acceptable to publish this web site, or should it stay private? Should I ask Nord?- the source code is private for now as the file format is undocumented, I'm not sure if I can publish it.answering to myselfI contacted Nord and here the answer:I talked to the guys here, and it is fine with us for you to proceed with this project - as long as you accompany your published work with a disclaimer that Clavia in no way is affiliated with it. We will not be able to provide any assistance with this, but good luck nonetheless!@Clavia Support.Last thing, I do this as a hobby in my free time, nothing to sell...PS: I edited this post to reflect on this 1st message all the improvements done since the beginning...PS: want to collaborate?read thisThanks

post_content: rpossemo wrote:Have you documented your findings so far? I mean, from the binary file have you marked the meaning of each byte, etc?my source code is documented but still need to think how to produce such document if I decide to go this way. This can be added to my todo list...rpossemo wrote:I wonder if I can help yousure any help is welcome.The simplest would be to have more validation steps, like a quality check. I tested all setting one by one for Panel A. For Panel B I did that for few settings only as it looks like everything is just duplicated. But feel free to test individually parameters from Panel B. I'm following a naming convention to automate the unit tests. Example:  I created about 240 programs like that so far.example 1: testing Panel A / Synth modulefilename must be "panelA.synth.enabled eq true.ns3f"filename must be "panelA.synth.enabled eq false.ns3f"example 2: testing Panel A / Synth Osc1 Wave Form Type = Classic Sinefilename must be "panelA.synth.oscillators.type eq Classic and panelA.synth.oscillators.waveForm1 eq Sine.ns3f"I you decide to go this way, please send me all your test ns3f files and rename them to understand the changes.My biggest concern is about legal aspect if we publish this, hence my questions on my initial post.

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Let's see if I can help with something like this that I just did. If so, I can continue with other settings for Piano section, that you mentioned that is not done yet.Piano TimbreOffset in file: 0x4E (Just Least Significant 6 bits, so OR 0x2F)Values:0x00- None0x08- Soft0x10- Mid0x18- Bright0x20- DYNO10x28- DYNO2Piano KB TouchOffset in file: 0x4D (just least significant bit 1, so OR 0x01) and 0x4E (Just Most Significant Bit, so OR 0x80)Values:0x00 + 0x8x- KB Touch 10x01 + 0x0x- KB Touch 20x01 + 0x8x- KB Touch 3Piano Layer DetuneOffset in file: 0x34Values:0x00- None0x20- 10x40- 20x60- 3Piano Soft ReleaseOffset in file: 0x4D (just least significant bit 4, so OR 0x08)Values:0x00 - No0x08 - Soft ReleasePiano Pedal NoiseOffset in file: 0x4D (just least significant bit 2, so OR 0x02)0x00- No0x02- Pedal NoiseString ResOffset in file: 0x4D (just least significant bit 3, so OR 0x04)0x00- No0x04- String ResSustain PedalOffset in file: 0x48 (just bit 0x40)Values:0x00- No0x40- YesPitch Stickoffset in file: 0x48 (just bit 0x80)Values0x00- No0x80- YesOctave Shiftoffset in file: 0x47 (just 4 last bits, OR 0x0F)Values:0xF5- Shift -10xF6- No shift0xF7- Shift +1

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: And to know the piano Type and Model:Type:offset 0x49 (only 4 bits, last 3 of first nibble, first of second nibble) OR 0x98Values:0x40- Grand0x48- Upright0x50- Electric0x58- Clav0x60- Digital0x68- MiscModel:Offset 0x49 and 0x4A (last 3 bits of 0x49 and first 2 bits of 0x4A). So byte 0x49 OR 0x07 and byte 0x4a OR 0xC0Values:0x00 0x00: model 10x00 0x01: model 2.. and so on0x02 0x01: model 10

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Hi Mr Florence and others,Great job on the NS3 program viewer!As discussed, I have shared my own NS2P mapping with you (check your inbox) which will hopefully save the community some time back-filling the NS2 information.  My mapping is, like yours, 100% complete, although there is always room for bugs, and was developed by me manually over many weeks, by brute force bit comparison, same as you have done for NS3.NS2 coverage:- Organ: 100%- Piano: 100%- Synth: 100%- Morph: 100%- FX: 100%- Global parameters: Master Clock/Transpose/Split 100%- Extern and output sections: 100%I have also shared my complete software with you with MIT license so you are freely allowed to use as you see fit. It provides a more 'performance overview oriented' HTML view of the patch (see images below) which happens to be what I value the most when using hundreds of patches and quickly learning new ones. It is especially important to highlight the morphs and show clearly which parameters are affected by them and how, and to show the split points to quickly remind which hand is doing what and where.The one thing I did not ever achieve is automated conversion from NS2 to NS3. Three reasons:1. no interest in decoding the checksum algorithm to be able to CREATE a valid ns2p/ns3f file (and at first glance it was not trivial what was being checksummed and how)2. not possible to migrate synth programs due to the NS3 INFERIOR FM synth implementation (but superior in other aspects) i.e. not a true superset of NS23. Actually the practical knowledge gained by manually dialling in the settings on my new NS3, rather than an automated conversion, was valuable and really helped me learn the NS3 after having been an NS2 and NS1 expert.-gordon(standard Disclaimer applies here: The author and this work is not affiliated, associated, endorsed by, or in any way officially connected with Nord Keyboards / Clavia DMI AB, or any of its subsidiaries or its affiliates.  The official Nord Keyboards website can be found athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com- the names Nord and Clavia as well as related names, marks, emblems and images are registered trademarks of their respective owners.)Examples of HTML from the ns2p script:Lets-Go-Crazy--decoded.jpg (205.15 KiB) Viewed 5933 timesAfrica_TOTO--decoded.JPG (105.97 KiB) Viewed 5933 times

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Thanks Hlaalu !will check how is implemented the output routing, if it is per program it can be added... also @Hobster proposed his help to check these global settings, once available it can be added of course.regarding the synth engine: right I tried different approach but maybe not the most simplefirst the type is under OSC (Sample, Classic, Wave....)If Sample then- Nord Library Sample: The name is actually not stored in the program itself, only a sample ID that is a hash code from the Original Nord Sample library file. I added all library hash code to be able to translate it to a name. If the sample ID is unknown then it simply shows Unknown...- User sample: the name is stored in the Preset property. I simply show the preset name.If Classic, Wave, Formant, Super...- I show the Waveform name and optional Preset name if availableFinally if the displayed name is the same as the preset, I show it only one time... this is maybe what cause your confusion...

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: As Florence stated, I will be taking a look at other possible global settings.This is part of the work I'm currently doing which is writing a Perl script that takes an NS3 program file and outputs, in a simple and fairly user-configurable way, a text file with all the parameter values.It doesn't look as polished as Florence's online viewer as there's no real graphics but it can do this in batches and should be useful, among other things, for seeing how all Nord's presets work and for easily comparing one file that you know is slightly different to another file but are not quite sure why, for example.It was Florence's work that actually inspired me to do this as he's done the hard work of not only figuring out what 'bits' in the .ns3f file represent each parameter, but also which Nord samples are used. That last bit will have been extremely time consuming as the sample names are not stored in the file but, instead, a 'hash' of the name is stored.And as we don't have the hashing algorithm that Nord uses, he's had to individually map, one at a time, EVERY sample to the hash it produces!Being a software engineer, I can tell you this guy has put a HUGE amount of effort into his viewer!I hope my script will prove useful and will hopefully be available in the next week or two.Once again though, huge thanks to Florence and the other guys who contributed to this herculean effortPS. With regards the sample names, user sample names are also stored as hashes so, again, without knowing Nord's hashing algorithm, it's impossible to display the name of a user sample. We don't even know if it's a one-to-one hash-to-name thang or if the hash translates to some sort of internal storage mapping...Of course, if Nord would care to let us in on their hashing algorithm...

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Hobster wrote:And as we don't have the hashing algorithm that Nord uses, he's had to individually map, one at a time, EVERY sample to the hash it produces!btw I believe that this hash code is one way only. If you change just one letter from a sample filename then it changes...time consuming... yes my friend: I loaded all Piano, library 2, 3 and archive sample, also product bundles to define my own database. It contains now about 4700 entries! This was done by chunk of 25 programs each time as a bundle can only contain 25 programs... Then by automation I read the bundle to extract the hash code and detailed sample names.

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: I am using your tool a lot recently, and I can't express my gratitude enough!I have a couple of suggestions/questions.1) When an engine is ON on a Panel but the Panel itself isn't active in the Program, the tool will show that Panel's settings in a dimmed-out fashion (if you know what I mean... English isn't my first language). Isn't there a way to make them more visibile (while still providing some visual clue that the Panel is not active) -- a little less dim, to be actually readable? The "show all instruments" settings show them ALL, even the OFF ones, so it becomes a bit confusing visually.2) Try load the attached Program in the tool. You'll notice that, on Panel A's Synth section, it reads "config: 4 detune", but the wave type is super, which isn't compatible with the osc configuration 4, "detune". I was wondering if the Synth somehow remembers the last setting done on a different wave type and still show it even if it's not applicable in the current settings. For example one selects the classic "sine", goes to osc config n. 4, then change the wave type. The osc config n. 4 disappears, but apparently it is still "remembered" and saved into the Program. A bit strange though...

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: Let's see first how it works for the A1 implementation... Adding additional boards would be something easy if I had the board myself. Most of the structure is commun and a lot of what I learned for the NS2/NS3 could be reused for the A1 or Electro. But working with a remote board owner is really painful because for each detail I need to ask a program file, wait the answer, try a solution, retry another solution if requires.... it requires really a lot, a lot, a lot of time, and a lot is lost during these emails exchanges...At the end if Nord is reading this: Please add program viewer capability in the Nord Sound Manager, enable the feature even if a board is not connected (allows Stage user to read Electro file, or inverse)... and then everybody will be happy

post_content: Hi, is it possible to add the Electro 6 Patchformat ? I'm a user of both, the NS3 and the NE6, so i would be able to transfer Patches between these two Keyboards!@cookie: It´s me, who wrote the comment on my Keys to Music

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: docnormal wrote:Hi, is it possible to add the Electro 6 Patchformat ? I'm a user of both, the NS3 and the NE6, so i would be able to transfer Patches between these two Keyboards!Hi docnormal,it's not that easy ... Nord does not disclose the details of their file formats, it's therefore necessary to do a byte-by-byte (or maybe even worse: bit-by-bit) comparison of program files for each option to find out how the format works. This is very time consuming as mentioned by the developer Christian (username florence):nord-stage-forum-f3/ns3-program-viewer- ... ml#p146169One way to speed it up would be to lend an Electro 6 (your Electro 6?) to Christian (florence) for the time needed to de-code the Electro 6 file format

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: I ran into an issue. I wanted to check if all my 2-kb programs are set up in the right manner. But it seems that status isn't covered yet: DualKB or not? 1 engine DualKB or full panel B for remote control? Which engine is controlled from extern?Is it possible to sort that out? Can I help in any way? Or do I need to derive that info from other hints: The panel B piano engine is active (black) even if the kb zones are all switched off - is it that what indicates the DualKB status?In any case, I would highly appreciate that feature as it tends to be part of the more complicated structure of my programs: Depending on the DualKB status, I need to change pedals for sustain, control etc. - DualKB with 1 engine uses the Stage 3 pedals, DualKB with full panel B uses the remote pedals, Global MIDI isn't tested yet. That's what makes my use of the NS3C a bit tricky.BTW, reading a bundled program bank in one shot is a great thing!

title: RE: NS2 and NS3 program viewer
post_content: The NS2/NS3 program viewer is a very handy tool for Nord Stage users. As every Nord instrument has its own program format and the viewer is a user created utility, it serves a special use case. It's meant to help recreate sounds from one to another of the most complex Nord machines. There's even no NLA1 support which is quite close to the synth on a NS3.

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: You load samples using the sound manager.Samples that are compatible with the NE3 can be found herehttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... ry-archive

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: Thanks for your help - I understand the "Sound manager" concept now (some jungle!) - at least some of it ..I've downloaded the sound manager to my computer, + uploaded to newest version, and I've learned how to delete songs in order to get more space e.t.c.But I still can't figure out how to import winds like french horn, alp horn e.t.c. on my Nord Electro 3 ("73") - any help? hi Stig

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: You do this by first downloading the samples from Nord's sample library to your computer, then start the Nord Sound Manager and use the option "Sound Down" to select the sample and load it to your Electro 3. You have to make sure that your Electro has sufficient free memory to store the sample

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: nord-electro-forum-f9/can-i-tweak-the-s ... ml#p135144In this thread a fellow was having trouble organizing programs. I have posted some links for videos that explain everything about sound manager.

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: Egernvej14 wrote:But I still can't figure out how to import winds like french horn, alp horn e.t.c. on my Nord Electro 3 ("73") - any help? hi StigIt depends:If the sound is already in Nord Sample format (nsmp*) you can upload them to your instrument using the Nord Sound Manager application. Just drag the sample inside the Nord Sound Manager. Make sure to activate the sample section (not the piano or program section) first in Nord Sound Manager and enable organise (so you see empty spots where you drag the sample to).If the sound is a wave file, you will need to make a nsmp file from it using theNord Sample Editor 2application.How to convert wave files to Nord Sample format is explained in the Nord Sample Editormanual.Youtube tutorials:Nord Keyboards Sample Editor Training/Tutorial | Steel DrumsNord Sample Editor Advanced Tutorial

title: RE: Sounds in Samp Lib
post_content: Berretje wrote:If the sound is a wave file, you will need to make a nsmp file from it using theNord Sample Editor 2application.As I quoted yesterday, the Nord Sample Editor 3 is now capable of producing NSMP files (nsmp 2 format) which will serve for NE3, too. So you can use both editions: 2 and 3; they work a bit differently.But the desired sounds should already exist, as I suppose.

post_content: Welcome-Most of his live performances he used a Rhodes and a Farfisa.  You have both in the NS3. Find the videos on YouTube, listen to the sounds, and select them in your instrument.  When you get one that is close, use the EQ and effects to get closer.-dj

post_content: There is something here:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... sa-library

title: RE: The Doors Sounds for NS3
post_content: Thanks for the replies.. It gives me a good start.. much appreciated

title: RE: The Doors Sounds for NS3
post_content: Actually, Ray never used a Farfisa.  He used a Gibson G101 which is quite different.  One of the major differences is the ability to engage the "sustain" tab and get a longer release envelope.You can start with the Farfisa and get somewhat close, but the waveforms in the G101 are really not the same as the Farfisa.  Unless you are a purist, it probably won't matter to you or your audience.

title: Shine a Little Love by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO)
post_content: Hi everyone!With reference to the song "Shine a Little Love" by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO), I have a Nord Stage 3 and am trying to find a way to replicate that cascading descending keyboard sound near the start of the song. It kind of sounds like a chromatic glide down the keyboard but haven't had much luck so far creating the sound. Any ideas?  Or does anyone currently utilise a specific sound/patch for this song? Ideally I'm trying to achieve an effect where I can activate the sound just by pressing one key and then it starts the glide down. Thanks in advance!

title: RE: Shine a Little Love by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO)
post_content: The sound you're looking for sounds pretty much like the sample used at the beginning of the program created by WannitBBBad on the Styx - Too Much Time On MY Hands thread.Not sure if its in the right key but its pretty close as a starting point.

title: RE: Shine a Little Love by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO)
post_content: Ok thanks for the tip! Will go have a listen.

title: RE: Shine a Little Love by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO)
post_content: Transonic wrote:Hi everyone! With reference to the song "Shine a Little Love" by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO), I have a Nord Stage 3 and am trying to find a way to replicate that cascading descending keyboard sound near the start of the song. It kind of sounds like a chromatic glide down the keyboard but haven't had much luck so far creating the sound. Any ideas?....To make a sample, once you have the sound you like (it sounds like a monophonic synth with sustain to me), I would suggest recording the chromatic drop for an octave at a speed to cleanly cover the notes and let the last note sustain a little (or you can sequence it if you have a MIDI sequencer). At this point, don't add any delay effect. In Audacity or other WAV editing software, speed up the tempo (not pitch) of your recording as needed to what's used in the song. Import your saved WAV file into the Nord Sample Editor and set it to loop where it sounds correct to you. Save the file and import the NSMP3 file into your keyboard where you can then work on adding the delay effect to top it off.  That's how I would go at it to start. I hope that helps, take care.

title: RE: Shine a Little Love by Electric Light Orchestra (ELO)
post_content: Hi thanks for your reply WannitBBBad!This is pretty much what I have done now, though I used the arpeggiator set to down and added a little glide and then recorded it into my PC after which I then tweaked it a little in Audacity, exported as a WAV then imported via Nord Sample Editor and then finally added the delay effects etc ...Working great now!

title: RE: Summer Madness Synth
post_content: Hello and welcome to the Forum! The sound is very thin, so perhaps try the narrow pulse wave for OSC1and blend it with the sawtooth in OSC2, and then work with the filter Freq, EQ, and reverb to get closer. Take care.

title: I ran flock of seagulls

title: RE: I ran flock of seagulls
post_content: I would like this too if anybody has it ..cheers

title: RE: I ran flock of seagulls
post_content: Listening to the song, the low note played sounds like it has a flanger or phase shifter effect on it, and the upper part sounds like analog strings.  Just to try out, take my "Jump" program (http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stage ... mp#p112686) and make the following changes:For left-hand synth on Panel Aa) reassign the split (C3?) for just the notes needed using the Panel A Jump synth and adjust the octave,b) set the AMP ENV Decay at 10,c) change OSC1 to use the SynthPad1 sample athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... /synth-padd) change OSC2 to sawtooth and lightly add to the mix,e) apply a very slow flanger effect to it the sound,f) change the EQ on the synth as neededFor the right-hand strings on Panel Ba) adjust the octave for the right-hand strings in panel B for where you want to play it.b) set the AMP ENV Attack to 3 and Release to 4c) modify Chorus to tasteI hope that helps.

title: RE: Distortion and clean guitar sounds
post_content: Are you willing to design some sounds from scratch? Take the Nord samples as a starting point and add some effects! It will be your sound.That is what I have actually done. I play in a hard rock / heavy metal band and we have only one guitarist as well. For some songs, especially in the solo parts, a second guitar for the rythmics is esential. I use my Nord Wave for that and I mix 2 different distortion quitar samples, add a little FM and a subtle organ wavetable for extra harmonics, some chorus and delay effects, eq and a bit of extra drive to make the sound fatter. Sounds pretty good!It's very interesting also to study Derek Sherinian's sound signature (Dream theater, Billy Idol, Malmsteen, Sons of Apollo), he has developed a unique quitar sounding tone with a Nord Lead 3 and some pedals. Great inspiration!

title: Pink Floyd Tenor Sax
post_content: The forum has helped me, so here's my stage 3 Floyd Tenor Sax. Just the original tenor sample from Nord, and then I used the effects, remembering what a sax player I toured with used to tell the sound guys about how he wanted his sound set up.Some doubling delay, quick and with low delay threshold so just one note gets repeated (like a vocal doubling effect.)Some reverb.Some chorus. (I also added in a tremolo setting too.)I used the mid parametric eq sweep to scoop OUT a very 'synthy' frequency that needed to go.Finally, compression, set to 8. Lot's, in other words ... so the airy tones are up there with the screech timbre. On a big rock stage, it's those timbres you want, all of them, soft and hard, without dropping out or ripping ears. So ... compressed.All effects, just the original stage 3 tenor sample. It's Pinkish, I thinkish. Cheers everyone, enjoy.Us&ThemTenorSax.mp3Us Horn.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 558 times

title: RE: Pink Floyd Tenor Sax
post_content: That sounds great man!

title: RE: Pink Floyd Tenor Sax
post_content: That's a very useful sound -- not just for Pink Floyd!

title: RE: Pink Floyd Tenor Sax
post_content: Just remember, when sax players bend, they bite down on their reed and it bends ... up. They will create an illusion of bending down when they release that bite down on the reed, and relax back down to the note they actually played. However, unlike guitar riffs, a sax actually doesn't ever bend down, always up. Remember that with your pitch bend technique, and it goes a long way to adding authenticity. Don't bend down, and you're all good. Only up. A real sax can't bend down, except to return to the note it bent up from. Subconsciously, people will notice this and it helps to make the sound do it's magic.Ya, I'm actually quite happy with this sax patch, which are notorious for not sounding very authentic on most synths. This one, I can live with I think.

title: RE: Pink Floyd Tenor Sax
post_content: I'll add that the patch is bigger than you may need it to be. The sax is all alone on panel B and easy to copy out. Panel A has the organ and piano pad, which is where the patch size expands, likely the piano sample. But you can scrap that panel A and just take the sax panel out and use it in your own program.That organ on panel A has the rotor morphed so if you set the wheel to just below half way you get the slow leslie effect Wright used on Us and Them. There's enough room under where I have the sax split to play the piano part for Us and Them along with your sax soloing. But you can scrap all that and copy panel B to a new program and you'll just have the sax, and I'm sure it will be a smaller patch then. Maybe. Still on the learning curve over here.

title: how to download sound from the forum
post_content: hii have a windows.when i download sound the computer is not recognize the file ?anybody know how to solve the problem?

title: RE: how to download sound from the forum
post_content: Hello. Here are a few things to check: Make sure Nord Sound Manager is installed on your computer.  When you click on a file to download from the Forum, choose the option to save it to your computer. Windows will recognize the Stage 3 program (*.ns3f) and sample (*.nsmp3) files if you double-click on them after downloading if you have Nord Sound Manager installed. The manual for the Nord Sound Manager covers importing the files (drag and drop works for individual files). I hope that helps, take care.

title: RE: New NS3 user need help
post_content: When you start working with samples and want to start saving new ones, here are a few tips for Sound Manager:- View your current samples in organize mode to show open memory locations.- Sort samples from largest to smallest and delete the ones you don't need starting with the largest so you're freeing up the most space without losing as many samples.- Save all new samples to memory locations 250 and above so you always know which ones you loaded versus which ones came with your Stage 3.- If you post a program using a new sample, tell folks what sample you're using and a) provide a link to the sample if it's on this forum (retains recognition of who created/provided it and any associated discussion), or b) post the sample with information on the source if not on this forum.Below is a link to access over 70 programs I have put together for the Stage 3 that might help you. Welcome to the forum - take care.Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: DX7 and Rhodes - light Voices and Pad
post_content: I am a new Stage 3 owner and have the most basic question: Which electric piano sound on the 3 has the most similar sound to a Rhodes piano. Obviously the electric piano sounds are not labeled as such. ThanksQ

title: RE: DX7 and Rhodes - light Voices and Pad
post_content: Sorry for the duplicate entry - see below thanks.

title: RE: DX7 and Rhodes - light Voices and Pad
post_content: enbritton wrote:I am a new Stage 3 owner and have the most basic question: Which electric piano sound on the 3 has the most similar sound to a Rhodes piano. Obviously the electric piano sounds are not labeled as such. ThanksQThe Piano Library at the Nord website (https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... no-library) is a good starting point for information on the pianos available.  For a Rhodes, I use EP1 the most, followed by EP7 and EP5. EP1-EP8 are all Rhodes pianos, each with their own tonal characteristics based on vintage, amplification (or not), and "voicing" of the tines. On a Rhodes, the tine for each key can be adjusted in relationship to its magnetic pickup to get the tone desired. When Styx was big on the charts, I took a Rhodes that sounded like the EP1 and adjusted each tine to get to something similar to EP5. The amplification used in the recordings also mattered, as my Rhodes sounded quite different direct than it did through the Fender Twin Reverb with Roland CE-1 Chorus/Preamp that I used for some time. I hope this helps, take care.

title: Classic Rock and other programs - Set 3
post_content: I just purchased a Nord Stage 3 and working quickly to recreate all the patches I had on my Stage 2 before selling it. Most of the classic programs are fairly simple, but I thought some of you might appreciate saving a little time with something to start with and tweak. Note that most of my programs use the control pedal morph even if only to bring instruments in and out of a mix.With some of these programs you may need to relink the piano(s) to what you have in your Stage 3, as one of the first things I did when I got my Stage 3 was replace some pianos with smaller files to add more - I have 48 at this time.All sample locations below 250 are pre-loaded Stage 3 locations that I don't mess with. Even if I delete samples from the stock collection to add space, I keep those sample locations open and load new samples in locations 250 and above. The programs below use all the "stock" samples except for my program using "WarmPad2_CL stereo 3.0.nsmp3" in location 254.It doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store new samples in your Nord Stage 3, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load WarmPad2 into your sample location 280 (254 in mine), then you just need to point Slot B to 280 rather than 254.I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.Utility Program:My "go to" utility program is a good starting point for other programs. This has piano, strings, bass, and B3 organ with drawbars on the mod wheel. Slot A has all but the bass; Slot B has left handed bass and piano/B3 on the right. Listen through to the end to catch it all:Utility Program W.mp3Utility      W.ns3f"Utility" program with Piano, B3 with drawbars on wheel, bass, and strings by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1037 timesLayered Pianos- I love the character of all of the Nord pianos on their own, but a combination I really like is Grand Lady D with BlueSwede slightly behind it in the mix. This program uses those pianos along with strings and the B3 organ with drawbars on the mod wheel similar to my "Utility W" program.  The sample "WarmPad2_CL stereo 3.0.nsmp3" is used in slot 254 but other pads can be used:GLadyBluesStrB3W.mp3GLadyBluesStrB3W.ns3fGrand Lady D, BlueSwede, mix of strings, and B3 with drawbars on the wheel by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 921 timesI put this patch together for a song by EastSouthern called "Whisper" that I originally did on a Stage EX. Though it sounds heavy in effects, I think it fell right into the song well. The first MP3 is an example of the program, the second MP3 is the song by EastSouthern, played straight through with no overdubbing.EastSouthern_W.mp3EastSouthern Whisper W.mp3EastSouthern   W.ns3fPiano, Pads and B3 in deep reverb by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 885 timesBruce Springsteen's "Born To Run"- Left hand B3 and Piano, Right Hand Strings, Piano, B3, and Vibes in sample location 156 (factory pre-loaded). The vibe volume can be brought down using the mod wheel as needed. This might help get you started:BSBornToRun W.mp3BSBornToRun    W.ns3fBruce Springsteen's Born to Run by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 674 timesCrosby Stills and Nash - Cathedral. At a gig our guitar player sat down at my keyboard to play Cathedral thinking he was only playing piano. Standing next to him to sing, I slid the control pedal over and at times brought in a Cathedral organ and voices without him knowing - he was looking around trying to figure it out.  We've known each for over 50 years since grade school, so that's allowed sometimes.GLadyCathedral W.mp3GLadyCathedral W.ns3fGrand Lady D with mix of organs and voices by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 705 timesPedal Steel with aftertouch: A cool feature of the OSC controls is being able to tune up an octave and then have control to "bend down" the notes like a pedal steel.  Though I usually like to play pedal steel programs using the left hand control of the pitch bar and mod wheel, these programs use aftertouch on the pedal steel to take the notes down a half step and have vibrato with a delay, freeing up the left hand for playing other parts.  If you don't want to fade in the pedal steel with the control pedal, you can set the AMP ENV Attack to about 5 to fade it in:PedalSteelAfterTouch.mp3BanjoPedalSteA W.ns3fProgram with right hand pedal steel with aftertouch sliding down a half step by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 1011 timesMarimbaSteelAT W.ns3fProgram with right hand pedal steel with aftertouch sliding down a half step by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 774 timesPedal Steel - Pure Prairie League's "Two Lane Highway"with Wurlitzer and Pedal Steel. The MP3 is a live version with our other keyboard player on Rhodes and then me coming in on the pedal steel:TwoLaneHighway_W.mp3PPL TwoLaneHwy W.ns3fPure Prairie League's Two Lane Highway by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 729 timesSteely Dan's "Pretzel Logic"with Wurlitzer and horns on the control pedal. Turning on the other piano adds the "bass" note to the left hand based on the split:SDPretzelLogic W.mp3SDPretzelLogic W.ns3fSteely Dan's Pretzel Logic by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 836 times90+ programs with MP3 examplesnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlClassic Rock and other programs - Set 1 (9 programs)nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15722.htmlClassic Rock and other programs - Set 2 (9 programs)nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15723.htmlMy Pianos and Program List as of April 2020 can be found at -->post130083.html?hilit=program%20list#p130083
