title: RE: Classic Rock and other programs - Set 3
post_content: Below I've added a couple variations of the Pedal Steel above where left and right hand splits are set up - the left being set up with AT or AT and CP to control a note played while the notes with the right hand are left unaffected.  The result allows you to use your left hand on the pitch stick when you want all the notes on the right hand to slide, or you can play notes with the left hand too and use the AT/CP control to sound as if you are pressing a pedal or knee lever on a pedal steel to affect just those notes played.The first program allows the left notes to be "bent down" by the Control Pedal and "bent up" with AfterTouch.  The Control Pedal allows for smoother movement but you sacrifice being able to use the CP for volume.PedalSteel with CtrlPed Down and AT Up.mp3PedalSteelATCP W.ns3fPedal Steel with AfterTouch and Control Pedal left of split affecting pitch(592 Bytes) Downloaded 597 timesThe second program allows the left notes to be "bent down" using AfterTouch and the Control Pedal is used for volume. On the MP3 I play the first part using the pitch stick and playing with my right hand, and then I swap to playing with both hands, using AT to affect the single notes left of the split.PedalSteel with AT Down.mp3PedalSteelAT   W.ns3fPedal Steel with AfterTouch left of split and Volume on Control Pedal(592 Bytes) Downloaded 590 timesPrograms, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

Sunny regards from Germany.HI Bert,I had a similar dual keyboard setup with my NE5D 73 and reproduced my dual keyboard programs on my NS3 Compact.I have edited the Sound settings for both keyboards as follows;B3 Tonewheel Mode : Vintage 2B3 Organ Click Mode : LowB3 Org Key Trigger Point : LowRotary Speaker Type : 122 CloseRotary Balance : 50/50Rotary Rotor Speed : LowRotary Rotor Accel : LowRotary Horn Speed : LowRotary Horn Accel : LowHere's the settings for the 2 programs.Dual Keyboard B3 - WinwoodUpper Keyboard : 888642488, Chorus OFF, Percussion OFF, Leslie ON Slow - Fast, Drive 8, Reverb Stage 1 2.0Lower Keyboard : Bright Grand, Reverb Stage 1 2.0Dual Keyboard B3 - LordUpper Keyboard : 886400000, Chorus OFF, Percussion ON Soft Fast Third, Leslie ON Slow->Fast, Drive 8, Reverb Stage 1 2.0Lower Keyboard : 886400000, Chorus OFF, Percussion OFF, Leslie ON Slow->Fast, Drive 8, Reverb Stage 1 2.0Hope this helps!

title: RE: NS3 Dual Keyboard Programs

title: RE: NS3 Dual Keyboard Programs
post_content: Hi there, first of all, I would like to thank SuperStage for sharing this. It is amazingly inspiring and 'stage ready'.However, my 2nd keyboard is not a fantastic one, and it is only suitable for e-pianos and organs, but certainly not for a-pianos.So for people who is not aware, you can Swap panels easily:MONITOR / COPY PANEL / PASTETo display what a parameter on the panel is set to, without changing it, hold down the MONITOR button and turn the associated parameter knob.The COPY PANEL button can be used not only for copying a panel, but also for copying a program or a morph:1	Make a copy by holding down the COPY PANEL button in combination with one of the options below:• To copy a Panel, press the PANEL A or B buttons2	To paste the copied settings, hold down PASTE (Shift + Monitor/Copy Panel) and the button corresponding to the panel, morph or program the settings should be pasted into. Panels and morphs can either be pasted within the program they were copied from, or into any other program. When pasting a panel to the other panel in the same program, two options are given: Swap (Program 3 button) will have the two panels switch places while Paste (Program 4 button) performs a normal paste operation. Press Cancel (Program 1 button) to abort.

title: RE: Help with "Die Ärzte - Westerland"
post_content: It’s more of a Philicorda of sorts.I use the Vox with only the upper registers and vibrato.The key to getting that part in the verse is that both the first one (G) and the second one (A) are major chords — it’s just the same lick, a whole note up. The actual sound isn’t really that important: I’ve played it with the Hammond sound from my Electro 2 for years, and everybody was happy with it.

title: Organ Bank (Rock, Pads, Pipe organs)
post_content: This is my organ bank. It contains 15 programs, in 3 categories:Rock Organs: Dynamic and distorted organs for classic and original rock soundsPads Organs: Soft and ambient organs that can be used as a string or pad substitute (for instance w. synth splits)Pipe Organs: Rich and expressive pipe organs for powerful thematic variationsSome practical notes:All patches are programmed at approximately -2 to -4 dB, to allow for some volume tweaking in both directions.Additionally, all patches have a default light compression and reverb setting, intended for live playing.Finally, all these default patches are limited to using Panel A only. This was done for mainly 2 reasons:For me to learn the synth better, and use all possibilities within one panelTo allow for better expansion upon all my base patchesLinks to NUS and a list of samples used are in the following posts.PS: The level of synth layers (Rock and Pipe bank) are set to "Off" and a Morph is set up, so that a swell/control pedal pressed to 100% sets the correct volume (so that the swell/control pedal works for both layers). If you don't have a swell/control pedal connected, set the level of the synth layer to the Morph "End" value.PPS: These patches are very much meant as inspiration, it shouldn't be too hard to edit them, change samples, layers etc. - but starting from a good base sound, instead of a completely blank program.Enjoy!

title: No Son Of Mine - Padsound
post_content: Hi,has anybody an idea for the Pad-sound (not the Clock- and Elephant-Sound) for "No Son Of Mine" of Genisis?In my NS3 there is the "Soft Pad 1" Sound, but it is not the same and I can't create the original sound.Perhaps someone can help me?Thanks!

title: RE: No Son Of Mine - Padsound
post_content: An option would be to simply use the sawtooth wave on OSC1 with OSC2 blended in a little an octave up, Modulation VEL/MOD ENV set at 0, FREQ set about 3, RES/FREQ HP about 5, AMP  ENV ATTACK set at about 4.  Unison 1 or 2 along with Chorus 1 speed set low would be good to add.  Using the sawtooth works well if you want to use the MORPH function to turn down the RES/FREQ, turn up the FREQ, and turn up the Chorus amount, and have more of an Analog Strings sound for the second part in the song. Other options would include using settings similar to above with the first WAVE sound, or download SynthPad2 from the Nord site athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... y-30/synththat's pretty nice.  With any of those options you could have the Panel B synth set up for the analog strings in the second part.  I hope that helps, good luck!

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: I would recommend this for starters:https://www.mykeystomusic.com/courses/s ... ndamentalsAnd then on to this:After that, start playing around - that's what I did.

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: Both I already did. I understand the basics of synthesis and how the NS3 is build and works.The problem is more to recognize the sound you want to create.What is the basic of the sound? What sample or oscillator you use?

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: Nobody can teach you this, it's all a matter of training your ears. Once you have understood the basics (waveforms, filters, envelopes) start watching videos about different kinds of synths, read about your favorite artists gear to learn what synths they use and try recreating something simple at first. And tweak a lot to see what affection each parameter has to your sound. Good luck!

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: alex78 wrote:Nobody can teach you this, it's all a matter of training your ears. Once you have understood the basics (waveforms, filters, envelopes) start watching videos about different kinds of synths, read about your favorite artists gear to learn what synths they use and try recreating something simple at first. And tweak a lot to see what affection each parameter has to your sound. Good luck!Support this. A few days ago I looked up how E-Guitarists create their sound. In short, it's more working backwards (from Amp to Effects) and providing a matching sample as input. Results became better, and I see some things I probably can't do with the NS3 alone (harmonizer etc.).Also experimenting with sounds will help. E.g. mixing 2nd harmonic wave (A) with 3rd, or 4th and so on (B) is interesting.In summary what helps me is to separate Effects (reverb, flange etc.) from the sound I'm after, trying to figure out the sounds basic ingredients and try finding something that comes close enough.

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: matje wrote:...The problem is more to recognize the sound you want to create.What is the basic of the sound? What sample or oscillator you use?There are perhaps some basics that could be taught, but I agree with the comments here that for the most part it's your own experimentation that will get you where you want to be. Among the basics of a sound, I listen for what the sound is doing. Does it start with a sharp attack or fade in? Does the filter simply decay or is there a slight effect of it opening up first like you hear on an analog brass sound? Is the sound exactly the same no matter how long it's held?  Getting into the oscillators you can play around for hours, especially digging into the OSC2 functionality that adds a lot of flexibility to modifying the sound. You can learn a lot by taking apart programs as well and seeing what oscillators were used to create the sounds. Overall it will take some time, but I think you're already on a good path of learning what the synth can do for you, rather than go the path of simply sampling - you'll get more out of it. Good luck to you.

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: There is an iPad app available called Syntorial which seems to guide you in that direction, maybe worth to have a look at it if you are an Apple/iPad user

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: Around 3:09 there is an extemely soft part in the left side of the stereo image.  It only lasts for a couple of bars.-dj

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: It's very subtle, hard to tell exactly but not so difficult to create. Try layering two saw waves one octave apart one another, apply a very short attack, decay in the middle, sustain a bit less and release at your taste. Low pass filter halfway open, if your keyboard has key tracking for the filter use it, it will help. Balance the two oscillators as you like and you are almost there.

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: Maybe a stupid question, but what will “key tracking” do when used for the filter?

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: When applying a low pass filter the higher frequencies are cut, so as you move upwards the keyboard the sound becomes more dull as there are no low frequencies. When KT is on it adjusts somehow the relationship between the pitch of the note you play and the frequencies to be cut. You get a richer sound this way. In my Nord wave there are 3 possitions for the tracking, I believe the stage has it too.

title: RE: Online course in sound design
post_content: Oh yes, it's clearly explained in the manual - I should have read it

title: RE: How to create this sound from the NS3 synth ?
post_content: There are some accordion sounds in the official Nord Library.https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... -harmoniumIn some Presets i combine an accrodion sample with the organ (also a bit 16' action and chorus) to fatten the sound. In other Presets i add the same Sample in the B slot but one octave below ... and also a bit quiter...But i don't know if it works for Polka, Polka, Polka and if the attack is high enough in the samples.You could also try to combine one sample with normal attack curve and one with 'fast attack' (where the normal settling/attack phase is cut off). This Sound should have more 'click'.I will have a look next week if i could get this sound.

title: RE: How to create this sound from the NS3 synth ?
post_content: Schorsch wrote:Thanks to both of you, I will try to find a sample that comes closewhat I wonder about is if it is possible to create this with the synth engine rather than using a sample, will see ....I haven't tried it, but you could take my original "Jump" patch and set OSC2 an octave higher with sawtooth wave and go heavier with the effects.(Update: based on the suggestion from Alex78 below, try changing OSC1 to Supersaw as well, and still set the sawtooth for OSC2 up an octave). In my original program the second synth is set up but not used, so you could change it to use the accordion and not lose any of original sound. For the accordion, a quick filter close (Releases set at 0) would help get the effect in the song too.  Take care.

title: RE: How to create this sound from the NS3 synth ?
post_content: It sounds like a typical supersaw. You can easily make a similar sound combining two saws in different octaves, slightly detune one of them, put them in unison (I guess it is possible in the stage, I do not have one), on the amplitude envelope set the attack on a very low level, decay and sustain more than half the way up, short release, a taste of chorus, some reverb, low pass filter open to your taste. I believe it will get the job done.

title: RE: How to create this sound from the NS3 synth ?
post_content: Schorsch wrote:Hi, can one of you help me in how to create the sound from the 2nd part of the intro of this song, starting at 0:09 (replay of the accordion at the very beginning), with the synth of the Stage 3?...thanks:Here's something to get you started. Try a few different accordions to get what you like - I blended in OSC2 with a sawtooth an octave up. As suggested by alex78, for the second synth I have a Supersaw on OSC1 and sawtooth on OSC2 an octave up with some effects. You could also try a "techno" sample in its place and possibly layer more instruments to fill it out but keep the accordion out front. Take careBrings Polka   W.ns3fQuick shot at Brings Polka Polka Polka(592 Bytes) Downloaded 132 times

title: RE: Baba O' Riley / Sample and Program
post_content: Yep, not sure how you get far closer to the original sound besides sampling the original sound like I did, but for playing live what you have may stand out. As you are really looking at nailing this, the only suggestion I would have would be to perhaps use samples for the 32nd notes specific for the notes played (there's just a few) so that each note plays at the same tempo as the song rather than slower or faster depending on key played. That's the only bad thing about sampling when the tempo is part of the sampled sound - it doesn't interpolate well. Take care

title: Lead Bank (Nord, Sync, Phat leads)
post_content: This is my lead bank. It contains 9 programs, in 3 categories:Nord Leads: Detuned saw leads - classic analog leadsSync Leads: Synced square leads - hard and screaming leadsPhat Leads: "Super" leads - fat and voluminous leadsSome practical notes:All patches are programmed at -2 to -4 dB, to allow for some volume tweaking in both directions.Additionally, all patches have a default light compression and reverb setting, intended for live playing.Finally, all these default patches are limited to using Panel A only. This was done for mainly 2 reasons:For me to learn the synth better, and use all possibilities within one panelTo allow for better expansion upon all my base patchesLinks to NUS and a list of samples used are in the following posts.These lead sounds are all made using both organ, piano and synth section to add extra dimension and width to the sounds. This also means that there are some easy ways to enhance the sounds while playing:Try organ "Preset II" to add fundamental and more depthSet Piano timbre to "Bright" for enhanced attackSwitch on "Effect 1" for an interesting Auto-wah effectIn addition, all patches have a Morph setup on the Mod Wheel that modulates drive, freq and resonance.Enjoy!

title: Nord sound manager issues with loading in a new bundle
post_content: HI AllCould I please have some help I am trying to load in a new bundle however Sound manager is not accepting it. I have relocated the file, updated the keyboard and manager to latest version but still no joyany advice?I have attached as 2 images the messages that are popping up each time I try and do this action

title: RE: Nord sound manager issues with loading in a new bundle
post_content: I think this means that the files are named in a way, so that they get the same name in the NS3. For instance, if two programs both start with xxxxx_yyyyy_zzzzz_soundname, then you'll get this error.I believe bundles are simply zip-files, so try to add a .zip extension, go into the file, and see if there are conflicting filenames (files that have a rather long string in the beginning that's the same).

title: RE: Nord sound manager issues with loading in a new bundle
post_content: Hi thanks for the comment however I dont seem to be able to still get it to work

title: RE: Nord sound manager issues with loading in a new bundle
post_content: I'm pretty certain that the first error message has something to do with a file name overlap - maybe it's not the exact solution I wrote.Try and rename all the programs in the bundle (to something obscure) and load them, just to see if it works.

title: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: learning Programming on my stage 3. Starting on Night Rangers Rock in America.It sounds like there’s a synth layered with the guitar during the intro, then there’s aFast arpeggio sound, and then a synth under the verse.Would appreciate some ideas on how to start these sounds. Thanks in advance

title: RE: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: One approach would be to use a guitar sample with distortion in Panel A for the intro behind your guitar player, use a vintage synth sound in Panel B for the verse, and just use a digital piano for the fast arpeggio part. I have a few guitars posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 17012.htmland the second synth I used for a Cory Henry song might work for you atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 16294.htmlIfyou like the second synth, save it as a new synth pre-set in your Stage 3 and then add it to the guitar program in place of one of the guitars. Listening to the song, I would try to set up three sections (two split points) - Panel A: B3, Digital Piano, Distortion Guitar, Panel B: B3, Digital Piano, Synth, and then switch between the two Panels as needed. Hopefully this will give you a decent start, take care.

title: RE: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: That what an extremely thoughtful response.  I'm new to this forum and checking out all the information here.  That was really nice man.

title: RE: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: As I can hear there is no synth in the intro, it's just a guitar with a lot of chorus and flanger, a typical van halen guitar sound I would say. The overall feeling of the song is very van halen-ish anyway...Let us not forget that all those hair metal groups of this era were highly affected by Van halen's technique and massive sound. You can create the intro sound by layering an overdrive guitar sample, as WannitBBBad said, with a simple sawtooth wave, tweak the filter to find the sweet spot and apply those effects. The main songs consists of a classic b3 rock organ and a typical Jump-style synth sound, check this video on how to create it (it's not for nord stage but that kind of 80's sound is bread and butter for nord's synth engine)For the arpeggio sound all you have to do is morph the attack and decay of the same sound to make it shorter and sharper, and maybe close the filter a bit. Very enjoying song to play, have fun!!!

title: RE: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: That's a good thought alex78, here's a link to "Jump" by Van Halen to check out the synth:nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p112686

title: RE: Night Ranger - Rock in America
post_content: We play that song. There’s a fair amount of Hammond organ in that song. I use the stage 3 for the organ in the intro, chorus, and during the guitar solos. I use my Roland Jupiter 50 for the arpeggiated run before each verse, which I made out of a midi file. There is a synth during the verses which I also play on the Roland which I did as a sawtooth with portamento applied to it. I also use the Roland for the rising synth sound between the choruses after the guitar solo.

title: Bonnie Raitt - I Can't Make You Love Me
post_content: Bonnie Raitt recorded the beautiful song "I Can't Make You Love Me" written by Mike Reid (Nashville Song Writers Hall of Fame with twelve #1 hits) and Allen Shamblin. It inspired covers by Adele, Bon Iver, George Michael, Prince, and many others. Below are a few programs I put together for the song, which has no less that four separate keyboard parts on the original recording, beautifully produced.On the MP3 is a little from the original recording followed by a sample of programs 1 and 2 where you'll hear the "F" note holding in the top split while I start with the Rhodes, add in the slot B White Grand, and then switch to the 2nd program that has the Rhodes to the left and White Grand to the right for the parts played by Bruce Hornsby.  Not heard on the recording, but for programs 2 and 3 I also have B3 and light strings set behind the Rhodes on the Control Pedal, and another synth in slot B to be added behind the Grand for the second chorus where the movement goes to Gm. Take care.Stage 3 Programs - I Can't Make You Love Me w song.mp3Program #1- I usually play an intro to the song with different initial settings, so after you save this to your Stage 3, go to slot A and turn on the Rhodes, go back to slot B and turn off the White Grand, and then save it again.  Putting the synth on "hold", hit the F note in the top split and bring it up in the mix with the Control Pedal as you start playing the Rhodes intro. For the second part of the intro, select the slot B piano set up for the White Grand.BR ICantMakULM1W.ns3fStage 3 program #1 - I Can't Make You Love Me(592 Bytes) Downloaded 366 timesProgram #2- After the intro you move to the second program that has the Rhodes on the left and White Grand on the right for the piano parts (back in the mix a little).  Programs 2 and 3 have B3/strings behind the Rhodes, and another synth behind the piano ready to be selected when the second chorus moves to the Gm.BR ICantMakULM2W.ns3fStage 3 program #2 - I Can't Make You Love Me(592 Bytes) Downloaded 335 timesProgram #3- Same as #2 but a different split, an octave shift for the left hand, and White Grand set a little louder.  I use this after we get into the song a little stronger with the bass player covering the low end and me covering the higher Rhodes and Grand parts. Programs 2 and 3 have B3/strings behind the Rhodes, and another synth behind the piano ready to be selected when the second chorus moves to the Gm.BR ICantMakULM3W.ns3fStage 3 program #3 - I Can't Make You Love Me(592 Bytes) Downloaded 326 timesOver 70 programs free to a good home:For those new to programming - Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Sitar sample
post_content: Great thanks.  I did download the sample and convert it.  It seems to have a sweet spot around middle C.  And it sounds better with the sustain pedal.  I couldn’t find a way to keep the sustain pedal on automatically if it is possible.  One less thing to think about.  Thanks again.

title: RE: Sitar sample
post_content: SteveM wrote:Great thanks.   I couldn’t find a way to keep the sustain pedal on automatically if it is possible.  One less thing to think about.  Thanks again.Hey SteveM: To automatically sustain a synth sound on NS3, press the KB HOLD key (turns on Keyboard Hold). Then save with the program.

title: RE: Sitar sample
post_content: Another option is to set the MOD ENV and AMP Release levels around 2 o'clock and adjust as needed from there. Take care

title: RE: Sitar sample
post_content: SteveM wrote:I couldn’t find a way to keep the sustain pedal on automatically if it is possible.Maybe bumping up the AmpEnv release will achieve a similar effect.  Or a bit of reverb.  With sustain pedal or hold you may run into some undesirable polyphony effects.

title: Strawberry Fields Mellotron Flute
post_content: Strabery Fields intro.mp3Strawberry Flute.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 300 timesThe Mellotron Flute sample in NS3 is great for "Strawberry Fields Forever". I tweaked it a bit to come up with "Strawberry Flutes", which is as close as I could get to the recorded sound. Rolls off a bit of the high frequencies, adds a bit of drive. To play along with the Beatles, fine tune it up (about 45 cents) if playing in A, or down if playing in Bb.A few posts have questioned whether any band would actually play SFF in a bar or any other setting...some folks may find this program useless. I fiddle with sounds as a way of learning about the NS3 .

title: Lead guitar with feedback
post_content: Any tips on how I could recreate some feedback on a lead guitar sound- something triggered by aftertouch or mod wheel. Lead guitar sound is ok but have reached an impasse on how to get a delayed feedback effect....?

title: RE: Lead guitar with feedback
post_content: I would suggest setting up OSC 2 for the high harmonic you're looking for (sawtooth wave perhaps) and then morph the mix to the mod wheel or after-touch.  You could also use the second synth to work with the sound further and have the morph turn down the level of the primary guitar while turning up the harmonic feedback of the second synth.

title: RE: Lead guitar with feedback
post_content: very helpful. will have a go !

title: RE: Lead guitar with feedback
post_content: That is exactly what I did for this NS2 patch a while ago, same principle as Wannit describes:post112298.html?hilit=feedback%20lead#p112298-dj

post_content: I added a program to one of my prior posts that has a solo guitar with harmonic feedback on OSC2 using aftertouch to mix it with OSC1. If you're after an even nastier guitar harmonic, you could try adding the harmonic using the 2nd synth. title: panel A og B
post_content: HejJeg er helt ny bruger af Nord Stage 3 og føler mig meget forvirret.Hvem kan hjælpe mig med en detaljeret vejledning hvordan jeg får et Grand piano på knap A og Farfisa orgel og string (nordstring) på panel B?

title: RE: panel A og B
post_content: Lars Henrik wrote:HejJeg er helt ny bruger af Nord Stage 3 og føler mig meget forvirret.Hvem kan hjælpe mig med en detaljeret vejledning hvordan jeg får et Grand piano på knap A og Farfisa orgel og string (nordstring) på panel B?Hej Lars,Det er et engelsksproget forum her, så du vil nok blive bedt om at skrive på engelsk.Men hvis du trykker på først begge panelknapper og så slipper først a og så b ender du nok med at kun a lyser. Så vælger du et klaver du vil have i klaver sektionen og slår de andre sektioner fra. Så trykker du på b og vælger de to andre lyde i de andre sektioner, og så trykker du på a og b samtidigt. Derefter blinker det aktive panel og du kan så justere niveauer mm eller trykke på den anden knap for at gøre det andet panel aktivt. Hvis du kun vil have en lyd ad gangen, så tryk begge ned og slip den ene først så kan du bare trykke enten a eller b for kun at have den ene.Short answer in the official forum language (which is what we're all kindly requested to use, myself included): The manual is your best friend

title: RE: panel A og B
post_content: Lars Henrik wrote:HejJeg er helt ny bruger af Nord Stage 3 og føler mig meget forvirret.Hvem kan hjælpe mig med en detaljeret vejledning hvordan jeg får et Grand piano på knap A og Farfisa orgel og string (nordstring) på panel B?Hallo und willkommen im ForumDas ist eigentlich ganz einfach und im Handbuch gut beschrieben. Du wählst zunächst Panel A aus und stellst dort nur das Grand Piano ein, danach wählst du Panel B und dort die Farfisa Orgel und in der Synth Sektion das Sample für die Strings. Danach kannst du beim Spiel zwischen Panel A und Panel B umschalten.Farfisa und Strings kannst du entweder parallel spielen oder du teilst die Tastatur mir Keyboard Split auf, so dass du auf einem Teil der Tastatur die Farfisa und auf dem anderen die Strings spielen kannst.BTW: Google Translate can be helpful for both of us but it would be easier to use English, don’t you think so?

title: RE: panel A og B
post_content: Schorsch wrote:BTW: Google Translate can be helpful for both of us but it would be easier to use English, don’t you think so?Genau!

title: Synth Strings - "Random Strings"
post_content: This is my kid's program called "Random Strings." My kid is pretty young but took to the Nord right away. I'm just amazed what little ears notice in the Nord's stunning soundscapes.If you do a factory restore, program K:41 is called "Rich Stage." My kid immediately started digging into it, turning off the organ and piano engines so just the synth was left. Then asked me, "can you make a program of just that?"It's two layered synths - both square waves, but it sounds like synth strings. Changing them to triangle, sawtooth or different duty cycles changes the timbre in interesting ways too, but sticking with square waves for now. The LFO on panel B, the "shape" modulation, unison = 3 and the LP filter/Mod Env are the secret sauce here.I added arpeggiation just to panel B, I really like what it does (thus "random" in the name). But you may like it better turned off.Also including the MIDI file that was used in the demo.random-strings.mp3

It falls in between a realistic sounding sample playback and a synth brass sound. They are fine if I just need a brass sound and dont have my MODX around but I’m just looking if people have better sounds.The  nature of NS3 that is not supporting multisampling like Modx, plus its nearly impossible to get those brasses using only Synth engine avoiding samples.The best brass option, resampling good VST library.

title: How to download and install a program from a Forum
post_content: Do I have this correct? Is there an easier way to do this- I've looked at numerous videos and the manual and done many searches, but it took having my nephew come over and figure it out and walk me through how to actually get a program installed on my NS3:To download a program from a forum:So when you go look for a new program online, you will see that there are three file:.nsmp3 is samples needed to run the program.ns3f is the program.mp3 is just a recording of some guy demoing how the the program can sound in actionFirst download the .nsmp3 samples, put them in the downloads file (happens automatically on my Mac)Then download the .ns3f program fileNow go to the sound manager-go the sample library-click the “sound download” icon while in the “sample lib” view-might need to make space-click “browse for files”-go find the .nsmp3 file you just downloaded-click “open”-it is now downloaded (takes a few seconds)-move to the “program” view in sound manager-click on the “sound download” icon-find an open slot (one with less than 25 programs), M works-browse for files-click .ns3f file you just downloaded-click “open”-it then downloads very quicklyNow look at the program and see if there are any yellow highlighted “unknown” samplesIf there are, then you click “relink” icon- then find that sample you just downloaded— it could be anywhere-click on itThat should do it.

title: RE: How to download and install a program from a Forum
post_content: Warning: sending a Program from computer to NS is called "upload" on Nord Sound Manager, correcting that (i.e. replace "download" with "upload" in your procedures)  the rest is fine and there are no "shortcuts"; in some cases the patch creator may provide a .ns3pb (bundle) file which contains Program+samples "all in one" or if no samples are needed (or they are already loaded on the NS3) you will just do the Program upload, of course.PS: hi and welcome to NUF, btw...

title: RE: How to download and install a program from a Forum
post_content: Hi,1: Nord Sound Manager will show if samples on your Nord Stage are unused or not, so it’s easy to identify those which can be deleted without any concerns.2: yes this is different from samples. A number of synth presets are delivered with the factory install of the Stage, others can be loaded into it with Nord Sound Manager. The file extension for synth presets is .ns3y, these are included in a bundle file of a specific program like also pianos (.npno)  and samples (.nsmp3)

title: RE: Layering 2 preset sounds
post_content: LewTheKeysGuy wrote:Technically the reference to yamaha and korg isn't correct. the reason behind this is the motif XS and XF, Korg Krome and Kronos, even the Roland Fantom, have the ability to merge patches together in live sets or combis regardless of the engines used, I should know, I've owned a few lol.The nords don't operate like this due to two constraints.The Nord Stage DOES kind of operate this way.On the NS3, a Program is equivalent to what Krome/Kronos calls a Combi, or what the Motif XS/XF called a Performance or a Master. Look at it this way:Korg Combi = up to 16 internal or external soundsYamaha Performance = up to 4 internal soundsYamaha Performance placed into a Master = up to 4 internal sounds plus up to 8 external soundsNord Program = up to 2 sounds (panels), but each of these sounds in turn can contain a piano sound, an organ sound, a synth/sample sound, and an external sound. So instead of looking at it as a combination of 2 sounds, you could also say that Nord Program = up to 6 internal sounds plus up to 2 external sounds (with the additional qualification that the 6 internal sounds can be up to two piano library sounds, up to two organ sounds, and up to two synth/sample sounds).But no matter how you look at it, a single Nord Program is already a combination of multiple sounds.Here's the important part. It is true that you cannot combine two Nord Programs,but you similarly cannot combine two Korg Combis or two Yamaha Performances/Masters.Don't forget that a Nord Program is not a single sound like a Korg Program is or like a Yamaha Voice is... rather a Nord Program isalreadya combination of multiple sounds (up to 8... 2 synth programs, 2 pianos, 2 organs, and 2 external MIDI sounds).And on all these platforms, you cannot combine one combination of multiple sounds with another combination of multiple sounds.(Okay, not counting the rare cases where a single Yamaha Voice or Korg program consist of multiple sound at the Element/Oscillator level.)Now, let's get back to the OP's question: "I have found 2 different built in patches that I want to layer" --First, let's assume that by "patches" you're talking about programs. Take a look at what is in each panel... you may find that all the sonic components you care about are located on just one of the two panels (maybe even only one of the two panels is sounding by default), and then you can combine the one panel from the first program with the one panel from the second to create a new program that contains what you're looking for from those two patches, as maxpiano alluded to. There are plenty of Nord Programs that default to only one active panel, so there is a reasonable chance you can get exactly what you want this way.Second, let's instead assume that by "patches" you're talking about "synth presets." Well, then again you're in luck, because you can combine any two synth presets, by putting one on one panel and one on the other.Third, we'll elaborate on the approach Lew suggested, of sampling the sound combination so it becomes a single sound. This approach has numerous significant limitations, but it may be useful anyway. Lew is right that you probably don't want to include the pianos in this approach (largely because they will not sound nearly as good in a single-velocity sample), and as long as--between the two programs you're trying to combine--you don't actually need to play more than two piano sounds simultaneously, there's no need to worry about this, since you can pick up to two piano sounds and copy them into your new combined program anyway (again, as maxpiano alluded to) or recreate them (piano sounds don't have a ton of parameters). Similarly, it is unlikely that, between the two sounds you're trying to combine, you'll need more than two organ sounds, so the same applies, you can manually bring whichever organ sounds you want (up to two of them) to your new combined program. (Sampling organ sounds can be problematic because you can't effectively sample, for example, the percussion or the leslie and retain the original playing characteristics.) The most likely place you're going to want to combine more than two of something is in the sample/synth sections. Here's where you could try what Lew suggested... resample one pair of synth sounds into a single sample set, resample the other pair of synth sounds (assuming you do need the maximum of four) into another single sample set, and then you can layer those two sample sets to get all four sounds. Maybe. It will work better with some kinds of sounds than others. The trickiest part will probably be reproducing the effects. You're still limited in how many effects you can apply at once, and once you merge two sounds, you won't be able to put an effect on one sound without putting the identical effect on the sound you merged it with. An alternate approach could be to sample the sound with the effect you want, so the effect is "baked into" the sample itself. But it will likely change the sound... for example if you take a sound that was put through a phaser and sample it with the phaser enabled, when you play back the sampled version, you'll have all the notes behaving with their own phase shift effect instead of all sharing the same one. And some effects, like an echo that happens after you let go of a note, can't really be made part of the sample at all. Modulations within the synth presets themselves can cause similar problems. So, as I said, there are significant limitations. But there are some cases where it could conceivably work.Fourth possible solution... take advantage of the EXT functions, which are currently unused (as they naturally are in all factory programs), and instead of sampling two sounds to turn them into one sound, you can sample up to two of the sound and still keep them separate by sampling into, for example, an iPhone or iPad app, and then use the EXT section to trigger whatever additional sounds you need from that app. You can then use the Nord's usual mechanism to trigger two of the sample/synth sounds, and the EXT functions to trigger two more of them, re-sampled into your other device. For the re-sampling, choose the sounds that least need effects, because if you want them to have effects, you'll have to get them elsewhere (i.e. from another iOS app).In any resampling scenario, one of the other things you'll have to think about when deciding which sound will be where and how you will set it up is whether these are sounds that stop playing when you let go of a key versus ones that gradually decay when you let goThis isn't all easy, and won't necessarily get you what you want. Without knowing which sounds you're trying to combine, I can't tell you whether a given approach will work, or will at least get you something close, or if you barely have a prayer of getting what you're after. But these are at least some things to consider, and even thinking about how these different ideas work may help you better understand how the NS3 does things.

title: Automobile Engine Revving Up - Synth Created, Not a Sample
post_content: Well, I've had my Stage 3 a little over a month now and love messing around with the Synth section.  The engine sound uses multiple morphs assigned to the wheel for the quick variations needed for the effect. What's interesting is that I could only get this sound using Wave 46 - I'd be interested if you find an alternative.  When you play this, start with a lower note and as you rev up, go to a higher note and alternate 1/2 steps up/down when you get to your "cruising speed"; the notes are on a slow glide so the variations are more authentic. Among other songs, it could be used at the beginning of Living In The USA by Steve Miller Band or modified for Electric Avenue by Eddy Grant - or just have fun with this.Car Engine W.mp3Car Engine     W.ns3fAutomobile Car Engine / Motor by WannitBBBad(574 Bytes) Downloaded 405 timesPROGRAMS, MP3 EXAMPLES, AND LINKS TO MANY OTHERSnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlKeywords: Race Car Automobile Motorcycle Engine Motor Revving Speed

title: Need A Specific Synth Sound
post_content: To start, I am not a pianist of any kind. I am a drummer by trade and i know my way around a few other instruments and have a pretty solid knowledge of music / sound in general. That being said, I don’t know a thing about synthesizers or how to get sounds out of them that I can hear in my head.The issue at hand is this: I play drums in the band at a large, very modern church. The church owns a Stage 3 HP76 and we have a few different keyboard players. They’re great, can play anything you throw at them, but none of them have invested time into learning this board in and out, so none of them really go any further than the presets. (I know, it’s a tremendous waste of an extremely high caliber instrument and there are people that would kill to own it who would use it to its fullest potential). Hopefully this changes in the future, but in the meantime we need some help.In a few weeks, we’ll be covering Paramore’s “Fake Happy” and we’re looking to replicate (as close as possible) the synth sound heard throughout. I personally (again, not a keyboard player) have read the entire synth section of the Nord’s manual several times over and have watches many videos and tutorials, but I’m realizing it’s a little deeper than that. There are concepts and terminology around synths that I just don’t understand. title: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: Hello,New to Nord and keyboards.  Where do I get a list of program and synth presets?  Thank you.

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: Hi and welcome!  You can get a list of programs through the Nord Sound Manager program.  Take a look at the 2:23 mark of the "Extended Features" tutorial video on the Nord Sound Manager Page.http://www.nordkeyboards.com/software-t ... nd-managerAlso, here's a quick link to the video at the 2:23 mark on YT:----UPDATE:  I just tried this myself and the result is 5 HTML files (YYYY-MM-DD is the date the export was created):Nord Stage 3 Piano YYYY-MM-DD.htmlNord Stage 3 Program YYYY-MM-DD.htmlNord Stage 3 Samp Lib YYYY-MM-DD.htmlNord Stage 3 Song YYYY-MM-DD.htmlNord Stage 3 Synth YYYY-MM-DD.html

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: I’m also new to the Nord Stage 3 and finding it a very steep learning curve.In short, there is no list of programs and synth patches, because, I suppose, it’s all user configurable.But, there is a complete list of the internal samples on the Nord website, here:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... ory-soundsRight now I’m trying to programme my Nord for a theatre show next week.  Probably not the best board to use for this purpose, but I’ve decided to ahead (in place of my trusty Yamaha and Kurzweil ROMplers) to make myself learn how to use it.My real frustration at the moment is with the non-keyboard sounds.  Trying to find a decent soft string section or realistic trumpet is hard.  When you access the ‘sample’ bank, the samples are, basically,  the raw waveforms and it is up to the user/player to modify them to get a useable sound.  I’m really struggling with this aspect.  All the keys sounds, are of course, great!It would be a great service if Nord could provide a few banks of factory (or downloadable) programs using the orchestral samples.  I’m sure a lot of other folks struggle to make any headway with these samples....Mike

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: thank you so much ajstan!

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: Mikecruiser wrote:It would be a great service if Nord could provide a few banks of factory (or downloadable) programs using the orchestral samples.  I’m sure a lot of other folks struggle to make any headway with these samples....MikeHi Mike - check out the Synth Preset knob in the Synth section.  It has a bunch of presets using the samples and the other oscillator waveforms.

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: Also, if you press shift and turn the program knob, it will switch to list mode. Then you can hit the soft key to show categories and use the page buttons to switch between them, scrolling through the actual programs with the knob.Unfortunately, the categorisation is only partially useful, and there are no „layers“ or „splits“ categories. But it can get you started.The category list view is FAR more useful in the synth section (shift + turn the synth patch preset knob for list view), where you can quickly find a better brass sample (in the „wind instruments“ category - no „brass“ here), for example.I had a brass sound set up that turned out to not work well AT ALL in context at rehearsal. Took me thirty seconds to find a sample synth preset that everybody was happy with.

title: RE: Newbie - Nord Stage 3 Program & Synth Preset List
post_content: I'm just working my way toward actually buying it, and I couldn't figure out the list of programs. I'm thrilled to learn all the effects but feeling a little overwhelmed.The question and answer from Mike and ajstan were very, very helpful!

title: Christmas Program?
post_content: I'm looking for a patch that has strings/bells/piano that would be good for Christmas music?Thx

title: RE: Christmas Program?
post_content: Kind of a bit "Enya" ish? if so I'd suggest  building a program based on the Royal Grand 3D and  then either a soft string pad or orch strings on panel A and then from the nord sample library v3 church or carillon bells on panel B. A touch of hall 2 reverb or stage 2 reverb just to add some space to it, add some attack to the strings unless you want a more romantic feel then spread the attack so it's a slow ramp and just soften the bell strike a touch by adding a slight ramp on the attack. This should give you that sound.I'd write the program for you but the studio's offline whilst work's being done to get it comfortable due to some help coming through. once everything's back online, then I'll see what I can do, if not, try it yourself. if it's more of an enya profile for christmas then go to the digital pianos sound and add the mks70 piano to panel B and take the volume down a touch so it's more of a rounded sound to the grand.

title: RE: Girls Just Wanna Have Fun
post_content: Nordmutt2 wrote:Hey Nord Friends!  Has anyone made a good Solo patch on the Stage 3 for this song?  ThanksJust played around with it - try the following:MOD ENV- Attack 0, Decay 2, Release 2.5;ARP RunON,KB SyncON;OSCILLATORS- OSC1 WAVEFORM Classic Triangle, LFO Mod Env 0;FILTER- LP12, KB TRACK 1;MODULATION- LFO Amt 0, FREQ 0, MOD ENV 10, RES/FREQ 0; (the MOD ENV Decay determines how quickly the filter goes from the MOD ENV setting to the FREQ setting);AMP ENV- Attack 0, Decay 5, Release 3;Arpeggiator7;I also used the EQ to bump up the midrange a little with a little drive and small room reverb. Play notes quickly and only hold the ones you want triggered by the arpeggiator.  For the main sound, MvanD notes a Vox is used.  I hope this helps. Take care.

title: Advice desired for recreating “here comes the rain arp”
post_content: Hello.I’ve recently purchased a stage 3 keyboard.  This is the first time I’ve had access to synthesizer controls on a keyboard.  I’m trying to reproduce the sound heard in the opening part of the Eurythmics song.I’ve learned how to set up the arpeggiator to repeat the 3 note sequence timed with 1/16 master clock, but can’t figure out how to use the filter / modulators to adjust the saw wave to make the right sound (or if it’s possible).   I read something on a different synth site which described applying a LFO and drive to a saw wave to make the sound, but I’m not having any luck.If someone could could explain the settings or provide a program file that would be appreciated.Thanks

title: RE: Advice desired for recreating “here comes the rain arp”
post_content: Choose a saw or supersaw wave for Osc1, set the amp attack to 0 and the amp decay to ~132ms to get a short crisp sound. Turn the filter resonance to 4 and filter to taste. There is some noise added in the original, so set Osc 2 to a noise source and mix to taste. That should get you 90% of the way there. You can experiment with modulating the filter with the mod envelop or adding unison voices.

title: RE: Advice desired for recreating “here comes the rain arp”
post_content: ddavis539 wrote:Hello.I’ve recently purchased a stage 3 keyboard.  This is the first time I’ve had access to synthesizer controls on a keyboard.  I’m trying to reproduce the sound heard in the opening part of the Eurythmics song.I’ve learned how to set up the arpeggiator to repeat the 3 note sequence timed with 1/16 master clock, but can’t figure out how to use the filter / modulators to adjust the saw wave to make the right sound (or if it’s possible).   I read something on a different synth site which described applying a LFO and drive to a saw wave to make the sound, but I’m not having any luck.If someone could could explain the settings or provide a program file that would be appreciated.ThanksAnd I can´t figure out how to set up arpeggiator to play this sequence...how did you managed it?

title: RE: Advice desired for recreating “here comes the rain arp”
post_content: ChillOnTheSun wrote:And I can´t figure out how to set up arpeggiator to play this sequence...how did you managed it?I just set up the arpeggiator to use the default ascending mode.  Configured it to tie to the master clock (126 for this song) and to 16th note.  I enable the kb hold button to play it continuously  and then press G4 + B5 + C5 to get it started.The default arpeggiator is just those 3 notes repeated.  Sometimes they use a 2 octave arpeggiator, so I quickly tap the octave button to enable that for a couple measures and then twice again to reset it to the default.  It's worked out well for this song.Hopefully that description helps, I'm not in front of the kb at the moment.

title: nord stage 3 sample library latest addition E Guitar S62
post_content: HiI am new here - I have a question:I have just downloadet the E Guitar S62 from the latest addition to the sample library - but when I play it on my Nord Stage 3 compact - it does not sound like it does in the library on the website.Where can I get the settings og can anybody tell me what to do ?Thanks in advancehshjn

title: RE: nord stage 3 sample library latest addition E Guitar S62
post_content: Hi, and welcome! Here are a couple of tips:Make sure that all the settings in the synth section are default and zeroed out.  Start with an empty patch. Add a little reverb.But here is the key.  You must play the sample the way a guitar player would, as is done in the sample in the Nord Library.  Playing the sample from a keyboard player's perspective will never really sound like a guitar.  If you have a guitar, play a few chords, note the order of the notes (much different than a keyboard) and try to emulate strumming a chord.  That should give you more realistic results--dj

title: How to Delete a Program to get an empty program space again
post_content: Hi There,I have no empty programs left on my Nord stage 3. How can I empty a stored sound to make it empty again? The reason I ask this is because I need to have an empty program if I am to split the keys and have two sounds to be stored. It doesn't do it if you don't start off with a blank empty program. The Nord does'nt store the split sounds I create in Panel A and Panel B unless I can start with an empty program. Seems to me, there is no way of deleting stored sounds, you can only replace them once they are programmed to a spot. One would think that you should be able to clear sounds completely without having to do a complete system restore to factory settings.

title: RE: How to Delete a Program to get an empty program space again
post_content: You can just switch off the sections (of the existing program) you don't need or use one of the Init functions (e.g, Piano Init) on each panel.grenfernandez wrote:I need to have an empty program if I am to split the keys and have two sounds to be stored. It doesn't do it if you don't start off with a blank empty program.?? Not at all, you can create/add a split on an existing program, anytime.

title: RE: How to Delete a Program to get an empty program space again
post_content: You can just go into Nord Sound Manager, click the Organize Icon, right-click on a program and select delete--dj

title: NS 3 - Need Realistic Grand Piano Harmonics
post_content: I am knew to NORD....only two weeks old. Does anyone know how to modify Piano settings to provide a more legato effect on notes being held by the sustained pedal. I find the strings' resonance and harmonics decay to quickly when playing. This seems to be true for all piano samples I experienced thus far. Any help would be great appreciated.

title: RE: NS 3 - Need Realistic Grand Piano Harmonics
post_content: Hi, and welcome to the forum!Maybe it helps, if you turn up the stringresonance volume in the sound menu. Hold Shift and press Sound (Program 2) to get into  the menu. Then switch to the second page "Piano String Res Level" and turn up the volume a bit, using the program dial.The other way is to use the reverb effect to get a longer "sustain". Just play around a bit with the settings. Most times I use the "Room2" with about 40-50% of reverb.Greets Clemens

title: RE: NS 3 - Need Realistic Grand Piano Harmonics
post_content: If you're looking for that artificial sustain found on recordings, that's a compressor.

title: RE: NS 3 - Need Realistic Grand Piano Harmonics
post_content: Thanks - Your suggestions are helpful. I also am playing around with the synth to provide harmonics.Glad to be apart of this forum.

title: If you can help to create this Vietnamese sound
post_content: Hi everyone, I am a Vietnamese and have been using Nord for the last 4 years and am currently owning Nord Stage 3. I must be in the rare group of oriental musicians who use Nord because out of the box most of the Nord sound do not help with Far East Asian music and I think it is one of the reasons why majority Asian musicians would go with safe option like Korg, Yamaha or Roland products.I have been struggling all these years to re-create this Vietnamese instrument sound (please see the youtube link below, ignore the singing). I would appreciate if anyone could help to create this sound as close as you can. Thanks in advance for all your help.Martin

title: RE: If you can help to create this Vietnamese sound
post_content: As far as I can see, it’s mostly the playing technique.I would set the synth to monophonic, pitch bend to -12/+2, and start with the Oud sample from here:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... nic-stringAdd compression and reverb, push the mids and remove the highs in the EQ, and you should get fairly close, I’d think.

title: RE: If you can help to create this Vietnamese sound

I was also aware Nord recently kindly put some Chinese samples on their website and I went through every single one in that section few months ago but still with no hope.I understand some comments that the sound based a lot on the technique and mostly using the wheel but it has a distinctive sound which is not easy to replicate even when play a simple note (well not easy for me). title: RE: Synthi, Zusammen  by Fanta 4
post_content: For the glide up at 3:47, I put this together this morning to get you started.  The Program uses a combination of Classic sawtooth synth sound and one of the voice samples. You can try other sounds in place of the sawtooth and other voice samples as well to get it closer.  If you modify the glide duration, just note the setting and match it for both panels. The vocal volume is "morphed" to the control pedal so you can bring it in after the glide has started. On the MP3, I hit the low B in the upper split but immediately hit and hold the highest note in the split to start the glide. Take careZusammen Fanta 4.mp3ZusammenFanta4 W.ns3fProgram of glide sound in video Die Fantastischen Vier - Zusammen by Fanta 4(574 Bytes) Downloaded 324 times

title: RE: Need Pedal Steel guitar slide sound
post_content: PeteHughes wrote:Thanks the pedal steel sounds are fanmtastic, thank you.You're welcome! At the link below I added two more Stage 3 programs for the pedal steel that emulate the pedals/levers on a pedal steel. The programs require playing with both hands for the effect.  The first program allows the left notes to be "bent down" by the Control Pedal and "bent up" with AfterTouch. The Control Pedal allows for smoother movement but you sacrifice being able to use the CP for volume. The second program allows the left notes to be "bent down" using AfterTouch and the Control Pedal is used for volume. On the MP3 I play the first part using the pitch stick with my left hand and playing with my right, and then I swap to playing with both hands, using AT to affect just the notes left of the split.nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p119250PedalSteel with AT Down.mp3Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: Sample the Sound of Ocean Waves
post_content: Hello!I'd like to include the sound of the Oregon Coast into my set, but I'm not sure how to use the sample I have in the Sample Editor. When I piped it through the editor & downloaded to the Nord, it plays continuous while I hold the key. This would be fine if the sample didn't sound super compressed into one note, like a saw wave.it's not really an instrument that I'm sampling, so I'm not sure how to remedy this issue. I wouldn't mind have the sample play then pressing "KB Hold" to keep it going, but I don't hear the waves like they're suppose to sound.Anyone have any thoughts? Has anyone sampled sounds besides other instruments in the Nord Editor?Thanks so much in advance!

title: RE: Sample the Sound of Ocean Waves
post_content: Did you check this?It helped me when I first started sampling.

title: RE: Sample the Sound of Ocean Waves
post_content: You need to loop your sample manually, not let NSE loop it for you (most important) and then set it as an Unpitched Sample (so it will play the same across the keyboard), but watch the tutorial video linked by MvanD, first of all (if you haven't already seen it)PS: "sampling is an art" and as all arts it takes time to study, learn, practice, make errors, retrials,...

title: RE: Sample the Sound of Ocean Waves
post_content: Also, if you don't need to have your Ocean Waves sample in stereo, the sample size (and required sample memory in your Nord) can be cut in half by creating the sample in mono. Take care.

title: Hammond B3 - Enhanced Key Click - Drawbars on MW
post_content: Below is a simple program for those of you who want the typical B3 key click to be set at "normal" but would like to have it stand out more in a song or two, or stand out a lot with a Keith Emerson solo. This uses the Synth to emulate the key click for when the note is played. The Synth and B3 levels are morphed to the Control Pedal.  As the Leslie modifies the B3 key click, I used Chorus on the Synth key click so it's not the exact same sound for every note played. If you want it even closer, you can load the key click Synth in Slot B and route it through the Leslie too.  I use the Amp/EQ to increase the key click volume (midrange works well) but the synth level set for the morph can be reassigned to your taste too.  This is my default B3 with the drawbars morphed to the Mod Wheel for a bit of performance flexibility. Take care.B3 Key Click.mp3B3 Key Click   W.ns3fStage 3 Program - Hammond B3 with Drawbars on Mod Wheel and Synth set for enhanced key click.(592 Bytes) Downloaded 831 timesPrograms, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: GEM organ samples
post_content: I looked up "GEM" and surprisingly found that I used to own one - actually a Baldwin Howard Combo that was made in Italy by GEM back in the mid-late 60s. YouTube videos of folks opening them up show the similarity down to the circuit boards between the GEM and Vox Jaguar.  From what I recall the sounds weren't all that different than the other "transistor" organs at the time.  Have you tried your GEM side-by-side with the Stage 3 through the same amplification to see if you can get close with the Stage 3 with Vox or Farfisa and the EQ/AMP section?

title: Roland D50 Soundtrack Programs for Stage 3
post_content: Hanon_CTS posted some great Roland D50 samples atnord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/d-5o ... ?hilit=d50.  Both of these programs use the D50 Soundtrack sample in Slot A, but Slot B is set up differently.  Both Slot B Programs make use of the OSC2 functionality, combined with the MODULATION MOD ENV, OSC CTRL, and MOD ENV ATTACK among others. Take careProgram "D50 Soundtrack W":This first program has Slot B set up to emulate the D50 sample using just the synth settings. I like the effect a lot and with the synth (versus the sample) you can adjust many more characteristics of the sound including the timing of the note and harmonic being heard.  The MP3 covers three chords played twice with the D50 Sample, played twice with the Slot B harmonic synth, and then played twice with both synths on.  I then add a little of the LFO and play around a little with the MOD ENV.D50 Soundtrack W.mp3D50 Soundtrack W.ns3fStage 3 program with D50 Soundtrack Sample in Slot A and Slot B Synth emulating the D50(592 Bytes) Downloaded 448 timesProgram "D50 Soundtrack2W":The second program has the same D50 sample in Slot A but Slot B is set up for a simple “bend up” in notes played to complement the sample. The way it's set up, you can have the effect on any OSC1 classic, wave, or formant waveform, depending on what you want. The MP3 covers three chords played twice with the D50 Sample, played twice with the Slot B synth, and then played twice with both synths on.D50 Soundtrack2W.mp3D50 Soundtrack2W.ns3fStage 3 program "D50 Soundtrack2 W" with D50 Soundtrack Sample in Slot A and Slot B Synth set to bend up to the note played(592 Bytes) Downloaded 397 timesDon't forget the D50 nsmp3 sample below.Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: Lead Fusion By Jesús Molina - Background Synth Sound?
post_content: stefmazurier wrote:..Can you tell me how to do with the NS3 (with the synthesizer party) to have this Lead ?? Many thanks !!!!StefHi Stef, the solo sound in the video is a classic sawtooth wave.  You can start from the Cory Henry program posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 16294.htmlif you'd like, as the Rhodes is already set up for the left hand. The suggested settings for the solo synth to start with are provided below:MOD ENVSection: ATTACK 0, DECAY 0 (no effect based upon MODULATION settings), RELEASE 3OSCILLATORSSection: CLASSIC set with SAWTOOTH, OSC 2 OFFVOICESection: MONO, GLIDE 1, UNISON Off or maybe 1FILTERSection: LP12 or LP24, DRIVE 0, KB TRACK 1MODULATIONSection: LFO AMOUNT 0, MOD ENV 0, FREQ 3, RES 0. You need to adjust the FREQ to get the tone desired.AMP ENVSection: ATTACK 1 (takes a little edge off the start of the note played), DECAY 10 (play note as long as key is held down), RELEASE 3, no VELOCITY.VIBRATOSection: Set for WHLThe next thing you would want to do would be to find a great sound for the second synth behind the Rhodes.  Hopefully others in this forum may have some suggestions as well.  I hope this helps - take care.

title: RE: Bruce Springsteen e-street band
post_content: charomusic wrote:Hello I am new on this forum. I recently became a happy owner of a Nord stage 3 compact. I now find out that the sounds and programs of the NS2 can not be used on the NS3. Can someone help me with the sounds and programs for the Bruce Springsteen repertoire?Hello, you'll find programs for "Glory Days" and "Dancing in the Dark" atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15723.html, and a program for "Born To Run" atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15745.html. My "Utility" program also posted there may work out well for other Springsteen songs; it includes piano, strings, and a Hammond organ with the "drawbars" morphed to the Mod Wheel - I use that program and variations of it quite a bit. If you don't have a control pedal, I'd suggest getting one because the "morph" function opens up the programming flexibility in performance quite a bit.For getting a start on your new Stage 3, you might find some helpful programs atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlthat includes links to those above and many others. For any other programs you are looking for, I'd suggest checking the Stage 3 program forum using the search function - it works well when using a single keyword, but try variations too because the word has to be an exact match - for example, "Dancin" will not find anything but "Dancing" will bring up your post and mine. Good luck, take care.

title: Rick Wakeman Mini Moog Sound
post_content: Can anyone give me some tips on Stage 3 synth settings for a Mini Moog sound like Rick Wakeman gets on Journey to the Centre of the Earth? I thought that it was a saw wave, but I just can't seem to get the sound right. I know it is not complex, but I just can't seem to work it out. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

title: RE: Rick Wakeman Mini Moog Sound
post_content: Why don't you use the 2:35 M Trilogy Lead synth sound.  If that is not suitable for you, you can decompose it and/or edit it to your liking?Essentially, it's a two Oscillator Mono wave with Modulated filters.

title: RE: Rick Wakeman Mini Moog Sound
post_content: kbrkr wrote:Why don't you use the 2:35 M Trilogy Lead synth sound.  If that is not suitable for you, you can decompose it and/or edit it to your liking?Essentially, it's a two Oscillator Mono wave with Modulated filters.Great idea. Early on the album there are some parts using the square (pulse) wave and at one point the LFO on the Mod Wheel using a sawtooth or inverse sawtooth wave.  The dominant Mini Moog sound used about 27 minutes into the album is using the Classic sawtooth wave with the distinctive resonance in the decay that's also used in the synth sound 2:35. To make the sound I would suggest starting with the following:MOD ENV Section:ATTACK 0, DECAY 6-7 (see MODULATION Section for how this plays into the sound), RELEASE 6OSCILLATORS Section: CLASSIC set with SAWTOOTH, OSC 2 with SAWTOOTH +12(?)VOICE Section: MONO, GLIDE 1, UNISON Off or maybe 1FILTER Section: LP12 or LP24 (can't remember which is similar to Mini Moog), DRIVE 1, try KB TRACK offMODULATION Section:LFO AMOUNT 0, MOD ENV 10, FREQ 3, RES 6-7.  You need to play around with these settings - I describe it this way: the MOD ENV is the highest point in the filter and resonance you'll hear, and the MOD ENV DECAY setting determines how quickly that filter and resonance will drop to the FREQ setting. There are a couple places in the solos where a note is held so you hear the range of the filter decay and how quickly it decays. Working with MOD ENV, FREQ, RES, and DECAY, you should be able to get the sound you're looking for.AMP ENV Section: ATTACK 0, DECAY 7, RELEASE 5 (notes hang on a little after being released), no VELOCITY.VIBRATO Section:Set for WHLIt's a pretty clean sound, no chorus or phase shifter effects, but reverb is needed and a little echo might be nice.  I hope this helps, take care.UPDATE:Listening to this again and comparing it to my Nord, I'm having a hard time hearing whether it's sawtooth or mid-size pulse (square) wave being used (at 61, I'm thankful I'm hearing anything at all).  I tried it with OSC1 set with mid-size pulse and OSC2 set with sawtooth +12 and that sounded pretty good too.

title: RE: Rick Wakeman Mini Moog Sound
post_content: Thanks so much guys. Appreciate the Xmas present! I will get onto it and see if I can nail the sound. Greatly value your suggestions and advice. I was pretty sure that it was a saw wave and that I needed the glide - but synth isn't my strong point on the Nord, but I am working on it. Just so good to have all these fantastic people on the forum so willing to help.Merry Xmas and and Happy New Year to you all.

title: Stupid Question?  nsmp3 file to Stage 3
post_content: Hi,maybe thats a stupid QuestionI have a nsmp3 file that i want transfer to Nord Stage 3 via Nord Sound Manager newest Version.But he only can read ns3f or ns3b for bundle Sounds. This is a one Sound.How can i transfer it to the stage 3?

title: RE: Stupid Question?  nsmp3 file to Stage 3
post_content: This one is a SAMPLE not a  programm,you need to drag and drop in the Sample Section of NS3 Editor.

title: RE: Stupid Question?  nsmp3 file to Stage 3
post_content: Once it's on the Stage, you need to create a new program with a synth that actually USES the sample to be able to play it.On a new program, turn off all other engines (organs/pianos) and activate a synth engine.Set the oscillator type to "SAMP" (sample).Select the Ohne Dich sample using the rotary knob, and you will be able to play the sound.

post_content: You Drag it into the sample section of the NORD SOUND MANAGER.If you have the latest version, that will work.

title: RE: Problem with .ns3f Files
post_content: .ns3f files are not synth presets. They are full Nord Stage 3 programs that go in the program section..ns3y files synth presets that go in the synth section and can be stored as part of a program on the Stage.

post_content: I didn't think the question was dumb at all.The architecture of the Nord Stage is very different from most other keyboards.

title: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: Just wanted to discuss the limitation of 400 programs on the NS3.

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: so your band plays more than 400 songs and there are no overlaps in instrumentation needed to play those songs. Every single one is unique and requires a different program?I think you need to consider re-imagining how you work playing songs.Our band plays 5+ hours of material from the 70's to current day. In order to play those songs I need less than 30 patches.All centered around the idea that there are basic sounds for every song (Organ (B3, Vox, Farf), Piano (acoustic, Rhodes, whirly), Strings, Horns, some synth patches and in a few cases some specific sound samples (hand claps, whistles, DOH, etc).The bread and butter sounds are the B3, Clav, Piano, Rhodes, Strings, Horns etc. There really aren't that many signature unique sounds.

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: Well, kind of, anytime I'm trying to find a different feeling for each song then , I tweak a bit, I add there, smoothen Here so, yes quite more than the 30 you mentioned but no, not 300 I,haven't deleted yet a huge bunch of factory presets because I plays them first to see if they could fit.....Even if you play different songs for 4/5 hours git's, it will still be 70 songs?

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: Sorry i posted here meant to be in the main ns3 forum. However I use a lot of different sounds as am fussy tp get stuff sounding close to original sounds in the songs. So might have several variations of one sound for several songs. Also different arpeggiations etc. I normally like to keep all the stock sounds there as building blocks and have my user programs seperate from the factory stuff. I almost never use the same horn section for 2 songs, i do however use the same piano and organ but other than that mostly custom stuff if you can understand that.I understand we all work differently, but my band mates enjoy an ear for detail in the sounds programmed.

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: What say you delete factory presets then a month down track learn some new songs and the sounds you deleted might have been close to what you need?I agree if you only really used the basic sounds then you only need piano, organ etc most of the time, but then maybe an Electro 5D may be better for that use? Having an A1 synth on board theres prob a need for loading classic synth banks etc, then theres all the sampled sounds aswell its nice to have a few more spaces in that case.Be great if they had a factory bank and user bank of 8 x 50 programs.

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: @theshinenz: please stop posting over and over the same subject. Once is sufficient, you posted 5 times the same question.

title: RE: NS3 Program Capacity
post_content: theshinenz wrote:What say you delete factory presets then a month down track learn some new songs and the sounds you deleted might have been close to what you need?I agree if you only really used the basic sounds then you only need piano, organ etc most of the time, but then maybe an Electro 5D may be better for that use? Having an A1 synth on board theres prob a need for loading classic synth banks etc, then theres all the sampled sounds aswell its nice to have a few more spaces in that case.Be great if they had a factory bank and user bank of 8 x 50 programs.Hi,to try and sum up your (repeated) questions, I am afraid that if this is your approach to keyboards and you need to have a library of thousand patches preloaded in, because that is what you are used to do (and your reference are workstations such as Yamaha Montage, Korg Kronos and the likes), you may not be happy with a Nord Stage 3 which is based on a "less is more" approach and as an instrument it is not much of a workstation but more of a (very) advanced stage piano.There is not a single board which is "good for all", so you need to match your needs with each instrument specific features, without dreaming if/when they could be different than what they are. The Nord Stage 3 is what you can read from its specs and manual, it won't change. If you need more/different go for another board or be ready to get soon into the need for adding something more (a workstation?) to the NS3.

title: Request: Mother's Finest - Baby Love

title: RE: Request: Mother's Finest - Baby Love
post_content: Hey there MoonMonkey, you could try this and then play around with the settings. Starting from the top left of the Synth section:a) Turn the LIST knob to an unused patch (starts around group 7);b) Set the synth for MONO with just a little glide (GLIDE=1);c) Set the Vibrato to WHL (Modulation Wheel);d) MOD ENV: start with Attack=2, Decay=7, Release=2;e) Set OSC 1 Waveform to CLASSIC, select Sawtooth, Modulation=0, OSC=0;f) Hold down the SHIFT and turn the OSC 2 /Config knob to FINE with the Sawtooth; release SHIFT;g) Set OSC 2 to 0 (in tune with OSC 1), and then turn OSC CTRL to 0.03 (the screen shows the setting) to put it slightly out of tune with OSC 1;h) Filter LP24, KB Track=1, and try it with and without Drive;i) Modulation: LFO Amt=0, Mod Env=5 (highest point in the envelope relative to the end state set by Freq), Freq=3, Res/Freq HP=5 (this adds the distinctive filter sweep sound);j) AMP ENV: start with Attack=0, Decay all the way up (plays as long as you hold the note), and Release about 2.Playing around with the MOD ENV decay (how quickly the filter moves from the Mod Env setting to the Freq setting), the Freq, and the Res/Freq HP, can yield some decent results.  The EQ section can be used as needed.Take care

title: The Beach Boys - Good Vibrations - 5 programs for song list
post_content: I've had the Nord Stage 3 a few months now and enjoying everything about it. I was listening to the classic "Good Vibrations" by the Beach Boys that has quite a few different parts throughout the song and decided to take a stab at it. Below are five separate programs to use in song mode as you step through the song. The MP3 covers the reverb B3, synth cellos with Tannerin, detuned piano, and harmonica with B3. Program 5 (not on the MP3) includes voices to layer over those singing at the end.  The Tannerin sound in Program 2 has after-touch for the vibrato, however I use the sustain pedal to hold the synth "cello" note so my left hand is free to use the pitch bar for the Tannerin to make it sound more like the original. Make sure you download all five programs - the text for each file describes some of the sounds captured.The programs below use all the "stock" samples except for my program using "Flute.nsmp3" in location 268; this is a great flute sample with little noise.  It doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store new samples in your Nord Stage 3, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load the Flute into your sample location 280 (268 in mine), then you just need to point Slot B to 280 rather than 268.I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.BeachBoys_GoodVibrations_WannitBBBad.mp3BBGoodVibratio1W.ns3fProgram 1 - Good Vibrations - Reverb B3 and flutes(574 Bytes) Downloaded 506 timesBBGoodVibratio2W.ns3fProgram 2 - Good Vibrations - Synth Cello and Tannerin(574 Bytes) Downloaded 464 timesBBGoodVibratio3W.ns3fProgram 3 - Good Vibrations - Left hand synth and right hand honky tonk piano(574 Bytes) Downloaded 464 timesBBGoodVibratio4W.ns3fProgram 4 - Good Vibrations - B3 and Harmonica(574 Bytes) Downloaded 453 timesBBGoodVibratio5W.ns3fProgram 5 - Good Vibrations - Cello and voices(574 Bytes) Downloaded 451 timesFlute.nsmp3Programs, MP3 examples, and links to many othersnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: 80's Rock Ballad Piano
post_content: Hello all!Having a blast with my Stage 3 and digging in building some custom programs. This one is close to the Bad English "When I See You Smile" piano/synth sound. I used Bright Grand XL and Soft Pad 2 as the synth sound, so from stock, you'd have probably relink the piano to another stock one.Sorry about the quality of the MP3. My new home studio isn't quite there yet, so I made a quick recording with my iPhone just to give you an idea. Has the piano, with a touch of chorus and the stock synth has been modified to have a decaying "bell" with the pad lying underneath. To finish it off, gotta have some reverb! It was the 80's. My playing, well it was a quick jobHope it's useful for someone!80sRkBlPno.mp380s RockBalladPn.ns3f(574 Bytes) Downloaded 314 timesWarren
